This clinical trial aims to investigate the psychological factors associated with nociplastic pain (NP) in women with chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia. The study will assess the role of personality traits, defense mechanisms, central sensitization, and childhood traumatic experiences in these conditions. The study will use a cluster analysis approach to identify specific psychological clusters that are associated with each condition.

The study will recruit 150 women with chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia, as well as 50 healthy controls. Participants will complete a series of self-report questionnaires assessing central sensitivity, traumatic experiences, personality traits, defense mechanisms, mental pain, environmental sensitivity, depression, anxiety, and quality of life.

The primary outcomes of the study will be the central sensitivity index, traumatic experiences index, personality traits, defense mechanisms, mental pain, and environmental sensitivity. The secondary outcomes will include the presence and intensity of psychological symptoms of depression, anxiety, and psychosomatics, physical and psychological quality of life, alexithymic traits, perceived social support, sexual satisfaction, and genital pain.

The study will provide valuable insights into the psychological factors that contribute to NP in women with chronic migraine, fibromyalgia, and vulvodynia, and may inform the development of targeted interventions to improve symptom management and quality of life in these women.

assistant

This randomized controlled trial compares the pressure ulcer prevention effects of two mattresses with different support surfaces in bedridden patients. The study includes 18-year-old or older patients with a low risk rating on the Braden Scale, a BMI not exceeding 30, and no pressure sores upon admission. Patients are randomly assigned to either a group using a massage mattress with a cube/block system or a group using a standard viscoelastic pressure sore prevention mattress.

The primary outcome measure is the number of patients without pressure ulcers, assessed after four weeks. Patients in both groups undergo daily pressure ulcer assessments and have their pressure sore area calculated in square centimeters. The study aims to determine if the massage mattress with a cube/block system is more effective in preventing pressure ulcers compared to the standard mattress.

assistant

The study aims to investigate the effect of exercise with augmented reality glasses (AR) on metabolic parameters, anthropometric measurement values, and quality of life in children with Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) aged 10-12. The study will randomly assign 60 children with T1DM to either an experimental group or a control group. The experimental group will participate in a 12-week exercise program using AR glasses, while the control group will receive no intervention. The primary outcome measures will be changes in HbA1c levels, body mass index, and quality of life. The study will assess the effectiveness of AR-based exercise in improving metabolic control, reducing the risk of complications, and enhancing quality of life in children with T1DM.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: The Effect of Virtual Reality on Preoperative Anxiety Before Abdominal Surgery

Objective: To evaluate the effect of virtual reality on anxiety management before abdominal surgery in patients undergoing surgery.

Methodology:

* This is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label study with three arms: experimental (virtual reality glasses), placebo (non-virtual reality glasses), and control (no intervention).
* Patients will be asked to watch a video with or without virtual reality glasses, and their anxiety levels will be measured using the Visual Anxiety Scale (VAS-A) and a smart wristband that detects stress-related changes.
* The study will include 96 patients, aged 18-70 years, who are undergoing abdominal surgery and meet the inclusion criteria.
* The primary outcome measures are the preoperative anxiety levels measured by the smart wristband and VAS-A scale before and after watching the video.

Keywords: anxiety, preoperative period, virtual reality.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Clinical Performance and Safety of Suture-TOOL for Abdominal Wound Closure in Men and Women Patients Undergoing Elective Open Abdominal Surgery

Objective: To evaluate the clinical performance and safety of Suture-TOOL, a device for fast and standardized closure of the abdominal fascia, in patients undergoing elective open abdominal surgery.

Eligibility: Patients aged 18 years or older with a BMI of 18-40 kg/m2, undergoing elective open abdominal surgery for benign or malignant colorectal disease through midline incision, with an anticipated incision length of ≥ 12 cm.

Intervention: Patients will undergo laparotomy closure with Suture-TOOL.

Primary Outcome Measure: Proportion of patients with a Suture length/Wound length (SL/WL) ratio ≥ 4.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Stitch count, number of sutures used, incision closure time, surgeons' comfort with the device, and surgeons' satisfaction with the final closure result.

The study is a single-arm, open-label, prospective interventional study with a primary purpose of prevention.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Immune Biomarker Study for Salivary Gland Carcinoma

Objective: To investigate the immune characteristics of patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma in the head and neck region, and compare them to patients with benign salivary gland tumors and healthy controls.

Design: Observational study with three arms: patients with primary salivary gland carcinoma, patients with benign salivary gland tumors, and healthy controls with functional diseases of the nose or ear.

Interventions: Sampling of blood, saliva, and stool samples from all participants.

Primary Outcome Measures:

1. Changes in an established immune matrix (intratumoral and systemic) using liquid immune profile-based signature (LIPS) and Tumor Associated Lymphocytes (TAL).
2. Longitudinal immunophenotyping of patients to detect about 30 distinct immune cell subtypes and their activation markers.
3. Analysis of cytokines in peripheral blood and their change at certain points in the course of treatment.
4. Analysis of patients' metabolic state using mass-spectrometric untargeted metabolomics.
5. Analysis of patients' microbiomic state by examination of saliva, tumor, and stool samples using 16S rRNA deep sequencing.

Duration: Up to 5 years.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Determination of Compliance to Mediterranean Diet, Impacts on Walking and Quality of Life in Multiple Sclerosis

Objective: To evaluate the compliance of patients with multiple sclerosis (MS) to the Mediterranean diet, their use of nutritional supplements, physical activity habits, walking-related problems, and quality of life, and to determine if there is a significant relationship between these parameters.

Study Population: Adults aged 18-65 with a diagnosis of MS, who have voluntarily agreed to participate in the research and meet the inclusion criteria.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Mediterranean Diet Compliance Status (evaluated using the 14-item Mediterranean Diet Adaptation Scale)
* Quality of Life of Multiple Sclerosis Patients (evaluated using the Multiple Sclerosis International Quality of Life Scale)
* Impacts on Walking (evaluated using the 12-item MS Gait Scale)
* Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS)

Duration: The study will last for 1 year, with assessments at 1, 2, and 12 months.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Efficacy and Safety of Selective Intensive Induction Therapy Based on Ustekinumab Clinical Decision-making Tools in Patients With Crohn's Disease (SIIT-CD Study)

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools in patients with Crohn's disease.

Design: Multicenter, prospective, randomized, controlled study with a parallel assignment design.

Eligibility: Patients aged 18-75 years with a diagnosis of Crohn's disease, active disease, and moderate to low responsive activity, as determined by UST-CDST scores. Exclusion criteria include extensive colectomy, significant liver or kidney disease, and contraindications to ustekinumab.

Interventions: Participants were randomly assigned to either an experimental group receiving selective intensive induction therapy based on ustekinumab clinical decision-making tools or a control group receiving non-intensive induction therapy.

Primary Outcome Measure: The difference in clinical response rate at week 24 between the intensive induction regimen and standard induction regimen.

The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of selective intensive induction therapy in patients with Crohn's disease, with a focus on improving treatment outcomes and reducing disease activity.

The study, "The Preference of a Culturally and Linguistic Diverse (CALD) Population for Second Line OAB Therapy: a Discrete Choice Experiment", aims to investigate the preferences of a diverse population with overactive bladder (OAB) for second-line therapies. The study includes adult patients with OAB who have not received sacral neuromodulation (SNM) or onabotulinum toxin A (Botox) in the past. Participants will fill out a questionnaire, making a choice between two fictive therapies with varying characteristics, including Botox and SNM. The primary outcome measure is the discrete choice questionnaire, which will be completed within 1 hour.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Three-arm Pragmatic Randomized Study on the Effectiveness, Feasibility, Acceptability, and Cost of the Use of Continuous Glucose Monitoring Devices Among People Living With Type 1 Diabetes in South Africa

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, and cost of continuous glucose monitoring (CGM) devices among people living with type 1 diabetes in South Africa, compared to standard of care and intermittent CGM use.

Design: Three-arm pragmatic randomized controlled study with 15-month duration. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: Arm 1 (continuous CGM use), Arm 2 (intermittent CGM use), or Arm 3 (standard of care).

Interventions: Arm 1: continuous CGM use for 9 months; Arm 2: intermittent CGM use for 4 time points (2 weeks each) over 9 months; Arm 3: standard of care (self-monitoring of blood glucose).

Outcomes: Primary outcome measure: change in HbA1c levels. Secondary outcomes: variability of blood glucose concentrations, unplanned visits to outpatient clinics and/or hospital, quality of life, acceptability and feasibility of CGM use, and cost of CGM use.

Participants: People living with type 1 diabetes, their caregivers, and healthcare providers at three study clinics in South Africa.

Duration: 15 months.

This study aims to provide evidence on the effectiveness, feasibility, acceptability, and cost of CGM devices in a real-world setting, informing policy and decision-making on their use in South Africa.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Fractionated Stereotactic Ablative Body Radiotherapy (SBRT) With Focal Dose Escalation on Dominant Lesion in Localized Prostate Cancer

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of SBRT with focal dose escalation on dominant lesion (DIL) in patients with localized prostate cancer.

Design: Single-arm, open-label study with 5 fractions of SBRT delivered to the entire prostate and a simultaneous integrated focal boost (SIB) to the DIL.

Eligibility: Patients with histologically confirmed adenocarcinoma of the prostate, primary localized disease, and intermediate or high-risk disease according to NCCN 2023.

Intervention: SBRT with focal boost delivered to a dose of 36.25 Gy in 5 fractions to the entire prostate and up to 50 Gy in 5 fractions to the DIL.

Primary Outcome Measures: Biochemical progression-free survival (PSA nadir +2 ng/ml) at 3 years and local control (disappearance of suspicious image on mpMRI) at 12 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Incidence and severity of acute and late urinary and rectal treatment-related adverse events, patient-reported outcomes and quality of life assessment using the EPIC-26 short form and IPSS.

The SMILER study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a serious game (SG) as an emerging e-health intervention for young people with neurologic or respiratory disorders, specifically asthma. The study involves 12-17 year olds with controlled asthma, who will be randomly assigned to either a group that receives the SG intervention or a control group that follows the standard treatment plan.

The SG is a running game that uses a 4K projector and Kinect sensor to track the child's movements and adapt the experience based on their motor skills and physiological data. The game includes exercises such as side bending, high jump, side lunge, and squat to help children with asthma maintain an aerobic zone.

The primary outcome measures are the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PedsQL) and the Skills and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ-Ita), which will be assessed at 6 months. The secondary outcome measure is the Conserved Transcriptional Response to Adversity (CTRA), also assessed at 6 months.

Exclusion criteria include flare-ups requiring oral corticosteroids, recent use of leukotriene receptor antagonists or therapy, respiratory infections, and various medical conditions. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the SG in improving quality of life and asthma management in young people with asthma.

assistant

The study "Cue Effects in Human Addiction: Pavlovian to Instrumental Transfer" aims to investigate the effects of acute and chronic stress on Pavlovian to Instrumental Transfer (PIT) in individuals with mild to moderate alcohol use disorder (AUD) and healthy controls. PIT is a process where a previously learned association between a stimulus and a reward influences subsequent behavior. The study consists of three experiments, each with a different design and focus.

Experiment 1 assesses the effects of acute and chronic stress on PIT in AUD individuals and healthy controls. The study uses a 2x2 design, with stress or no stress induction and AUD or healthy control groups. The primary outcome measures include neural PIT effects, behavioral PIT effects, and chronic stress levels.

Experiment 2 explores the relationships between PIT, cognitive control, and substance use disorders. The study uses a 2x3 factorial design, with AUD and non-AUD groups, and daily smokers, non-daily smokers, and non-smokers. The primary outcome measures include interference costs, PIT effects, and associations between PIT effects and substance use disorder symptoms.

Experiment 3 investigates the effects of outcome-specific PIT on behavior and neural activity. The study uses a full PIT paradigm, which includes primary reinforcers and Pavlovian stimuli. The primary outcome measures include behavioral PIT effects, neural PIT effects, and associations between PIT effects and substance use disorder symptoms.

The study also includes secondary outcome measures, such as saliva cortisol concentrations, alcohol consumption after 12 months, and cognitive control measures. The study aims to provide insights into the neural mechanisms underlying PIT and its relationship to substance use disorders, as well as the effects of stress on PIT.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Flow and Grow - The Ideal Time to Wean CPAP Off In Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants

Study Overview:
This is a multicenter, non-blinded, randomized control trial involving premature neonates born between 23 0/7 and 29 6/7 weeks gestational age. The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a standardized maintenance/weaning protocol for CPAP in extremely low birth weight infants.

Objectives:
The primary objective is to reduce the CPAP weaning failure rate by 50% compared to standard unit-specific practices. Secondary objectives include evaluating the rates of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids, and other respiratory outcomes.

Design:
The study is a randomized, parallel-group design with two arms: the treatment group (standardized NIS wean) and the control group (routine care). Infants in the treatment group will remain on CPAP until either 32 or 34 weeks CGA, depending on their gestational age at birth. The control group will be weaned according to unit-specific practices.

Primary Outcome Measure:
The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with CPAP/NIS weaning failure, defined as needing more support and/or increased sleep stimulation events after weaning off CPAP/NIS.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
Secondary outcomes include rates of bronchopulmonary dysplasia, use of postnatal steroids, and other respiratory outcomes, as well as feeding performance, nosocomial infections, and retinopathy of prematurity.

Participation Criteria:
Eligible participants must be admitted to the NICU at one of the participating centers, born at less than 30 weeks GA, and have informed parental consent obtained. Exclusion criteria include known congenital anomalies or complications that require long-term support.

Study Plan:
The study will enroll 130 infants and will take place over a period of approximately 4 months. The study will be conducted at four Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs) within the Rady Children's/University of California, San Diego network.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Efficacy and Safety Study of Frexalimab (SAR441344) in Adults With Nonrelapsing Secondary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Frexalimab (SAR441344) compared to placebo in adults with nonrelapsing secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS).

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled, Phase 3 trial.

Population: Adults aged 18-60 years with a previous diagnosis of relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) and a current diagnosis of SPMS, with documented evidence of disability progression and no clinical relapses for at least 24 months.

Interventions: Participants will receive either Frexalimab (SAR441344) or placebo via intravenous infusion, along with MRI contrast-enhancing agents.

Primary Outcome Measure: Time to onset of composite confirmed disability progression (cCDP) confirmed over 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Include time to onset of individual components of the composite, confirmed over 3- or 6-months, as well as measures of disability improvement, MRI lesion activity, brain volume loss, cognitive function, and patient-reported outcomes.

Duration: The study will last for approximately 5 years, with participants undergoing assessments at regular intervals.

This summary captures the key aspects of the trial, including the objective, design, population, interventions, primary and secondary outcome measures, and duration.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Comparative Study Between Modified Millard and Mishra Technique in Unilateral Cleft Lip Repair: a Randomised Controlled Study

Objective: To compare the outcomes of modified Millard and Mishra techniques in repairing unilateral cleft lip in infants aged 2-6 months.

Population: Infants with unilateral isolated cleft lip, aged 2-6 months, with incomplete and complete cleft lip.

Interventions: The study will randomly assign 21 patients to three groups: a control group, a group receiving the Mishra technique repair, and a group receiving the modified Millard technique repair.

Primary Outcome Measures: Surgical repair unilateral cleft lip measurements, including vertical lip height, horizontal lip length, and philtral length, will be assessed at 3 months post-operative.

This randomized controlled study aims to compare the effectiveness of two surgical techniques in repairing unilateral cleft lip in infants, with the goal of achieving a symmetrical lip and restoring the face's natural appearance and functional structure.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Endoscopic Management of Controlled Colo-cutaneous Fistula as a Complication of Acute Sigmoid Diverticulitis: A Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of endoscopic management of colo-cutaneous fistula as a complication of acute sigmoid diverticulitis using the OTSC (Ovesco Endoscopy) clip system.

Methodology: A randomized controlled trial was conducted at Zagazig University hospital between December 2020 and August 2023. Sixty-six patients with controlled colo-cutaneous fistula due to acute sigmoid diverticulitis were randomly assigned to either an endoscopic group (EG) or a surgical group (SG). The endoscopic group underwent endoscopic management of the fistula using the OTSC clip system, while the surgical group underwent sigmoid resection with primary anastomosis.

Primary Outcome Measure: Incidence of recurrence of fistula within one week after endoscopy.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Incidence of side effects of endoscopy within one month after surgery.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with controlled colo-cutaneous fistula due to acute sigmoid diverticulitis, recurrent fistula, and failed conservative measures, with good general condition (ASA I&II).

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with high output fistula, poor general condition (ASA III&IV&V), and those who responded to conservative measures.

The study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of endoscopic management of colo-cutaneous fistula as a complication of acute sigmoid diverticulitis and to reduce morbidity and mortality endoscopically.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Multidisciplinary Approach for High Risk Patients Leading to Early Diagnosis of Canadians in Heart Failure

Objective: To improve the screening of heart failure and identify patients at risk for heart failure earlier, with the goal of determining if early screening and treatment can help prevent further decline in these patients.

Design: Randomized, un-blinded study comparing usual care to an intervention group receiving early heart failure testing.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients aged 40 years or older with at least two additional risk factors for heart failure, including coronary artery disease, diabetes, atrial fibrillation, and others.

Intervention: The intervention group will receive NT-proBNP testing, AI echocardiogram, electrocardiogram, and cardiovascular physical examination if their NT-proBNP level is elevated.

Primary Outcome Measures: The number of participants diagnosed with heart failure, number of outpatient HF visits, number of urgent HF visits, and number of HF hospitalizations.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The incidence of prescription for guideline-recommended HF therapies in patients diagnosed with HFrEF and HF events in HFrEF.

This study aims to identify patients at high risk for heart failure and provide early screening and treatment to prevent further decline.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This is a prospective, observational study aiming to evaluate the effects of propofol dosing based on lean body weight (LBW) in patients undergoing general anesthesia for 2-6 hours. A total of 80 patients with a mean body mass index (BMI) between 18-35 will be included. Patients will undergo body analysis with Tanita before the operation to calculate total body weight (TBW), ideal body weight (IBW), and LBW. Propofol infusion will be started according to TBW and stopped when the Bispectral Index (BIS) value reaches 50-40. The total dose of propofol given will be calculated according to TBW, IBW, and LBW, and the relationship between the doses given and BMI will be evaluated. The primary outcome measure is the ratio of propofol dose with sufficient depth of anesthesia according to total and lean body weight.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Open Label Trial of Oral Letermovir for CMV Prophylaxis in Thoracic Transplant Recipients

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and tolerability of oral letermovir for CMV prophylaxis in heart and lung transplant recipients.

Design: Prospective cohort design comparing subjects who received letermovir for CMV prophylaxis with those who received standard valganciclovir prophylaxis in the pre-intervention period.

Eligibility Criteria: Heart or lung transplant recipients, CMV seropositive, able to start oral CMV prophylaxis within 14 days of transplantation, and meet other inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Intervention: Letermovir 480 MG (Prevymis) for CMV prophylaxis in thoracic organ transplant recipients.

Primary Outcome Measures: CMV viral load, proportion of days during which appropriately renally-dosed prophylaxis was administered.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Frequency of acute cellular rejection, proportion of subjects who develop CMV resistance, neutropenia, severe thrombocytopenia, unplanned discontinuation of MMF or azathioprine, and incorrect renal dosing.

Duration: Up to 365 days, depending on organ transplanted and donor and recipient CMV status.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

The study aimed to develop and validate the PHYSIOSCORE, a scale to assess the complexity level and physical therapy care in hospitalized patients with heart and lung diseases. The PHYSIOSCORE consists of 106 items, divided into three domains: respiratory, imaging, and neuromuscular. The scale was developed and validated through a three-phase process: Phase 1 involved a committee of physical therapists reviewing and classifying variables used in clinical practice; Phase 2 assessed the interrater reliability and concordance of the scale; and Phase 3 conducted a clinical validation of the instrument. The study included 110 patients with cardiac or surgical conditions, who were assessed by two physical therapists at different times during hospitalization. The primary outcome measures were respiratory and neuromuscular variables, including lung function, breath sounds, PaO2/FiO2 ratio, muscle strength, and postural control. The study aimed to establish the PHYSIOSCORE as a reliable and valid tool for assessing the complexity level and physical therapy care in hospitalized patients.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

Title: Selective Adjuvant Therapy for HPV-mediated Oropharynx SCCs Based on Residual Circulating Tumor DNA Levels (SAVAL)

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of a selective adjuvant therapy approach for patients with HPV-mediated oropharynx squamous cell carcinoma (OPSCC) based on residual circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) levels.

Design: This is a single-arm, open-label, phase II trial enrolling patients with p16+ OPSCC who are candidates for surgery (TORS) and have positive ctDNA levels.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with p16+ OPSCC, clinical stage T0-3, N0-N1, and M0 disease, and positive ctDNA levels prior to surgery.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with distant metastasis, prior invasive malignancy, prior systemic chemotherapy, prior radiotherapy to the region of the study cancer, or active drug or alcohol dependency.

Intervention: Patients will undergo TORS and observation on the experimental arm of the study. Those with intermediate risk features and negative post-operative ctDNA will be observed without adjuvant radiation therapy.

Primary Outcome Measure: Progression-free Survival (PFS) at 2 years post-last treatment.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Rate of Recurrence, Rate of Salvage, Locoregional recurrence (LRR), Overall Survival (OS), Freedom from Distant Metastases (FFDM), and patient-reported outcomes (PRO) such as xerostomia, dysphagia, and quality of life.

This trial aims to reduce acute and long-term side effects associated with current treatment approaches while maintaining excellent oncologic outcomes for patients with HPV-mediated OPSCC.

This is a single-institution, prospective, phase 2 clinical trial comparing ultra-hypofractionated whole breast irradiation (WBI) to partial breast irradiation (PBI) in women with breast cancer who have undergone breast-conserving surgery. The study aims to evaluate the acute and late toxicity of the two radiotherapy regimens, as well as their effects on local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life. The study population includes women aged 50 years or older with invasive ductal carcinoma, tumor size ≤ 3 cm, R0 resection, and no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or extensive intraductal component. The trial uses a randomized, open-label design with two arms: ultra-fractionated PBI and ultra-fractionated WBI. The primary outcome measures are acute and late toxicity, while secondary outcome measures include local-regional control, disease-free survival, overall survival, distant metastasis occurrence, cosmetic outcome, and quality of life.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

The study, "Evaluating Patient-Reported Outcomes and Wearable Data Among Individuals With Relapsed/Refractory Multiple Myeloma," aims to explore the use of digital health coaching and wearable data to inform a more complete understanding of the impact of multiple myeloma on symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and financial, physiologic, and psychosocial well-being among patients with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma. The study will enroll 100 patients and provide them with a digital health coaching program and a Fitbit device for activity tracking. The primary outcome measure is the feasibility of the digital health coaching intervention, and secondary outcome measures include changes in self-efficacy and symptom burden. The study aims to establish the feasibility of a digital health coaching intervention for individuals with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma and provide insights into their symptom burden, health self-efficacy, and well-being through the integration of patient-reported, wearable, and clinical data.

This is a 4-week pilot study to investigate the effect of a dietary supplement, WholeFiberTM, on inflammation, gut microbiota, and complaints in patients with Inflammatory Bowel Diseases (IBD), specifically Ulcerative Colitis (UC) and Crohn's Disease (CD). The study aims to explore the effect of a 10-20 g/day WholeFiberTM intervention on fecal calprotectin, IBD complaints, quality of life (QoL), serum inflammatory markers, gut microbiota, and short-chain fatty acid (SCFA) levels.

Twelve patients with mild to moderate IBD complaints will be included, with 6 patients with UC and 6 patients with CD. The patients will receive 1 sachet of 10g WholeFiberTM for the first 2 weeks and 2 sachets of 10g WholeFiberTM per day for the last 2 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in fecal calprotectin levels after the 4-week intervention.

Secondary outcome measures include changes in IBD complaints, QoL, stool consistency, stool frequency, fecal microbiota composition, SCFA levels, serum inflammatory markers, and oxidative stress. The study will also assess the feasibility and acceptance of the WholeFiberTM intervention in this population.

The study will provide valuable insights into the potential benefits of WholeFiberTM as a dietary supplement for patients with IBD and its effects on inflammation, gut microbiota, and QoL.

assistant

This randomized clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of porcine acellular dermal matrix (PADM) in combination with coronally advanced flap (CAF) for the treatment of localized gingival recessions. The study includes 18-60 year old patients with localized gingival recessions (3-5mm in height) and at least 2mm of keratinized tissue width. Patients are randomly assigned to either the active comparator group receiving CAF alone or the experimental group receiving CAF associated with PADM. The primary outcome measure is recession reduction, evaluated at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. Secondary outcome measures include thickness of keratinized tissue evaluation at the same time points.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This is a longitudinal crossover clinical trial aiming to compare the effects of physical exercise performed through virtual reality games versus conventional physical exercise on heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients during hemodialysis sessions. The trial consists of two groups: Group A, which performs virtual reality exercises, and Group B, which performs conventional physical exercise on a cycle ergometer. Each group undergoes 10 interventions, with a 1-week washout period in between, during which they switch exercises. The primary outcome measure is heart rate variability behavior during interventions, while secondary outcomes include blood pressure, heart rate, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation. The trial aims to determine the relative effectiveness of virtual reality exercise compared to conventional exercise in improving heart rate variability modulation in chronic renal patients during hemodialysis sessions.

assistant

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between ventilatory variability and dyspnea in patients undergoing invasive mechanical ventilation during a weaning trial. The study will assess the presence and intensity of dyspnea using the MV-RDOS scale and VAS-D, respectively. Ventilatory variability will be measured using two indices: the coefficient of variation (CV) of chest expansion and the H1/DC component of the respiratory signal. The study will also collect surface electromyography (EMG) signals from extra-diaphragmatic inspiratory muscles. The primary outcome measures are clinically significant dyspnea defined by D-VAS > 30 mm and MV-RDOS ≥ 2.6. The study will enroll 100 patients, including 50 communicative and 50 non-communicative patients, and will compare the variability indices and EMG signals between patients with clinically significant dyspnea and those without. The study will also assess the performance of the variability indices and MV-RDOS in predicting dyspnea and failure of the weaning trial.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Randomized Control Trial Comparing the Outcome of a Modified Mini-incision Approach Versus the Conventional Approach for Carpal Tunnel Release

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of a modified mini-incision approach versus the conventional approach for carpal tunnel release in patients with primary carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).

Methods: This randomized controlled trial will enroll patients with primary CTS who have failed conservative treatment. Patients will be randomly assigned to either a mini-incision group or a conventional incision group. The mini-incision group will undergo a modified mini-incision approach, while the conventional incision group will undergo a traditional incision approach. Patients will be followed up at 2 weeks, 1 month, 3 months, and 6 months post-decompression to assess improvement in symptoms, postoperative complications, scar effect, and recurrence of symptoms.

Primary Outcome Measure: Improvement in carpal tunnel syndrome associated pain, measured using the visual analogue scale (VAS) at 6 months postoperative.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Pillar pain, recurrence of neuropathic symptoms, operative time, and scar effect, measured at various time points postoperatively.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with primary CTS, aged 18-65 years, with EMG-and NCS-proved median neuropathy at the wrist, and failed conservative treatment. Exclusion criteria include presence of proximal radiculopathy, previous history of cervical spondylosis, inflammatory joint disease, and other hand pathology.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Effectiveness of an Intervention Using Observation/Action Therapy Among Patients With Mild Cognitive Impairment

Objective: To investigate the effectiveness of Action Observation Therapy (AOT) in improving cognitive status, upper limb function, activities of daily living (ADL), gait, and balance in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

Design: A randomized, open-label trial with three arms: (1) patients with MCI observing a therapist, (2) patients with MCI observing individuals without cognitive impairment, and (3) a control group receiving standard treatment.

Intervention: A 5-week exercise program based on observation and action, focusing on strengthening, balance, and functional exercises to improve gait. The program will be progressive each week, with sessions lasting 20-30 minutes, three days a week.

Outcome Measures:

* Changes in cognitive impairment (Montreal Cognitive Assessment)
* Changes in ADL (Barthel index)
* Changes in functionality (Fugl-meyer scale)
* Changes in upper limb dexterity (Box and block test)
* Changes in balance (Berg Balance Scale)
* Changes in gait (10 Meters Walking Test)

Population: Patients with MCI (65-100 years old) and individuals without cognitive impairment (65-100 years old).

The SPARCOL Study is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of Combined Endoscopic Laparoscopic Surgery (CELS) versus standard resection for early-stage colon cancer in elderly frail patients. The study aims to evaluate the primary outcome of patient-reported postoperative recovery using the Quality of Recovery 15 (QoR-15) scale, as well as secondary outcomes including exercise capacity, physical condition, quality of life, and long-term oncological outcomes.

The study includes 75-year-old and older patients with macroscopically or pathological colonic adenocarcinoma, clinical TNM classification T1/T2 N0 M0, and PS score ≥1 and/or ASA score ≥3. Exclusion criteria include inability to give informed consent, high-risk histological features, suspected other malignancy, preoperative chemo/radiotherapy, creation of stoma, and non-Danish speakers.

The study consists of two arms: Experimental (CELS) and Active Comparator (Standard Surgery). The CELS procedure is a minimally invasive, organ-sparing procedure that enables large local excisions of the colon without segmental resection. The Standard Surgery arm will undergo traditional oncological colon resection according to complete mesocolic excision (CME) principles.

The study will assess multiple secondary outcomes, including exercise capacity, physical condition, quality of life, and long-term oncological outcomes. The study will also evaluate the rate of complete resection margin, intraoperative complications, conversion rate, blood loss, and duration of surgery.

The study aims to recruit 120 patients and will follow them for 3 years postoperatively. The primary outcome will be assessed at multiple time points, including preoperatively, intraoperatively, and postoperatively. The study will also evaluate the rate of secondary standard resection and hospital readmissions within 90 days postoperatively.

* Lead Time assessment by liquid biopsy

**Title:** Catholic Health Initiatives (CHI) St. Joseph's Children Home Visiting Longitudinal Study

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a home visiting program on child development, parenting practices, and family well-being among low-income families.

**Population:** First-born children of low-income families living in a specific three-county area, aged 1-3 months at enrollment.

**Intervention:** A three-year home visiting program using paraprofessionals to deliver a hybrid curriculum, including home visits, to promote child development and parenting skills.

**Outcomes:** The study will assess child development and school readiness, maternal health, child health, child maltreatment, positive parenting practices, family economic self-sufficiency, and reductions in juvenile delinquency, family violence, and crime.

**Methods:** A randomized controlled trial design will be used, with participants randomly assigned to either the home visiting group or a control group receiving business-as-usual care. Data will be collected at multiple time points, including birth, 6 months, 12 months, 18 months, 24 months, 36 months, and 5 years.

**Key measures:** The study will use a range of standardized assessment tools, including the Child Behavior Checklist, Ages and Stages Questionnaires, and the Adult Adolescent Parenting Inventory, among others.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Title:** A Study to Compare Two Dosing Regimens for a New Malaria Vaccine

**Objective:** To assess the safety and immunogenicity of the malaria vaccine candidate RH5.1 soluble protein in Matrix-M using two dosing regimens in healthy adult volunteers.

**Design:** This is a Phase I, open-label, non-randomized clinical trial with two arms: Group 1 (delayed regimen) and Group 2 (delayed fractional regimen).

**Participants:** Healthy adult volunteers aged 18-50 years, with no history of malaria or participation in previous malaria vaccine trials.

**Interventions:** Participants will receive either three doses of 10 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg of Matrix-M (Group 1) or two doses of 50 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg of Matrix-M and one dose of 10 µg RH5.1 with 50 µg of Matrix-M (Group 2).

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The study will assess the safety of the vaccine by monitoring solicited and unsolicited adverse events, laboratory measures, and serious adverse events.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess the humoral immunogenicity of the vaccine by measuring serum ELISA response, quantitative antigen-specific IgG antibody levels, and purified IgG versus GIA titration. Additionally, the study will compare innate immune responses following the first and third vaccinations and correlate these with adverse event data and adaptive immune responses.

**Keywords:** RH5.1, Matrix-M, malaria vaccine.

The Medical Decision Making in Multiple System Atrophy (MeDeMSA Care) study is a randomized, open-label trial that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary, personalized symptomatic treatment plan with integrated mobile palliative care and telemedicine in improving the quality of life (QoL) of individuals with Multiple System Atrophy (MSA). The study will recruit 46 individuals with MSA and will be conducted over a period of 18 months. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a control group receiving standard care or an intervention group receiving standard care plus telemedicine and mobile palliative care. The primary outcome measure is the change in EQ-5D-5L score, which assesses the improvement in patient QoL. Secondary outcome measures include changes in MSA-QoL score, motor and non-motor scales, time to clinical milestones, and individual healthcare preferences. The study will also assess the satisfaction of patients and healthcare professionals with the treatment plan and the number of medical complications.

Title: A Study of the Genetic Basis of Response to Growth Hormone Treatment in Children With Idiopathic Short Stature

Objective: To investigate the genetic determinants of response to growth hormone (GH) treatment in children with idiopathic short stature (ISS).

Eligibility Criteria: Children with ISS who have received at least 1 year of GH therapy, are prepubertal, and have no prior exposure to growth-promoting therapy. Exclusion criteria include previous participation in the study, mental incapacity, and certain medical conditions.

Study Design: The study is a single-arm, observational trial with two participant groups: good responders (change in height Standard Deviation Score (SDS) > 1.0) and poor responders (change in height SDS < 0.4). Participants will have one study visit for taking a non-invasive biological sample.

Primary Outcome Measure: The frequency of genetic variants that significantly differ between the two responder groups, measured as an odds ratio.

Secondary Outcome Measure: The enrichment of genetic variants per gene/pathway, measured as a count.

This study aims to identify genetic factors that influence the response to GH treatment in children with ISS.

This clinical trial, titled "Impact of Neurochecks on Sleep in Critically Ill Adults", aims to investigate the effect of neurochecks on sleep quality in adult patients who have undergone elective coiling of unruptured cerebral aneurysms. The study includes 18-75 year old patients who are awake and able to communicate in English, and excludes those with past or current intracranial injury or disease, known sleep disorders, or ongoing sedation.

The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial with two arms: hourly neurochecks and every-other-hour neurochecks. Participants will undergo neurological exams at their assigned frequency and sleep quality will be measured using various parameters, including sleep efficiency, wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and subjective sleep quality.

The primary outcome measure is sleep efficiency, which will be assessed within 24 hours of enrollment. Secondary outcome measures include wakefulness, REM sleep, deep sleep, arousals, and subjective sleep quality, also assessed within 24 hours of enrollment. The study aims to determine the impact of neurocheck frequency on sleep quality in critically ill adults.

Title: Ascertaining the Radiologic Prognostic Importance of Extranodal Extension on Imaging (iENE) in Head and Neck Cancer

Objective: To evaluate the accuracy of identifying extranodal extension (ENE) on imaging and its prognostic significance in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC) patients.

Eligibility: Patients with HNSCC, including oral cavity, oropharyngeal, carcinoma of unknown primary, laryngeal, or hypopharyngeal squamous cell carcinoma, who have undergone curative intent treatment and have radiological and pathological evidence of ENE.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Accuracy of radiologic identification of ENE compared to pathological diagnosis
* Prognostic significance of ENE on overall survival rates
* Prognostic significance of ENE on recurrence rates
* Prognostic significance of ENE in risk-stratifying HNSCC patients based on HPV status and N stage

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Diagnostic accuracy of various radiographic features of ENE
* Utility of existing standardized diagnostic classification systems in diagnosing ENE
* Interobserver variability in grading radiographic ENE and impact of standardized criteria on this variability

Study Period: The study will run from 1999 to 2023, with data collection and analysis planned to be completed by the end of 2023.

**Title:** Bedside Bone Biopsy Versus Conventional Bone Biopsy for Management of Diabetic Foot Osteomyelitis: an Open-label Controlled Randomized Non-inferiority Trial

**Objective:** To compare the efficiency and safety of bedside blind bone biopsy (BB) with conventional bone biopsy (CB) in patients with diabetic foot osteomyelitis (DFO).

**Design:** Randomized, open-label, non-inferiority trial with 2 arms: bedside blind bone biopsy and conventional bone biopsy.

**Eligibility:** Patients with diabetes, diabetic foot ulcer (DFU), and suspicion of DFO, aged 18 years or older.

**Intervention:** Bedside blind bone biopsy procedure performed by a physician at the bedside, or conventional bone biopsy procedure performed according to local standard of care.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Remission of DFO at 12 months, defined as a composite criterion including epithelialized ulcer, absence of local inflammation, and no need for surgery.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Clinical efficacy, microbiological results, adverse events, costs, and quality-adjusted life years (QALYs).

**Hypothesis:** Bedside blind bone biopsy is non-inferior to conventional bone biopsy in DFO outcomes and can be used as a simpler alternative procedure.

Title: African Americans (AA) Communities Speak: Partnering With AA in the North and South to Train Palliative Care Clinicians to Address Interpersonal and Systemic Racism and Provide Culturally Aligned Care.

Objective: To develop and test a community-based training program for clinicians caring for older African American adults with serious illnesses, focusing on addressing systemic racism, implicit bias, and providing culturally aligned care.

Methodology: A cluster randomized trial will be conducted in two geographically diverse regions (Birmingham, Alabama, and the Bronx, New York) with 4 start dates for the training program. Clinician clusters will be randomized to receive the training program, which includes community-developed storytelling videos, guidelines for culturally concordant end-of-life care delivery, and implicit bias recognition and management training.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Patient/family perception of therapeutic alliance using the Human Connection Scale
* Goal-concordant care (patient/family reported)

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Family-reported goal-concordant care
* Clinicians' knowledge of cultural values, awareness of implicit bias, and confidence to change practice

Eligibility Criteria:

* Patients: self-identified as African American, age ≥ 60 years, English-speaking, diagnosed with a serious illness, and able to complete baseline surveys.
* Bereaved family members: self-identified as African American, age ≥ 60 years, English-speaking, and able to complete baseline surveys.
* Clinicians: practice at a University of Alabama at Birmingham or Montefiore/Einstein site, at least 3 months of clinical practice at the site prior to the intervention training, and able to complete baseline surveys.

This study aims to address the disparities in end-of-life care for African American patients by developing a culturally sensitive training program for clinicians and evaluating its effectiveness in improving patient/family perception of therapeutic alliance and goal-concordant care.

This study aims to investigate the differences in genomic alterations and expression profiles between HPV-positive and HPV-negative head and neck cancers. The study will analyze biopsy samples from patients with oropharyngeal or oral cavity squamous cell carcinomas to identify molecular markers that can predict treatment outcomes and guide more effective and less invasive treatment options. The study will compare the molecular profiles of HPV-positive and HPV-negative tumors using a panel of 87 hotspot genes, full-length analysis of 48 genes, copy number analysis of 43 genes, and gene fusion analysis of 51 genes. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older with histologically proven oropharyngeal or oral cavity squamous cell carcinomas and exclude those with other types of head and neck cancers.

The Validation of Visual Analog Scales to Measure SatisfactiOn and WELL-being at Work (SoWell-VAS) study aims to validate the use of visual analog scales (VAS) to measure various aspects of employee well-being and job satisfaction. The study includes a total of 22 outcome measures, which are divided into primary and secondary outcomes.

Primary outcomes include:

* Burnout: measured using the Maslach Burnout Inventory (MBI) and a visual analog scale (VAS)
* Anxiety: measured using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression (HAD) questionnaire and a VAS
* Job demand, job control, and social support: measured using the Job Demand-Control-Support (JDSC) questionnaire
* Effort-reward imbalance: measured using the Effort-Reward Imbalance Questionnaire (ERI)
* Work addiction: measured using the Work Addiction Risk Test (WART) questionnaire
* Life satisfaction: measured using the Minnesota Satisfaction Questionnaire (MSQ)

Secondary outcomes include sociodemographic and occupational data, as well as self-reported measures of physical and mental health, stress, and well-being.

The study will enroll a total of 200 adult participants with a professional activity, aged 18-80 years, who will be asked to complete a series of questionnaires and surveys at inclusion and one week later. The study aims to validate the use of VAS to measure employee well-being and job satisfaction, and to identify potential correlations between these measures and other outcomes.

Title: Soft Tissue Contour and Radiographic Evaluation of Ridge Preservation Using Different Techniques

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of different techniques for ridge preservation after tooth extraction, including spontaneous healing, bone particle with subepithelial connective tissue graft, vascularized interpositional periosteal connective tissue graft, collagen membrane, and Cytoplast.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group, double-blinded trial with four experimental arms and one control arm.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients aged 20 years or older with healthy soft tissue, at least 2mm of keratinized gingiva, and no need for simultaneous bone augmentation surgery during implant placement.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with poor oral hygiene, uncontrolled periodontal disease, heavy smoking, uncontrolled diabetes, or alcohol abuse.

Primary Outcome Measures: Soft tissue and hard tissue alterations measured using cone-beam computed tomography data and STereoLithography files up to 12 months after treatment.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Keratinized tissue width changes measured using a periodontal probe up to 12 months after treatment and visual analogue scale questionnaire 14 days after treatment.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of different ridge preservation techniques in maintaining soft tissue contour and radiographic evaluation.

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled clinical trial aimed at investigating the effect of preoperative prone position training (PPT) on postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs) in patients undergoing laparoscopic colorectal surgery. The study aims to assess whether PPT can reduce the incidence of PPCs in patients with colorectal cancer. The trial will enroll patients aged 18 years or older with a clinical diagnosis of colorectal cancer and randomize them into two groups: the PPT group, which will receive PPT training for at least 3 days before surgery, and the control group, which will receive standard perioperative care without PPT training. Title: Evaluate the Safety and Efficacy of BLEX 404 Oral Liquid Combined With Pemetrexed + Cisplatin Therapy

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 oral liquid combined with pemetrexed and cisplatin therapy in patients with advanced inoperable or metastatic EGFR wild-type non-small cell lung cancer.

Design: Phase I/II, open-label, sequential assignment study with a 3+3 design to determine the dose-limiting toxicity (DLT) and recommended dose level (RDL) in the first cycle of combination use. Phase II will determine the efficacy of the RDL in 20 stage-IV or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer patients.

Eligibility: Patients aged 20-70 years with histologically or pathologically diagnosed advanced inoperable or metastatic non-small cell lung cancer, EGFR wild-type, ECOG performance status 0-2, and adequate hematologic, hepatic, and renal function.

Interventions: BLEX 404 oral liquid administered twice daily, combined with pemetrexed and cisplatin therapy.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* DLT determination in the first cycle of combination use
* RDL determination in the first cycle of combination use
* Overall response rate (PR + CR) after 4 cycles of combination use

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Overall response rate (PR + CR) after at least 1 cycle of combination use
* Rate of grade 3/4 hematological toxicity
* Effect on quality of life by EORTC QLQ-C30

The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of BLEX 404 oral liquid combined with pemetrexed and cisplatin therapy in patients with advanced non-small cell lung cancer.

Title: AGE SELF CARE: Promoting Healthy Aging Through a Group Visit Program

Objective: To evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a virtual group visit program, AGE SELF CARE, in promoting healthy aging and preventing frailty among community-dwelling adults aged 65 and older who are pre-frail.

Design: Pilot study with a single-group assignment, open-label design.

Intervention: AGE SELF CARE is an 8-week virtual group visit program, consisting of 90-minute sessions, focusing on chronic disease management, healthy lifestyle education, home adaptation, and anticipatory guidance.

Participants: 12 community-dwelling adults aged 65 and older who are pre-frail (based on FRAIL scale) during the initial study visit.

Outcome Measures: Primary outcomes include recruitment rate, completion of testing, attendance, completion of home practice log, participant satisfaction, and proportion lost to follow-up. Secondary outcomes include frailty index, loneliness, self-reported health, physical activity, self-efficacy, depression, anxiety, sleep, and physical performance.

Keywords: yoga, mind-body, pre-frail, healthy aging.

Title: Pan-European Study on Geriatric Rehabilitation After COVID-19 Disease

Objective: To investigate the course of functional and medical recovery in post-COVID-19 geriatric rehabilitation patients in several European countries, and to explore the treatment modalities and organization of geriatric rehabilitation in these patients.

Design: Observational, multi-center cohort study with a sample size of at least 250 participants.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients recovering from COVID-19 infection, admitted to geriatric rehabilitation departments in European countries.

Exclusion Criteria: Presence of severe cognitive impairment or refusal to participate in the study.

Interventions: Standard rehabilitation treatment as usual, including physical therapy, occupational therapy, and medical treatment.

Outcome Measures:

* Primary outcome: Change in Activities of Daily Living (ADL) functioning, assessed using the Barthel Index.
* Secondary outcome: Change in Quality of Life, assessed using the EQ-5D-5L.

Data Collection: Anonymous data will be collected from clinical records at admission, discharge, and 6 weeks and 6 months follow-up. Additional data will be collected on patient characteristics, treatment modalities, and organization of geriatric rehabilitation.

Statistical Analysis: Descriptive statistics will be used to describe the characteristics of the participants. Paired sample t-tests and multilevel models will be used to analyze the primary and secondary outcomes.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the PREPARE-iVAC Trial:

The PREPARE-iVAC Trial is a multicentre, open-label, controlled, randomized study to evaluate the replacement of Mycophenolate Mofetil/Mycophenolic Acid (MMF/MPA) with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients (KTRs) on immunogenicity and safety after vaccination. The primary objective is to investigate whether replacing MMF/MPA with everolimus results in superior immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination, as measured by neutralizing antibody titer against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain.

The study aims to evaluate the immunogenicity of COVID-19 vaccination, including humoral and cellular responses, as well as the safety of replacing MMF/MPA with everolimus in KTRs. The study will also assess the immunogenicity of herpes zoster vaccination and the safety of kidney transplant recipients.

The study includes 1:1 randomization of KTRs to either continue immunosuppressive therapy with MMF/MPA or replace it with everolimus. Participants will receive COVID-19 vaccination and, optionally, herpes zoster vaccination. The study will assess various outcomes, including virus-neutralizing capacity of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies, SARS-CoV-2 antibody concentration, SARS-CoV-2 specific T-cell response, varicella zoster specific antibodies, varicella zoster specific T-cell response, and solicited local and systemic adverse events.

This randomized controlled trial aims to investigate the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes in patients with partial thickness burns (30-50% burned body surface area). Sixty patients aged 20-45 years will be randomly assigned to either a study group (n=30) or a control group (n=30). The study group will receive resistance exercises (3 times a week for 8 weeks) using dumbbells and sandbags, in addition to their physical therapy program and medical treatment. The control group will receive only their physical therapy program and medical treatment. The primary outcome measure is the level of plasma liver enzymes (AST and ALT) at two months post-burn. The study aims to determine whether resistance exercises can reduce plasma liver enzymes levels in patients with burns.

Title: Effectiveness of Tecarterapy on the Performance of Amateur Athletes

Objective: To investigate the effectiveness of Tecarterapy on the performance of amateur athletes, specifically in terms of sprinting and jumping ability.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with two arms: Tecarterapy group and Sham group.

Population: Amateur athletes aged 18-30 years, competing in university or national amateur leagues, and performing sprinting and jumping in their sports practice.

Intervention: Tecarterapy, a non-invasive electrothermal therapy, will be applied to both legs for 25 minutes using the T-Plus Wintecare machine. The Sham group will receive a sham treatment with the machine without power.

Outcome measures: Primary outcomes include changes in 30-meter sprint time and electromyographic activity during sprint. Secondary outcomes include countermovement jump, changes in electromyographic activity during countermovement jump, isometric leg extension, and changes in electromyographic activity during isometric leg extension.

The study aims to assess whether Tecarterapy improves functional sporting abilities in amateur athletes, specifically in terms of sprinting and jumping performance.

Title: Maxillary Implant Overdentures Retained by Bars or Locator Attachments: a 10-year Comparative Prospective Study

Objective: To compare the treatment outcomes of fully edentulous patients with maxillary implant overdentures retained by either bars or Locators over a 10-year period.

Design: Observational study with a parallel assignment design, where patients were treated 10 years ago with dental implants and an overdenture in the maxilla due to problems with retention and stability with their conventional denture.

The study aims to provide evidence on the long-term outcomes of different attachment systems for maxillary implant overdentures, which is currently lacking in the literature.

Title: Efficacy of Designed Exercise Program on Pain and Quality of Sleeping in Patients with Sickle Cell Disease Anemia

Objective: To investigate the effectiveness of a designed exercise program in reducing pain and improving sleep quality in patients with sickle cell disease anemia.

Methodology: This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 50 adult patients with sickle cell disease anemia, aged 18-55 years, who will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group (n=25) or a control group (n=25). The experimental group will receive a designed exercise program, including diaphragmatic breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, and a combination of stretching, stabilization, and strengthening exercises of the pelvic-lumbar region, as well as walking exercises. Outcome measures: The primary outcome measures include the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, and World Health Organization Quality of Life-BREF (WHOQOL-BREF). Secondary outcome measures include the Fatigue Scale, Perceived Stress Scale, and Quality of Life.

Duration: The study will last for 6 weeks, with pre- and post-intervention measurements.

Significance: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a designed exercise program in improving sleep quality and reducing pain in patients with sickle cell disease anemia, which can have a significant impact on their quality of life.

Title: Cognitive Stimulation Therapy for Dementia: A Two-Armed Pragmatic Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of cognitive stimulation therapy (CST) in patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia compared to standard of care.

Design: A randomized, open-label, two-armed pragmatic trial with a parallel assignment design.

Population: Patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia, aged 18 years or older, who are English-speaking and have a scheduled visit 6-12 months after record review.

Interventions:

* Active Comparator: Referral for Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) - participants receive a referral from their physician for CST treatment.
* Placebo Comparator: Standard of Care - participants receive standard of care and no CST referral.

Primary Outcome Measure: Clinically meaningful cognitive decline measured by an increase in Montreal Cognitive Assessment Score from baseline to follow-up.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Clinically meaningful cognitive improvement measured by a decrease in Montreal Cognitive Assessment Score from baseline to follow-up.
* Referral Acceptance Rate - percentage of people referred for V-CST who accept the referral over the 1-month referral period process.
* Participant Attendance - percentage of enrolled participants who attend each V-CST session over a 7-week period.
* Participant Attrition - percentage of enrolled participants who cease attending V-CST between session 1 and session 14 over a 7-week period.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of CST in improving cognitive function, referral acceptance, and participant engagement in patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: Important Correlation Between Anxiety and Reflux Symptoms in Patients With Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease

Objective: To assess the correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and to examine the modulation of anxiety on the severity of reflux symptoms.

Methods: This prospective observational cohort study enrolled patients with GERD symptoms who underwent gastrointestinal function diagnostics, including esophagogastroduodenoscopy, 24-hour pH-metry, high-resolution manometry, and esophagography. Patients completed the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) questionnaire to assess anxiety and depression levels.

Key Findings:

* Anxiety and depression are common comorbidities in patients with GERD.
* Patients with GERD have a higher incidence of anxiety, depression, and sleep disturbances than those without GERD.
* There is a significant correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms, with anxious patients experiencing more severe reflux symptoms.
* The study found that anxiety and depression levels were higher in patients with GERD, particularly those with pathological DeMeester scores.

Conclusion: This study highlights the important correlation between anxiety and reflux symptoms in patients with GERD, emphasizing the need for a comprehensive approach to managing GERD symptoms that includes addressing comorbid anxiety and depression.

Title: Evaluation of the CAD-EYE System for the Detection of Colorectal Neoplastic Lesions in Patients With Lynch Syndrome

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system in screening for neoplastic lesions in patients with Lynch syndrome, compared to indigo carmin chromoendoscopy (CE) as the reference technique.

This is a prospective observational study conducted at nine children's hospitals to evaluate the use of a water-soluble contrast-based protocol to assist in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO). The study aimed to detect a 15% difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups. A total of 314 patients were planned to be enrolled, but the actual number is not specified.

The study included children aged 1-20 years diagnosed with ASBO by an attending pediatric surgeon and underwent a trial of nonoperative management (NOM) on hospital admission. Patients were excluded if they had peritonitis, suspicion of incarcerated or internal hernia, active intra-abdominal malignancy, inflammatory bowel disease, or known contrast allergy.

The contrast protocol involved the administration of 30-200ml of enteral contrast followed by X-rays at 8-12 hours and 24 hours after contrast administration. The decision to operate was at the discretion of the attending surgeon. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients who required an operation, and secondary outcomes included total hospital length of stay and adverse events resulting from contrast administration.

The study found that five sites used contrast routinely and four used it selectively at the end of the study. The contrast agent and volume used varied across sites, but the protocol was standardized otherwise. The study did not find a significant difference in operative rate between the contrast and no contrast groups. However, the study suggests that the use of enteral contrast may be associated with a shorter hospital length of stay and fewer complications in patients with ASBO.

Title: Pharmacokinetic Study to Compare Itepekimab Exposure When Administered With an Autoinjector Versus Prefilled Syringe

Objective: To compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous itepekimab administered with an autoinjector versus prefilled syringe in healthy participants with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

Design: Single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel group, single-dose study.

Interventions:

* Itepekimab administered via autoinjector (AI)
* Itepekimab administered via prefilled syringe (PFS)

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) of itepekimab
* Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve (AUClast) of itepekimab
* Area under the plasma concentration versus time curve extrapolated to infinity (AUC) of itepekimab

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Time to reach Cmax (tmax) of itepekimab
* Area under the serum concentration versus time curve from 0 to 28 days (AUC0-28days) of itepekimab
* Terminal half-life (t1/2) of itepekimab
* Apparent total body clearance (CL/F) of itepekimab
* Apparent Volume of Distribution at the steady state (Vss/F) of itepekimab
* Incidence of treatment-emergent anti-itepekimab antibodies responses
* Number of participants with adverse events, serious adverse events, and adverse events of special interest

Eligibility Criteria:

* Healthy participants aged 18-65 years
* No language problems or poor mental development
* Written informed consent prior to study procedures

The CSD201204 study is an actual use study of the P12 electronic nicotine delivery system (ENDS) among U.S. adult smokers. The study is an open-label, randomized, three-arm, 8-week prospective observational study conducted at multiple sites in the U.S. Adult tobacco consumers aged 21-60 years who smoke at least 20 days out of the past 30 days and 5 cigarettes per day on days they smoke are eligible to participate. Participants will be provided with the Study IP for ad libitum use over a 6-week period and will self-report product use on a daily basis via an eDiary. The primary outcome measures are the number and proportion of subjects who reduce their cigarettes per day by at least 50% at Week 6 compared to baseline and the mean percent reduction in cigarettes per day at Week 6 compared to baseline.

**Title:** A Multicenter Randomized, Open-label Study to Compare the Efficacy of Subcutaneous Infliximab Monotherapy With Subcutaneous Infliximab and Concomitant Immunosuppression in the Treatment of Moderate to Severe Crohn's Disease

**Objective:** To investigate the efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab (IFX) monotherapy versus combination therapy with immunosuppressants in inducing corticosteroid-free clinical remission and endoscopic response in patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease.

**Design:** Prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, non-inferiority study.

**Population:** 158 patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease, aged 18-80 years, starting IFX treatment.

**Interventions:** Two groups: Group 1 (monotherapy) receives subcutaneous IFX 240mg at weeks 0 and 2, then 120mg every other week (EOW); Group 2 (combination therapy) receives subcutaneous IFX 240mg at weeks 0 and 2, then 120mg EOW, and immunosuppressive agents.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Proportion of patients in corticosteroid-free clinical remission (CDAI <150) and endoscopic response (Simple Endoscopic Score for Crohn's disease drop of at least 50%) at week 26.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Endoscopic remission, clinical remission, symptomatic remission, biochemical remission, histological healing, quality of life, and adverse events.

**Duration:** 26 weeks.

**Title:** Evaluating Bronchodilator Response in Patients With Bronchiectasis

**Objective:** To determine if bronchodilator response in patients with bronchiectasis is influenced by factors apart from the direct effect of bronchodilators, and to assess associations between bronchodilator response and various clinical factors.

**Design:** Randomized, crossover trial with two study arms: patients will receive either salbutamol or placebo, followed by a waiting period and then the alternative treatment.

**Participants:** Patients with bronchiectasis confirmed by CT scan, aged 5 years or older, with no recent pulmonary exacerbation or use of long-acting beta agonists or short-acting beta agonists within a certain time frame.

**Interventions:** Salbutamol inhalation and placebo inhalation.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcome measures include bronchodilator response compared to placebo (change in FEV1 and FVC) and secondary outcome measures include associations between bronchodilator response and various clinical factors such as age, sex, specific bronchiectatic disease, baseline FEV1, and use of inhaled steroids.

**Duration:** Single clinic visit with three spirometry tests: baseline, 15 minutes after first intervention, and 15 minutes after second intervention.

**Keywords:** Bronchodilator response, bronchiectasis.

**Title:** Sex, Hormones and Identity Affect Nociceptive Expression

**Objective:** To investigate the impact of gender identity, genetic sex, and hormone status on pain sensitivity, and to examine social and psychological factors that contribute to pain sensitivity in individuals with different gender identities.

**Methodology:** The study will recruit 6 groups of participants: Cis Man, Cis Woman, Transgender Man, Transgender Woman, Transgender Man plus Testosterone, and Transgender Woman plus Estrogen. Each participant will undergo a single visit, which will include blood draws, questionnaires, body measurements, and pain testing using heat, pressure, and cold stimuli.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Experimental Heat Pain Thresholds, Experimental Pressure Pain Thresholds, Experimental Pain Sensitivity, Temporal Summation, Conditioned Pain Modulation, Sleep quality, Depression, Social Support, and Hormone levels.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Community connectedness, Bodily pain, Quality of life metrics, Body image, Gender role expectation of pain, and Adverse childhood events.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Participants with chronic pain, HIV positive diagnosis, cardiovascular or pulmonary disease, regular use of opioid pain medications, uncontrolled hypertension, current illness accompanied by fever, prostatectomy, hysterectomy or oophorectomy, and hospitalization due to psychiatric illness within the last 6 months.

**Study Duration:** The study will consist of a single visit, which will take approximately 1 hour to complete.

Title: Technology Enriched Stroke Rehabilitation in Acute/Sub-acute Stroke

Objective: To evaluate the feasibility of technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation in acute and sub-acute stroke patients.

Background: Stroke is the most common cause of severe physical disability in Scottish adults, and current rehabilitation services are often limited by staffing shortages. Technology-based rehabilitation has the potential to increase intensity and dosage of therapy, but has not been widely adopted.

Methodology: This mixed-methods feasibility study will enroll patients with a diagnosis of stroke who are medically fit for rehabilitation and have been identified as requiring rehabilitation. Patients will be prescribed and supported to use commercially available technology, such as robotics, virtual reality, and mobile digital devices, in addition to usual care. The primary outcome measures will include duration of time spent on activities within the "technology-enriched rehabilitation space," movement repetitions, rates of recruitment and attrition, and adherence to sessions. Secondary outcome measures will include intervention acceptability, assessed through audio-recorded semi-structured interviews.

Eligibility criteria: Patients must have a diagnosis of stroke, be medically fit for rehabilitation, and be able to provide informed consent. Exclusion criteria include acute medical instability, active cardiac disease, and inability to follow verbal or written instructions.

The study aims to assess the feasibility of technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation in acute and sub-acute stroke patients, and to inform the development of a larger, more comprehensive study.
