Title: Alleviating Persistent Dyspnea in Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis Patients Treated With Non-Invasive Ventilation Through Immersive Virtual Reality

Objective: To evaluate the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) on respiratory discomfort in patients with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) at the stage of respiratory failure treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV).

Methodology: This is an open-label, monocentric, randomized, controlled cross-over clinical study. Patients with ALS will be recruited during their respiratory evaluation and will undergo a digital therapy session based on IVR and music therapy, 60 minutes apart. The IVR session will be based on medical hypnosis, and the music therapy session will be based on the patient's choice of music. Each session will last 15 minutes.

Primary Outcome Measure: Evaluate the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort (scale A1 of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile questionnaire) at 15 minutes.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Evaluate the effect of IVR on sensory and emotional components of dyspnea, as well as the effect of music therapy on respiratory discomfort. Compare the evolutionary profile of respiratory discomfort under the effect of IVR and music therapy, and evaluate the acceptability of IVR.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with ALS diagnosed according to the revised criteria of El Escorial, treated with NIV for more than a month, with persistent dyspnea at rest ≥ 3, and stable clinical condition.

Ages Eligible for Study: Minimum age of 18 years.

This study aims to investigate the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort in patients with ALS treated with NIV, and to compare it with music therapy.

Title: Selective Reporting for Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing and GPs' Prescribing of Broad-spectrum Antibiotics in Women With E. Coli UTIs

Objective: To investigate the impact of selective reporting for antibiotic susceptibility testing on general practitioners' (GPs) prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics in women with E. coli urinary tract infections (UTIs).

Design: Randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment, double-blinded, and two arms: experimental (intervention) and active comparator (control).

Participants: Women ≥18 years old with E. coli UTIs, affiliated with general practitioners in Loire Atlantique and Maine et Loire, France.

Interventions: In the experimental arm, GPs received a selective reporting for antibiotic susceptibility testing report, emphasizing narrower-spectrum antibiotics, while in the control arm, GPs received a standard antibiotic susceptibility testing report.

Primary Outcome Measure: The rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing within 5 days after report of the antibiotic susceptibility testing.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Rates of directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, antibiotic de-escalation, and other measures of antibiotic use and patient characteristics.

Keywords: Antibiotic therapy, General practice, Primary care, Public health.

The study aims to determine whether sodium valproate can reduce infarct volume, improve neurological function, and increase peripheral anti-inflammatory CD177+ neutrophils levels. A total of 90 patients with acute ischemic stroke will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: low-dose sodium valproate, high-dose sodium valproate, or placebo. This randomized, open-label trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a virtual coach in promoting weight reduction in patients with obesity and ventral hernia. The study will enroll patients aged 18-90 with a BMI ≥ 30 and a diagnosed ventral hernia. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an experimental arm, where they will use a MyChart-enabled virtual coach to aid in preoperative weight loss, or an active comparator arm, where they will use standard preoperative weight loss tools.

The primary outcome measure is the average net amount of weight change over 6 months. Secondary outcomes include the number of interactions with the virtual coach, quality of life measured using the Hernia Related Quality of Life Survey (HerQLes), and satisfaction with the virtual coach. The study aims to determine whether the virtual coach offers a better solution for weight reduction in patients with obesity and ventral hernia.

Title: A Phase 3, Open-Label, Randomized Study to Compare the Efficacy and Safety of Odronextamab (REGN1979) in Combination with Lenalidomide Versus Rituximab in Combination with Lenalidomide Therapy in Relapsed/Refractory Participants with Follicular Lymphoma and Marginal Zone Lymphoma.

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of odronextamab combined with lenalidomide compared to rituximab combined with lenalidomide in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma.

Secondary endpoints: Odronextamab concentrations in serum, incidence of anti-odronextamab antibodies, best overall response (BOR), duration of response (DOR), overall survival (OS), event-free survival (EFS), and patient-reported outcomes (PROs) using various questionnaires.

Objective: To evaluate the effect of Proliverenol supplementation on liver function in patients with Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD) over a 12-week period.

**Study Name:** TINO: T Cells in the Nose of Older Adults

**Objective:** To identify the underlying mechanisms and consequences of the loss of nasal T cells in vital and frail older individuals, and to compare the nasal immune cell populations between young adults, vital elderly, and frail elderly individuals.

**Study Design:** A observational study with three participant groups: young adults (18-30 years old), vital elderly (>65 years old), and frail elderly (>65 years old). Participants will provide nasal and blood samples at baseline and 3 months later. The study will also investigate the frequency and functionality of nasal and blood T cell populations, as well as the transcriptomic cluster composition and clonality of nasal and blood T cells.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Frequency of nasal CD8+ T cells in young adults and frail older adults.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Phenotype, functionality, and transcriptomic cluster composition of nasal and blood T cell populations, as well as the stability of nasal T cells and immune populations over time. The study will also investigate the comparison of nasal and blood immune cell populations between the three participant groups, as well as the effect of sex on aging effects of nasal and blood immune populations.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Adults aged 18-30 years old, healthy elderly (>65 years old), frail elderly (>65 years old), and individuals with a self-reported respiratory tract infection in the previous year.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Individuals with a history of severe nose bleedings, asthma, COPD, or chronic rhinosinusitis, or those using inhalation corticosteroids or antibiotics in the past 6 weeks.

Title: A Phase IB Study to Determine the Safety and Tolerability of Canakinumab and Tislelizumab in Combination With Nab-Paclitaxel and Gemcitabine in the Neo-adjuvant Treatment of Patients With Pancreatic Cancer

Objective: To evaluate the safety and tolerability of a quadruplet regimen (Canakinumab, Tislelizumab, Nab-Paclitaxel, and Gemcitabine) in patients with resectable or borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) in the neo-adjuvant setting.

Interventions: Patients will receive Canakinumab (250 mg subcutaneous injection) and Tislelizumab (300 mg intravenous infusion) on day 1 of every 28-day cycle, along with Nab-Paclitaxel (125 mg/m2 intravenous infusion) and Gemcitabine (1000 mg/m2 intravenous infusion) on days 1, 8, and 15 of every 28-day cycle, for up to 4 cycles (4 months).

**Objective:** To investigate the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed tea in patients with hyperlipidemia (plasma triglyceride level between 1.7 - 4.5mmol/l) without diabetes over an 8-week intervention period.

**Title:** Pharmacodynamics and Pharmacokinetics of 3 New Developed Coated Glucose Beads in 20 Obese Healthy Subjects

**Objective:** To assess the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of three new coated glucose beads formulations containing glucose and caffeine in obese healthy subjects.

**Design:** Single-dose, randomized, open-label, five-treatment, five-period, five-sequence crossover study.

**Participants:** 20 obese healthy subjects (18-55 years old, BMI > 30 kg/m2) who have given informed consent.

**Interventions:** Five treatments, each with a different coated glucose beads formulation: three containing glucose and caffeine, one containing only glucose, and one uncoated beads formulation containing glucose and caffeine.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of Glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) and caffeine.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Pharmacokinetics of glucose, caffeine, and caffeine-related parameters, as well as visual analogue scale (VAS) scores for appetite and stomach rumbles, and tolerability and safety assessments.

**Duration:** Each treatment period is 13 hours, with a wash-out period of at least 3 days between periods.

**Conclusion:** This study aims to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and pharmacokinetics of three new coated glucose beads formulations in obese healthy subjects.

The study, "Influencing Panoramic Imaging Errors With Strips," aimed to evaluate the effect of using celluloid matrix tapes and oral tapes as a simple and cheap method for proper positioning of the tongue on reducing the palatoglossal airway shadow error in panoramic imaging. The study included 270 patients, aged 15 years and above, who underwent panoramic radiography. The patients were randomly divided into three groups: a control group, a group using celluloid matrix tapes, and a group using edible strips (fruit leather or chewing gum). The patients in the experimental groups were instructed to place the strips on their tongues before panoramic imaging. The radiographs were assessed by an oral and maxillofacial radiologist to identify and record errors. The primary outcome measure was the effect of using different strips on reducing the palatoglossal air space shadow error. The results showed that the use of celluloid matrix tapes and edible strips significantly reduced the error rate compared to the control group. The study suggests that the use of these strips can be a simple and effective way to improve the quality of panoramic radiographs and reduce diagnostic errors.

Title: Acute Effect of Kinesio Taping and Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy on Pain Severity and Lower Extremity Functionality in Plantar Fasciitis

Objective: To compare the acute effect of Extracorporeal Shock Wave Therapy (ESWT), Kinesio Taping (KT) with ESWT, and placebo ESWT on pain level, lower extremity functionality, and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis.

Methods: 100 patients with plantar fasciitis will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: ESWT, ESWT with KT, and placebo ESWT. ESWT will be applied at 10 Hz frequency, 2.5 Barr energy, and 2000 shocks/session. KT will be applied after ESWT and will be worn for a week. Pain will be measured using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), and lower extremity functionality will be evaluated using the Lower Extremity Functional Scale. Plantar fascia flexibility will also be assessed.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients aged 18-65 years with plantar fasciitis diagnosed by a physical medicine and rehabilitation specialist, willing to participate, and meeting specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

The study aims to investigate the short-term effects of ESWT, KT, and placebo ESWT on pain and functionality in patients with plantar fasciitis.

**Title:** Effects of Individual Tailored Physical Exercise in Patients With Post COVID-19 Condition, Diagnosed With Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) - a Randomized Controlled Study

**Objective:** To evaluate the effects of an individually tailored exercise program on time spent in upright position, health-related quality of life (HRQoL), physical activity, physical and psychological function, and workability in patients with Postural Orthostatic Tachycardia Syndrome (POTS) and post COVID-19 condition.

**Methodology:** A randomized controlled trial (RCT) will be conducted, enrolling 60 adult patients with POTS and post COVID-19 condition. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group receiving individualized physical exercise or a control group receiving standard care. The intervention group will receive a 16-week program of progressive exercise, supervised by a physiotherapist, while the control group will receive standard care. Primary outcomes will include changes in time spent in upright position, HRQoL, and physical activity. Secondary outcomes will include changes in walking distance, oxygen saturation, dyspnea, leg fatigue, exertion, heart rate, and other symptoms.

**Key Inclusion Criteria:** Adults (>18 years) diagnosed with POTS and post COVID-19 condition.

**Key Exclusion Criteria:** Known pregnancy, cancer, already ongoing individual physical exercise, or inability to perform measurements and/or intervention.

**Study Timeline:** The study will be conducted over a period of 16 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 6 and 12 months.

**Study Name:** Efficacy and Safety of Tirofiban in Patients With Acute Branch Atheromatous Disease (BAD)-Related Stroke (BRANT)

**Objective:** To determine whether intravenous tirofiban is effective in increasing the proportion of excellent functional outcome (mR: 0-1) at 90 days in patients with acute BAD-related stroke, when initiated within 48 hours of onset.

**Design:** Multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded-endpoint, parallel-controlled trial.

**Population:** Patients with acute BAD-related stroke between 18 and 75 years old, who can be randomized within 48 hours of onset, and meet the BAD Diagnostic Imaging Criteria.

**Interventions:** Two groups: Experimental (tirofiban group) and Active Comparator (standard antiplatelet therapy group).

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Excellent functional outcome (mR: 0-1) at 90 days and proportion of major bleeding at 90 days.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Various outcomes, including excellent functional outcome at 7 days, early neurological deterioration, NIHSS score, Barthel index score, ischemic stroke, stroke, TIA, composite endpoint, serious adverse events, adverse events, all-cause death, and changes in laboratory parameters.

**Duration:** 90 days from randomization.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Age 18-75 years old, acute ischemic stroke, time from onset to randomization ≤48h, and meet the BAD Diagnostic Imaging Criteria.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Various conditions, including transient ischemic attack, intracranial hemorrhagic diseases, vascular malformations, aneurysms, brain abscesses, malignant space-occupying lesions, and others.

The study will enroll patients aged 60 years or older with a diagnosis of SND, who are scheduled to receive a dual-chamber pacemaker. The intervention involves setting the pacemaker's lower rate setting to either 60 bpm (control group) or 75 bpm (PLR group), which may be adjusted based on the physician's diagnosis.

Title: The Effect of Remote Diagnosis and Treatment on 24 Hour Ambulatory Blood Pressure Rhythm of OSA Patients

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of remote diagnosis and treatment using telemedicine compared to in-person treatment for patients with Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA) in improving 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure rhythm and reducing healthcare costs.

Title: Prostate Medication, Metabolism and Gut Microbiota

Objective: To investigate the relationship between gut microbiota, metabolism, and prostate cancer (PCa) risk, and to explore the effects of prostate medication on gut microbiota and metabolic characteristics in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) or PCa.

The study aims to explore the effects of prostate medication on gut microbiota and metabolic characteristics in men with BPH or PCa, and to identify potential biomarkers for PCa risk and treatment response.

The "Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy Markers of Glioma Genomics" study aims to investigate the correlation between magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) markers and glioma genomics in patients with grade II or III glioma. The study will enroll patients who have undergone surgery and have a residual tumor measuring at least 2 cm in diameter. The primary objective is to evaluate the concentrations of 2-hydroxyglutarate and cystathionine measured by MRS, which will be correlated with IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion derived from ex vivo analyses in tumor tissue samples.

The study will use a single-group assignment design, where patients will undergo a single MRI examination without contrast agent. The primary outcome measures will be the concentrations of 2-hydroxyglutarate and cystathionine measured by MRS, as well as diffusion MRI metrics. Secondary outcome measures will include metabolic changes during anti-tumor treatment, diffusion MRI and amide proton transfer signal changes during treatment, and tumor volume changes.

The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older, with a Karnofsky index greater than 60, and who have not received any treatment other than surgery. Exclusion criteria include patients with contraindications to MRI, pregnant or breastfeeding women, and patients who are not affiliated with a social security regime. The study will run for 1 year, with follow-up assessments at 1.5 hours and 1 year post-treatment.

Title: Long-Term Assessment of Thalidomide and Hydroxyurea Combination Therapy in β-Thalassemia Patients

Objective: To evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of combining hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients.

Design: Open-label, single-arm trial with a 6-month hydroxyurea monotherapy phase, followed by the addition of thalidomide. Patients were monitored for up to 3 years.

Inclusion criteria: Patients with beta-thalassemia major or intermedia, partial response or decline in response to hydroxyurea, and not candidates for bone marrow transplant.

Exclusion criteria: Patients with comorbidities, allergies, mental disorders, or a history of thrombosis.

Interventions:

* Hydroxyurea: 10-20 mg/kg/day for 6 months
* Thalidomide: 2-5 mg/kg/day added to hydroxyurea after 6 months

Primary outcome measures:

* Response rates (good responders, responders, non-responders) at 1-3 years
* Changes in laboratory levels (hemoglobin, platelets, leukocytes, urea, creatinine, ferritin) from baseline at 1-3 years
* Changes in liver and spleen size from baseline at 1-3 years

Secondary outcome measures:

* XmnI polymorphism analysis at 1-3 years

The study aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of combining hydroxyurea and thalidomide in beta-thalassemia patients, with a focus on response rates, laboratory changes, and liver and spleen size.

Title: Wharton's Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cell (WG-MSC) Injections as GVHD Prophylaxis in Hematopoietic Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplantation With an Haplo-identical Donor

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of Wharton's Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cells (WG-MSC) as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis in patients undergoing haploidentical allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Design: This is a dose-escalation study with a single group assignment, where patients receive three weekly infusions of WG-MSC at different doses.

Eligibility: Patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), or lymphoid neoplasm requiring allogeneic stem cell transplantation, with no HLA-matched related donor available, and with a haploidentical donor identified.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, toxicity-related mortality, relapse incidence, overall survival, graft-versus-host disease and relapse-free survival, and poor graft function.

The study aims to determine the safety and efficacy of WG-MSC as GVHD prophylaxis in patients undergoing haploidentical allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Title: Pilot Study for the Evaluation of Algorithms for the Detection of Subcutaneous Insulin Pump Malfunctions in Subjects With Type 1 Diabetes

Objective: To test new algorithms for detecting insulin pump malfunctions that result in reduced or interrupted insulin delivery in individuals with type 1 diabetes.

Design: A pilot study consisting of three phases: Phase 1 (Preliminary Data Collection), Phase 2 (Induction of Hyperglycemia), and Phase 3 (Retrospective Data Analysis).

The Value of a Risk Prediction Tool (PERSARC) for Effective Treatment Decisions of Soft-tissue Sarcomas Patients is a parallel cluster randomized trial aimed at assessing the cost-effectiveness of PERSARC in treatment decisions of high-grade extremity Soft-Tissue Sarcoma patients. The primary outcomes are decisional conflict and informed choice, which will be measured at one week and three, six, and 12 months after the treatment decision. The study will measure various outcomes, including decisional conflict, informed choice, regret, worry, involvement in decision-making, patient-reported outcomes, utilities for cost-effectiveness analysis, healthcare costs, and absenteeism/presenteeism from paid work. Title: Early Childhood Caries in Jordanian Children: Prevalence, Risk Factors and Prevention Using Silver Diamine Fluoride

Objective: To determine the prevalence of early childhood caries in Jordanian children, identify risk factors, and evaluate the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control material and its acceptance among parents.

Methods: A cross-sectional epidemiological study was conducted among 887 children aged 3-5 years, with 159 children participating in a randomized controlled trial. The study group received a single application of 38% SDF, while the control group did not receive any intervention. The children were followed up for 1 year to assess the prevalence of early childhood caries, caries prevention, and caries arrest.

Outcome Measures:

* Primary outcomes: Prevalence of early childhood caries, caries prevention, and caries arrest
* Secondary outcomes: Risk factors for early childhood caries and parental acceptance of SDF

Eligibility Criteria: Children with early childhood caries involving anterior and/or posterior primary teeth, with cavitated lesions, and no clinical signs of pulp involvement. Exclusion criteria include children with grossly broken down teeth, teeth with more than one-third of the crown missing, pulpally involved teeth, and obvious discoloration or abnormal mobility.

Title: A Study to Learn About ABRYSVO Vaccine in Older Adults to Prevent Severe Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) Infection

Objective: To estimate the vaccine effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine against RSV-related lower respiratory tract infection requiring hospitalization among older adults.

Design: Retrospective case-control study with test-negative design (TND) and retrospective cohort design.

Inclusion Criteria: Older adults (≥65 years) who are eligible for vaccination per current ACIP recommendations, admitted to the hospital with acute respiratory infection/lower respiratory tract infection (ARI/LRTI), and have had an RSV test.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients who receive another licensed or investigational RSV vaccine prior to hospitalization or ED visit, or patients who are censored for receiving another licensed or investigational RSV vaccine during the study period.

Primary Outcome Measure: Vaccine effectiveness (VE) calculated as 1 minus the odds ratio (OR) comparing the odds of being vaccinated with ABRYSVO for RSV-related hospitalized LRTI cases and controls, multiplied by 100%.

Secondary Outcome Measures: VE estimates stratified by age groups, virus subgroups, frailty index, and chronic medical condition risk category, as well as estimates of VE against ED admission, hospitalization, and death.

Study Period: Up to 2 years.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ABRYSVO vaccine in preventing severe RSV infection in older adults, with a focus on hospitalized LRTI cases and controls, as well as secondary outcomes such as ED admission, hospitalization, and death.

**Title:** Depth of Botulinum Neurotoxin Injection for Treatment of Glabellar Lines

**Objective:** To compare the efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin injected at depths of 2mm and 4mm for the treatment of glabellar lines, and to assess the safety and tolerability of the treatment.

**Study Design:** Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with 120 participants aged 18 and older. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive onabotulinumtoxinA injections at either 2mm or 4mm depth in the glabellar complex.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The efficacy of onabotulinumtoxinA injections at both depths will be assessed using the Merz aesthetics scales at 120 days post-treatment.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The incidence of adverse effects and the comparison of efficacy between the two injection depths will also be evaluated.

**Conclusion:** This study aims to establish the optimal depth of injection for onabotulinumtoxinA neurotoxin in the treatment of glabellar lines, with the goal of achieving maximal improvement with minimal adverse effects.

The primary outcome measure is the impact of music therapy on anxiety, assessed using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) before the first and third chemotherapy sessions. The study includes patients aged 18 and above, diagnosed with localized breast cancer, and undergoing chemotherapy. The trial aims to determine whether music therapy can reduce anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

The Optimization of Conditioning Regimen for HLA Matched HSCT in SAA is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study evaluating different conditioning regimens for HLA matched donor transplantation in patients with severe aplastic anemia (SAA). The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of two conditioning regimens: Busulfan-based regimens (Bu/Flu/Cy/ATG or Bu/Cy/ATG) versus Flu/Cy/ATG or Cy/ATG regimens.

Eligible patients are diagnosed with SAA, have an available HLA matched sibling or unrelated donor, and meet specific inclusion criteria. The primary outcome measure is failure-free survival at 1 year post-hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT). Secondary outcomes include the incidence of mixed chimerism, regimen-related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, graft-versus-host disease, CMV and EBV reactivation, transplantation-related mortality, and overall survival.

The study is designed as a randomized, open-label trial with two arms: an experimental arm receiving Busulfan-based conditioning regimens and a control arm receiving Flu/Cy/ATG or Cy/ATG regimens. The study will enroll patients aged 1-50 years and will assess the outcomes at 1 year post-HSCT.

Title: A Study to Test a Medicine (Fitusiran) for Preventing Bleeds in People With Severe Hemophilia Who Previously Received Preventive Treatment With Emicizumab

Objective: To investigate the safety and tolerability of switching from emicizumab to fitusiran prophylaxis in male participants with severe hemophilia A, with or without inhibitors.

Design: Open-label, single-arm treatment study with a single group assignment.

Population: Male participants aged 18 years or older with severe congenital hemophilia A and an inhibitor titer of ≥0.6 BU/mL.

Intervention: Participants will receive subcutaneous fitusiran prophylaxis every 2 months or once a month from Day 1 until Month 18. They may also receive intravenous clotting factor concentrates or bypassing agents as needed.

Primary Outcome Measure: Incidence, severity, and seriousness of adverse events (AEs) during the fitusiran treatment period.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Peak thrombin generation, peak antithrombin levels, emicizumab concentrations in plasma, treatment satisfaction, treatment preferences, pain intensity, physical functioning and physical activity, joint health, and annualized bleeding rate while receiving fitusiran prophylaxis.

Duration: The study will last approximately 19 months, with a 14-month extension period.

**Title:** Safety and Validation of Community Rehabilitation Exercise Program for Stroke Patients

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a community-based complex exercise program for stroke patients, focusing on functional ambulation, balance, and overall health outcomes.

**Methodology:** This randomized controlled trial (RCT) will enroll stroke patients aged 30 years or older who can walk independently and have a score of 3 or higher on the Functional Ambulation Category (FAC). Participants will be randomly assigned to either an experimental group receiving the community rehabilitation exercise program or a control group with daily life activities. The exercise program consists of warm-up, flexibility exercises, aerobic exercise, strength and balance exercises, and cool-down exercises, performed every other day for 6 weeks.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** The 6-minute walk test (6WMT) will be used to assess functional ambulation.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess balance (Berg Balance Scale), ambulation ability (Functional Ambulation Category), muscle strength (Manual Muscle Testing), fall risk (Timed Up and Go), physical activity level, body composition, and quality of life (Euro-Quality of Life-5 Dimension).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Stroke patients aged 30 years or older, able to walk independently, with a score of 3 or higher on the FAC, and no or mild stiffness of the affected upper and lower limbs.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with moderate or severe cognitive dysfunction, fall risk, language impairment, serious cardiovascular disease, musculoskeletal disorders, or judged unsuitable for the study by a rehabilitation medicine specialist.

Title: A Behavioral Intervention to Promote Primary Prevention and Uterine Preservation in Premenopausal Women With Obesity and Endometrial Hyperplasia

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention, combined with progestin therapy, in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer.

Design: Randomized, open-label trial with a crossover design. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two arms: Arm 1 (experimental) will receive a telemedicine behavioral weight loss intervention, progestin therapy via a levonorgestrel-releasing IUD, and standard care; Arm 2 (active comparator) will receive enhanced usual care, including handouts on healthy eating and exercise, and standard care.

Endpoints:

* Primary outcome: Number of participants with atypia-free biopsy with uterine preservation at 2 years
* Secondary outcomes: Time to resolution of hyperplasia, change in weight, change in Cancer Worry Impact Events Scale (CWIES), atypia-free survival or endometrial cancer-free survival

Eligibility criteria: Premenopausal women with a diagnosis of histologically confirmed complex atypical endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer, BMI ≥ 30 kg/m², and willingness to undergo placement of a levonorgestrel-releasing IUD.

This study aims to investigate the effectiveness of a behavioral intervention in promoting primary prevention and uterine preservation in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer.

Title: THE COCONUT TECHNIQUE - A NEW METHOD TO PERFORM SAFE CHOLECYSTECTOMY FOR ACUTE CHOLECYSTITIS: Our Initial Experience

Objective: To evaluate the safety and effectiveness of a new laparoscopic technique, the "Coconut technique", for performing cholecystectomy in patients with stage II acute cholecystitis.

Methodology: The study included 3 patients (2 females, 1 male) with a mean age of 50 years, who were diagnosed with stage II acute cholecystitis and underwent the Coconut technique within 3 days of symptom onset. The procedure involved cutting 3-4 cm of the inflamed gallbladder wall, making an incision in a safe zone, and clipping the cystic duct.

Primary Outcome Measure: The study measured the success of the Coconut technique in performing subtotal cholecystectomy.

Key findings: The study demonstrated the safety and effectiveness of the Coconut technique in performing cholecystectomy in patients with acute cholecystitis.

Title: The Effect of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy and Virtual Reality Use in Supporting Physical Rehabilitation After Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) Operation

Objective: To examine the effectiveness of a Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol enriched with virtual reality (VR) in reducing psychological problems experienced by athletes after ACL surgery, including re-injury anxiety, kinesiophobia, poor rehabilitation adherence, and poor rehabilitation self-efficacy.

Methodology: This randomized controlled trial will enroll 60 athletes who have undergone ACL surgery and will be assigned to one of four groups: CBT+VR, VR, CBT, or control. The CBT+VR group will receive a structured CBT protocol with VR, while the VR group will receive only the VR component. The CBT group will receive only the CBT protocol, and the control group will receive a placebo control protocol. The primary outcome measures will be re-injury anxiety, rehabilitation adherence, self-efficacy, and kinesiophobia, which will be assessed through standardized scales.

Significance: If the CBT+VR protocol is effective, it has the potential to improve the quality of physical rehabilitation and enhance the psychological outcomes of athletes returning to sport.

Title: Analysis of a Stepped-Wedge Implementation of the PT-PENCIL Tool

Objective: To assess the development and implementation strategy of the PT-PENCIL, a patient-level clinical decision support tool, and analyze its effect on improving the proportion of patients discharged home from the hospital.

Methodology: A stepped-wedge implementation design was used, where physical therapists received the PT-PENCIL tool in a staggered manner. The tool was integrated into the electronic health record (EHR) and provided alerts and indicators to guide physical therapy treatment frequency.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients admitted to the hospital for at least one overnight stay, with a primary medical service in one of the specified areas, and aged 18 years or older.

Primary Outcome Measures: The effectiveness of the PT-PENCIL on discharge home versus facility, reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the tool.

Secondary Outcome Measures: None specified.

The study aims to evaluate the impact of the PT-PENCIL tool on improving patient outcomes and reducing post-acute care utilization by optimizing physical therapy treatment frequency.

Title: Comparison of Post Facilitation Stretch and Maitland Mobilization in Post-traumatic Stiff Elbow

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of post-facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion and reducing pain in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow.

Design: Randomized, controlled trial with 32 participants aged 18-35 years with post-traumatic stiff elbow. Participants were randomly assigned to either the post-facilitation stretch group or the Maitland mobilization group.

Interventions:

* Post-facilitation stretch group: 6-10 seconds of isometric contraction followed by 15 seconds of passive stretch, repeated 4-5 times daily, 5 days a week for 4 weeks.
* Maitland mobilization group: 2-3 oscillations per second for 1 minute, repeated 5 sets daily, 5 days a week for 4 weeks, along with hot packs and active and active-assisted exercises.

Primary outcomes:

* Range of motion (ROM) of elbow joint flexion and extension
* ROM of forearm supination and pronation
* Numeric pain rating scale

Secondary outcome:

* Disability measured through the DASH questionnaire

The study aimed to compare the effectiveness of post-facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization in improving range of motion and reducing pain in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow.

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a multidisciplinary approach using an AI-enabled handheld echocardiogram (Us2.ai) in diagnosing heart failure in high-risk patients.

Title: A Randomized Study to Investigate Central and Cerebral Hemodynamic Effects and Volume Kinetics of Ringer's Acetate Compared With no Intravenous Fluids, During Experimental Hypovolemia Compared With Euvolemia, in Healthy Human Volunteers

Objective: To explore the effects over time of an intravenous fluid bolus on the volume expanding effects and hemodynamic effects during experimental hypovolemia compared with euvolemia in healthy human volunteers.

Design: A randomized, crossover, placebo-controlled, single-center study with a factorial design (2x2) in healthy volunteers aged 18-40 years.

Interventions:

* No intervention (LBNP 0 + no intravenous fluid)
* Experimental: LBNP 0 + Ringer's acetate (5 ml/kg)
* Active comparator: LBNP 40 + no intravenous fluid
* Experimental: LBNP 40 + Ringer's acetate (5 ml/kg)

Primary outcome measures:

* Cardiac stroke volume (half-life of change)
* Intravascular volume (half-life of change)
* Middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity (half-life of change)

Secondary outcome measures:

* Hemodynamic variables, such as SV, CO, and ABP

The study aims to investigate the effects of Ringer's acetate on the volume expanding effects and hemodynamic effects during experimental hypovolemia compared with euvolemia in healthy human volunteers.

Title: Guided Internet-delivered Treatment for Moderate Depression, Social Anxiety Disorder, and Panic Disorder - An Open Naturalistic Multicentre Cost-effectiveness Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of a guided internet-based cognitive therapy (ICBT) program, eMeistring, for patients with moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder.

Methodology:

* The study is a naturalistic, open-label, multicentre trial with a minimum of 18 years old participants.
* Participants will receive eight to nine sessions of therapist-guided ICBT via the internet, with at least one session per week.
* The program will be delivered through a secure email system, and therapists will be licensed health professionals.
* The study will assess the effectiveness of the program using primary and secondary outcome measures, including depression severity, social phobia, panic disorder symptoms, health-related quality of life, work and social adjustment, anxiety severity, and system usability.
* The study will also collect data on the cost of healthcare services, medication use, work participation, and sickness absenteeism.

Key Inclusion Criteria:

* Moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, or panic disorder as a primary disorder
* Access to a computer and internet

Key Exclusion Criteria:

* Severe depression, suicidal impulses and thoughts, bipolar disorders, psychosis, substance abuse, unstable medication, and severe reading or writing disabilities.

The study aims to provide evidence on the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of eMeistring as a treatment option for patients with moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

This randomized controlled trial compares the efficacy of two ultrasound-guided analgesic techniques, Thoracolumbar Interfascial Plane (TLIP) block and Erector Spinae Plane (ESP) block, for perioperative analgesia in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery. The trial aims to evaluate the blockade area, perioperative effectiveness, and side effects of both techniques.

Patients were randomly assigned to one of three groups: TLIP group, ESP group, and control group. The TLIP group received a TLIP block with 20ml of ropivacaine 0.25% on each side, followed by general anesthesia. The ESP group received an ESP block with 20ml of ropivacaine 0.25% on each side, followed by general anesthesia. The control group received general anesthesia only, with incision anesthetization using lidocaine mixed with adrenaline.

The primary outcome measures include the blockade area, total amount of fentanyl used during surgery, Analgesia Nociception Index (ANIm) scores, total dose of morphine in 12 hours and 24 hours after surgery, and Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores. Secondary outcomes include side effects such as vomiting, nausea, itching, urinary retention, respiratory failure, and circulatory failure.

The trial aims to provide insights into the effectiveness and safety of TLIP and ESP blocks as alternatives to traditional analgesic techniques for lumbar spine fusion surgery.

Title: Phase 1/2 Study to Evaluate the Safety, Feasibility, and Efficacy of FP-1201 (Intravenous Interferon-Beta-1a) to Prevent Toxicities After CD19-Directed CAR T-Cell Therapy

Objective: To evaluate the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of FP-1201 (intravenous interferon-beta-1a) in preventing toxicities after CD19-directed CAR T-cell therapy in patients with recurrent or refractory B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or mantle cell lymphoma.

Design: This is a dose-escalation study with a single group assignment. Patients will receive FP-1201 intravenously for 3 or 5 days before and after CAR T-cell infusion. The primary outcome measures are dose-limiting toxicity rates and incidence of adverse events.

Eligibility criteria: Patients must be at least 18 years old, have a Karnofsky performance status of 60% or higher, and be eligible for treatment with axi-cel or brexu-cel. Exclusion criteria include known hypersensitivity to interferon beta, significant proteinuria, severe hepatic dysfunction, and significant cardiovascular abnormalities.

Interventions: Patients will undergo leukapheresis, lymphodepletion chemotherapy, and CAR T-cell infusion. They will also undergo imaging studies, lumbar puncture, and blood and tissue biopsies.

Primary outcome measures: Dose-limiting toxicity rates and incidence of adverse events will be assessed within 14 days after the last administration of FP-1201.

Secondary outcome measures: Cytokine release syndrome and immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome rates, cumulative corticosteroids dose, overall response rate, and complete response rate will be assessed.

This study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of FP-1201 in preventing toxicities after CD19-directed CAR T-cell therapy and to determine the optimal dose of FP-1201 for further study.

Title: Assessment of Sleep Quality of Hospitalized Patients Treated With EEG-guided Protection Procedures: Application in Intensive Care Unit (SleepScan)

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of EEG-guided sleep protection procedures in improving sleep quality and reducing sleep disruptions in critically ill patients in an intensive care unit (ICU).

Design: Non-randomized, open-label trial with sequential assignment to either a control group (usual care) or an experimental group (EEG-guided sleep protection).

Intervention: The experimental group received EEG-guided sleep protection, which used an algorithm to display a specific picture to caregivers and family members, instructing them to follow sleep protection rules to minimize sleep disruptions. The control group received usual care.

Outcomes: Primary outcomes included sleep quality, sleep fragmentation, and sleep interruptions by caregivers. Secondary outcomes included environmental noise and light, workload assessed by nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient-reported sleep quality, anxiety level, respiratory status, presence of delirium, unit care length of stay, and safety of the procedure.

Eligibility Criteria: Adults admitted to a medical ICU, un-sedated, and displaying a Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) score between -2 and +1. Exclusion criteria included patients with central nervous system disease, those who received drugs modifying EEG and sleep scoring, and those with cutaneous erosion of the scalp.

Duration: The study will enroll patients for an average of 14 days.

Title: Healthcare Disparities in Vitiligo: a Population-based Cohort Study in the UK

Objective: To estimate the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo in the population, and to identify health-related disparities across different sociodemographic groups, including age, sex, ethnicity, and deprivation.

Study Design: Observational cohort study using data from the Office for Population Censuses and Surveys Research Database (OPCRD) from 2004 to 2020.

Population: Adults and adolescents (aged 13+) registered with OPCRD during the study period.

Inclusion Criteria: People newly diagnosed with vitiligo at any point during the study period.

Exclusion Criteria: People with alternative non-vitiligo diagnoses, vitiligo diagnosis within 6 months of practice registration, people without vitiligo with less than 1 year of follow-up, people over the age of 95, and people who have opted out of record sharing.

Outcome Measures:

* Primary outcome: Total disease burden of vitiligo measured using cumulative lifetime incidence against age.
* Secondary outcomes: Incidence and prevalence of mental health conditions, healthcare utilisation (primary care encounters, dermatology referrals, mental health referrals), and work-related impact (unemployment, time off work).

The study aims to provide an estimate of the cumulative lifetime risk of vitiligo and identify disparities in health outcomes across different sociodemographic groups.

The study recruited 39 caregivers of children with developmental delay and randomly assigned them to either a hybrid group (n=20) or a self-learning group (n=19). The hybrid group received a behavior modification program that included online sessions, individual consultation sessions, and online schedule reminders, while the self-learning group received a description of the course goals and a reading of the Atomic Habits book. 

The study assessed the outcomes using several measures, including Intervention Fidelity, Parenting Sense of Confidence, Parenting Stress Index: Short form, The Conflict Tactics Scales: Parent Version, habit schedule record, and satisfaction questionnaire. The data were analyzed using Mann-Whinney U test, the Wilcoxon Signed Ranked Test, and Spearman correlation analysis. 

The primary outcome measures were Intervention Fidelity and Parenting Sense of Confidence, while the secondary outcome measures were Parenting Stress Index: Short form, The Conflict Tactics Scales: Parent Version, and Satisfaction Questionnaire. The study aimed to examine the effects of the behavior modification program on the caregivers' stress, self-efficacy, relationships, and conflict over an 8-week period.

**Title:** A Phase I/Ib Trial of Trotabresib (BMS-986378), an Oral BET Inhibitor, in Combination With Vinorelbine and Radiation Therapy in HER2+ Breast Cancer Patients With Central Nervous System Metastasis and Leptomeningeal Disease (CA076-1008)

**Objective:** To determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase II dose of trotabresib in combination with vinorelbine, and to measure progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) in patients with HER2+ breast cancer with central nervous system (CNS) metastasis and leptomeningeal disease.

**Design:** This is a phase I dose-escalation study followed by a phase Ib dose expansion study. Patients are assigned to one of two cohorts: Cohort I, which includes patients with CNS metastases or leptomeningeal disease who undergo radiation therapy and then receive trotabresib and vinorelbine, and Cohort S, which includes patients who undergo tumor resection and then receive trotabresib and vinorelbine.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients must have histologically or cytologically confirmed HER2+ breast cancer, newly diagnosed or progressive CNS metastases or leptomeningeal disease, and an estimated life expectancy of at least 3 months. Patients must also have a Karnofsky performance status of at least 60% and adequate bone marrow, liver, and renal function.

**Interventions:** Patients receive trotabresib orally and vinorelbine intravenously in combination with radiation therapy (Cohort I) or surgery (Cohort S). Patients undergo magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), computed tomography (CT), and collection of blood samples throughout the trial.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Dose-limiting toxicities (Phase I) and incidence of adverse events (Phase Ib).

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and objective response rate (ORR).

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with a history of allergic reactions to trotabresib or vinorelbine, impaired cardiac function, or poor bone marrow reserve are excluded from the study. Additionally, patients who are pregnant or nursing are not eligible for the study.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the digital health tool in promoting weight management and reducing binge eating in Black women with obesity.

The clinical trial, titled "Integrins and Protocadherins in Glutamatergic Circuits: Identification of Common Signaling Pathways and Molecular Targets in Anxiety and Major Depressive Disorders (GAPsy)", aims to investigate the neural mechanisms underlying anxiety and major depressive disorders (MDD-AD). The study consists of two parts: a human component and a murine model component.

In the human component, 10 patients with MDD-AD and 10 healthy controls (HC) will be recruited. Participants will undergo a 7T multimodal neuroimaging session, including T1-weighted, 1H-MRS, and fMRI, as well as structured clinical interviews and psychopathological tests. The study will assess brain structure differences in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, functional connectivity differences, and glutamatergic neurotransmission differences between the two groups.

In the murine model component, the study will investigate the effects of Pcdh9 deficits on excitatory synapses and glutamatergic signaling. The expression levels of glutamate receptor subunits will be analyzed, and the interaction between integrin β3 and Protocadherin9 will be characterized using co-immunoprecipitation analysis. Electrophysiological characterization of Itgb3 and Pcdh9 patterns in the medial prefrontal cortex will also be performed.

The primary outcome measures include brain structure differences in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, functional connectivity differences, and glutamatergic neurotransmission differences between the two groups. The study aims to identify common signaling pathways and molecular targets in anxiety and MDD-AD, and to explore the potential therapeutic applications of CRISPR-mediated transcription activation (CRISPRa) in treating these disorders.

Data Analysis: Machine learning methods will be used to analyze the multi-omics data and identify associations between the intestinal microbiome and cardiovascular and nervous system diseases.

Expected Outcomes: Identification of potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets for disease prevention and treatment, as well as a better understanding of the mechanisms underlying the association between the intestinal microbiome and cardiovascular and nervous system diseases.

Study Overview:
The study aims to improve the healthcare experiences of people with incurable Head and Neck Cancer (HNC) by understanding their experiences and identifying priority areas for improvement.

Methods:

Location:

For more information, please contact the study team.

The study is a randomized, open-label trial investigating the use of indocyanine green (ICG) fluorescence imaging to assist in identifying and protecting nerve roots during endoscopic spinal surgery in patients with lumbar disc herniation. The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of ICG fluorescence imaging in reducing nerve root injury and improving surgical outcomes.

The study will enroll patients aged 20-60 years with lumbar disc herniation who are undergoing endoscopic spinal surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: control group, 0.5mg/kg ICG group, 1mg/kg ICG group, or 2mg/kg ICG group. The primary outcome measures will include the fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, fluorescence signal ratio of nerve root to back fluorescence, and time taken to find the nerve root endoscopically.

Secondary outcome measures will include ICG-related adverse reactions, visual analogue pain scale (VAS), Oswestry disability index (ODI), surgical complications, and length of surgery. The study will assess these outcomes at various time points, including preoperatively, intraoperatively, and postoperatively.

The study is expected to provide valuable insights into the use of ICG fluorescence imaging in endoscopic spinal surgery, potentially improving surgical outcomes and reducing nerve root injury.

Eligible patients will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: usual practice (encounter-based PRO monitoring), experimental arm 1 (usual practice with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts), or experimental arm 2 (remote PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts).

Title: Intrathecal Catheter Placement Versus Resiting Epidural Catheter After Dural Puncture in Obstetric Patients

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of intrathecal catheter placement versus resiting epidural catheter after dural puncture in obstetric patients in reducing the incidence and severity of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH).

Design: Multicenter randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and open-label design.

Participants: Female patients aged 18 years or older with a confirmed diagnosis of dural puncture during labor, who provide written informed consent.

Interventions:

* Resiting Epidural Catheter: The epidural catheter is re-sited in a different intervertebral space after a dural puncture, and analgesia is maintained using a programmed intermittent epidural bolus system.
* Intrathecal Catheter Placement: An intrathecal catheter is placed through the dural tap after a dural puncture, and analgesia is maintained using a programmed intermittent subarachnoid bolus system.

Primary Outcome Measure: Incidence of PDPH at 24 hours from dural puncture occurrence.

Secondary Outcome Measures: PDPH intensity at 24 and 48 hours, quality of analgesia during labor, adverse events, chronic pain at 1 and 3 months, readmission to hospital, and patient satisfaction.

Keywords: Labor pain, obstetric labor complications, analgesia, epidural.

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CAR T-cell therapy, in patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma.

**Eligibility:** Patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, transformed follicular lymphoma, primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma, and high-grade B-cell lymphoma, who have received at least two prior lines of therapy.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Secondary outcome measures include overall response rate (ORR), duration of response (DOR), duration of complete response (DOCR), median progression-free survival (PFS), median overall survival (OS), and persistence of IMPT-314 in peripheral blood.

Title: The Application of Propofol and Remifentanil Mixed Solution for Controlled Sedation and Analgesia in Fiber Colonoscopy

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of propofol and remifentanil mixed solution for controlled sedation and analgesia in fiber colonoscopy compared to intravenous combined anesthesia.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group study with two arms: Experimental (Controlled analgesia/sedation group) and Active Comparator (Intravenous combined anesthesia group).

Participants: Patients aged 18-75 years with American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Grade I-II, body mass index (BMI) <25 kg/m², and no mental and nervous system diseases.

Interventions:

* Experimental group: Patients received a loading dose of 3 ml of propofol and remifentanil mixture, followed by continuous infusion at 0.1 ml/kg/h. Patients controlled the infusion rate by pressing a self-control handle.
* Active Comparator group: Patients received intravenous fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol, followed by propofol infusion to maintain auditory evoked potential index (AAI) between 30-40.

Outcome Measures:

* Primary outcome: Auditory evoked potential (AEPI) values at 5 time points before anesthesia, at the beginning of the examination, during endoscopy, and at the end of the examination.
* Secondary outcome: Time from surgery to OAA/S score of 5 and Aldrete score of 9.

The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of propofol and remifentanil mixed solution for controlled sedation and analgesia in fiber colonoscopy with intravenous combined anesthesia.

Objective: To evaluate the effect of hot-cold application to the bladder on postoperative urinary retention in orthopedic surgery patients.

Methodology: This is a single-blind randomized controlled trial (RCT) involving 2 groups: an experimental group receiving hot-cold application to the bladder and a control group receiving routine clinical functioning. **Title:** Radiomic Features of Pancreas from Contrast Enhanced CT Image Predict One-Year Recurrence Risk of Acute Pancreatitis

**Objective:** To evaluate the sensitivity and specificity of a deep-learning integrated model that combines radiomic features and clinical factors from high-concentration (370 mgI/ml) Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT images to predict the recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 12 months.

**Study Design:** Prospective, multicenter study with 694 consecutive patients with first episode of acute pancreatitis who underwent enhanced CT scan within 14 days after onset of symptoms. Patients were followed up for 12 months and divided into recurrent and non-recurrent groups.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** The sensitivity and specificity of the model to predict the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 12 months.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The total number of subjects who developed the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within 3, 6, and 12 months, as well as the sensitivity and specificity of the model to predict overall recurrence of acute pancreatitis in 3 and 6 months.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients aged 18-70 years with acute pancreatitis diagnosed according to the Atlanta Classification, who underwent enhanced CT scan within 14 days after onset of symptoms, and signed informed consent.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with history of allergy to iodinated contrast agent, confirmed or suspected hyperthyroidism or pheochromocytoma, pregnancy or lactation, or other exclusion criteria.

**Study Duration:** 12 months.

**Sample Size:** 694 patients.

**Statistical Analysis:** Descriptive statistics, summary statistics, and statistical tests were performed using R software.

The "Tailoring Bleeding Reduction Approaches in Patients Undergoing PCI" clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy and safety of two antiplatelet treatment strategies in patients with coronary artery disease who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The study will randomize patients to either a dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) de-escalation strategy or a potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy strategy.

The DAPT de-escalation strategy involves switching patients from a potent P2Y12 inhibitor (prasugrel or ticagrelor) to clopidogrel while maintaining aspirin. The potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy strategy involves discontinuing aspirin and continuing prasugrel or ticagrelor.

The primary outcome measure is thrombus formation, which will be assessed using the Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS) at 30 days. The study will also evaluate the safety and efficacy of the two strategies in terms of bleeding complications, ischemic events, and mortality.

The trial aims to determine whether the potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy strategy is non-inferior to the DAPT de-escalation strategy in terms of thrombus formation, while reducing bleeding complications. The study will provide valuable insights into the optimal antiplatelet treatment strategy for patients with coronary artery disease who have undergone PCI.

The study aims to develop a novel biomarker, virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA), for predicting response and prognosis of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients undergoing radiotherapy (RT) who are infected with hepatitis B virus (HBV). The biomarker is expected to accurately diagnose residual tumors and predict early recurrence/metastasis, allowing for early intervention with salvage therapies. The study will retrospectively analyze previously collected serum samples and surgical/biopsied tissues from HBV-related HCC patients who underwent RT, and prospectively collect plasma samples from patients before and after RT to validate the biomarker's performance. The primary outcome measures include the analysis of capture-NGS and VH-DNA specific PCR, serial changes of serum and plasma VH-DNA copies, and the association of VH-DNA changes with treatment response and overall survival. The study aims to identify the clonality of recurrent HCC and explore the use of VH-DNA as a biomarker for earlier evaluating treatment response, post-RT disease monitoring, and differentiating clonality at recurrence.

**Title:** The Feasibility of Remote Clinical Trial Conduct in Patients With Diabetes and Elevated Albuminuria, Individual Responses to Empagliflozin, and Whether Suboptimal Treatment Responses Can be Overcome by the Addition or Switch With Finerenone

**Objective:** To evaluate the feasibility and advantages of conducting a remote clinical trial in patients with type 2 diabetes and elevated albuminuria, and to determine the individual response to empagliflozin and whether suboptimal treatment responses can be overcome by adding or switching to finerenone.

**Study Design:** This is a single-centre, prospective, open-label, decentralized, crossover pilot study involving 10 patients with type 2 diabetes and elevated albuminuria. Participants will be assigned to one of three treatment regimens based on their individual response to empagliflozin: continue empagliflozin, intensify treatment with finerenone, or switch to finerenone.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The primary outcome measures are the participants' perspectives toward the feasibility of participation in a trial at home with digital technologies, and the number and percentage of urine collections not received at the laboratory or unable to be analyzed.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The secondary outcome measures include individual responses to empagliflozin and finerenone, including changes in urine albumin-to-creatinine ratio, systolic blood pressure, body weight, estimated glomerular filtration rate, and fasting plasma glucose.

**Interventions:** Participants will receive empagliflozin 10 mg/day for 3 weeks, followed by either continued empagliflozin, intensified treatment with finerenone, or switched to finerenone.

**Duration:** The study will last 10 weeks, with a total expected time commitment of approximately 25 hours.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients must have type 2 diabetes, elevated albuminuria, and an estimated glomerular filtration rate ≥25 mL/min/1.73m2.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Change in psychophysical olfactory function, perceived intensity and hedonics of odorants, and olfactory-related quality of life.

**Title:** Efficacy of Perioperative US-Guided Serratus Anterior Plane Block Versus Thoracic Epidural in Adult Patient Undergoing Thoracotomy: A Randomized Comparative Double-Blinded Trial

**Objective:** To compare the effectiveness of perioperative continuous serratus anterior plane block (SAPB) versus continuous thoracic epidural (TEA) in patients undergoing thoracotomy for cancer surgery.

**Methodology:** A randomized, double-blinded, controlled trial involving 74 patients (37 in each group) with lung cancer undergoing thoracotomy. Patients were randomly allocated to receive either SAPB or TEA. The primary outcome measure was postoperative total morphine requirement.

**Interventions:** SAPB was performed using ultrasound guidance, and a catheter was inserted to deliver a bolus of 30 mL of 0.25% bupivacaine followed by a continuous infusion of 0.125% bupivacaine at a rate of 7-12 ml/hr. TEA was performed using a thoracic epidural catheter, and a test dose of 3 ccs of 1.5% lidocaine with 1:200,000 epinephrine was administered.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcome measures included postoperative total morphine requirement, intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to the first analgesia requested by the patient, postoperative pain, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfactory score.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with lung cancer undergoing thoracotomy, physical status ASA II and III, body mass index (BMI) > 20 kg/m2 and < 40 kg/m2.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with known sensitivity or contraindication to local anesthetics, history of psychological disorders, localized infection at the site of block, coagulopathies, and patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation postoperatively.

Title: Evaluate Harm Reduction Products as a Second Line Intervention for Adult Smokers Who Do Not Quit With NRT

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of harm reduction products (nicotine pouches and e-cigarettes) as a second-line intervention for adult smokers who do not quit with nicotine replacement therapy (NRT).

Study Design: A randomized, open-label study with four arms:

1. Experimental: Group I - NRT Responder: Participants who quit smoking with NRT in the first four weeks have the option to remain on NRT or switch to another product.
2. Experimental: Group IIa NRT Non-Responder - Pouch Preferrers: Participants who did not quit smoking with NRT and prefer nicotine pouches are randomized to switch to nicotine pouches or remain on NRT.
3. Experimental: Group IIb NRT Non-Responder - Pouch Preferrers Control: Participants who did not quit smoking with NRT and prefer nicotine pouches are randomized to remain on NRT.
4. Experimental: Group IIIa NRT Non-Responder - ENDS Preferrers: Participants who did not quit smoking with NRT and prefer e-cigarettes are randomized to switch to e-cigarettes or remain on NRT.
5. Experimental: Group IIIb NRT Non-Responder - ENDS Preferrers Control: Participants who did not quit smoking with NRT and prefer e-cigarettes are randomized to remain on NRT.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Change in smoke exposure for NRT non-responders (expired air CO at week 10 compared to baseline)
* Smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders (complete smoking abstinence defined by self-report and expired air CO<6 ppm)

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Smoking abstinence rates for NRT non-responders (complete smoking abstinence defined by self-report)

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of harm reduction products as a second-line intervention for adult smokers who do not quit with NRT, and to compare the outcomes between different products and treatment arms.

Title: Effects of Two Types of Concurrent Training in Functional Performance and Cognitive Function of Older Adults

Objective: To investigate the effects of traditional concurrent training (strength training followed by aerobic exercise) and concurrent training consisting of strength training combined with dance classes on functional performance, cognitive function, and quality of life in older adults.

Participants were randomly assigned to one of three groups: traditional concurrent training, concurrent training with dance classes, or a control group that maintained their usual routine.

Title: A Comparison of Acute Psychobiological Responses to Laboratory Stress Tests

Objective: To compare the acute psychobiological responses to the Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST) and the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST) in healthy adults.

Design: Randomized, parallel assignment study with a between-subjects design. Participants were randomly assigned to either the MMST or TSST group.

Interventions: The MMST group completed a computer-based paced auditory serial addition task (PASAT-C) in the presence of an observer, while being exposed to emotionally evocative images and white noise via headphones. Participants: Healthy adults aged 18-35 years, with a BMI ≤ 30 kg/m2, who were not currently taking prescription or over-the-counter medication (except for oral combined contraception in women). Exclusion criteria included a recent history of smoking, cardiovascular and/or metabolic disease, psychiatric disorder, sleeping disorder, gambling addiction, and endurance training or engaging in ≥3.5 hours of physical activity per week.

Title: The Effects of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth Syndrome in ICU Patients: An Observational Study

Objective: To assess the prevalence of Small Intestinal Bacterial Overgrowth (SIBO) in critically ill mechanically ventilated Intensive Care Unit (ICU) patients and investigate its effects on ventilator-associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate.

Methods: This is a non-invasive observational study using a modified hydrogen breath test to diagnose SIBO in critically ill patients. Patients are administered 20g of lactulose and measurements are taken at predetermined time intervals. The primary outcome measure is the prevalence of SIBO, and secondary outcomes include the effects of SIBO on ventilator-associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality rate.

Eligibility criteria: Critically ill patients requiring mechanical ventilation with an expected ICU length of stay and mechanical ventilation duration of more than 48 hours.

Exclusion criteria: Abnormal hydrogen breath test on day of ICU admission, recent antimicrobial therapy, gastroprotective medication, probiotics, or prokinetics, known gastrointestinal disease, recent abdominal surgery, or extubation or death before protocol completion.

Objective: To investigate whether exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) is present after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and if it changes with exercise intensity.

Methods: A randomized, single-blinded study was conducted on 38 patients 24 hours after TKA, who were randomly assigned to either a low-intensity exercises (LIE) group or a high-intensity exercises (HIE) group. Pain severity was assessed using a Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured over quadriceps and biceps brachii muscles before and after exercise.

Primary outcomes: Change in pain severity and change in pressure pain threshold.

Population: Patients with knee osteoarthritis who underwent primary unilateral total knee replacement surgery and were hospitalized for at least 7 days.

Title: A Randomised Crossover Clinical Trial to Compare the Effects of Different Storage Conditions on Removable Retainers

Objective: To compare the microbial colony counts, surface roughness, colour stability, and compressive strength of removable retainers stored in wet and dry conditions, and to evaluate the oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) of participants.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with sectional fixed appliance treatment or fixed appliance treatment on single arch only, planned for double retention with bonded retainers, systemic disease that may affect salivary flow, or smoking patients.

**Title:** Essential Connections: Hospital to Community Impacting Malnutrition Outcomes in Older Adults

**Objective:** To test the feasibility and effectiveness of a new model of continuity of nutrition care for patients older than 60 years with malnutrition, focusing on vulnerable populations, including Black, Latino, Indigenous, and Native American individuals and those living in rural areas.

**Methodology:** This is a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design, where eight sites will be randomized to implement the new model in a staggered approach over five periods, with each period lasting seven months.

**Intervention:** The new model involves enhanced continuity of care between acute care hospitals and community meal provision organizations, including patient identification, cross-referrals, data reporting, and communication. Community RDNs will provide medical nutrition therapy (MNT) and medically tailored meals (MTM) to patients for three months post-discharge from the hospital.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Quality of Life Scale (CASP-19) and Change in percent of patients receiving nutrition care and meals.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Program Sustainability Assessment Tool, RDN Survey on Barriers and Facilitators to Implementation, Food Security Risk, Malnutrition risk, and Malnutrition Diagnosis (AAIM tool).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients must be English or Spanish speaking, screened as at risk for malnutrition, food insecure, referred to an RDN, diagnosed with malnutrition, and eligible to receive Title III-C1 or Title III-C2 nutrition services.

**Study Duration:** 35 months, with patient recruitment occurring across all five periods.

**Study Title:** A Phase 1 Study of Peposertib (M3814) and Low-Dose Liposomal Doxorubicin (Doxil) in Patients With Metastatic Leiomyosarcoma and Other Soft Tissue Sarcomas

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and tolerability of peposertib in combination with low-dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride in patients with metastatic leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas.

**Design:** This is a dose-escalation study followed by a dose-expansion study. Patients receive peposertib orally twice daily and pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride intravenously once daily during treatment cycles. Cycles repeat every 28 days in the absence of disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or withdrawal of consent.

**Primary Objectives:**

1. To evaluate the safety and tolerability of peposertib in combination with low-dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin hydrochloride.
2. To determine the recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination and determine the maximal tolerated dose (MTD) if identified.

**Secondary Objectives:**

1. To assess the pharmacokinetics of peposertib and liposomal doxorubicin used in combination with each other.
2. To estimate the objective response rate (ORR) per Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) 1.1 in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated with peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin.
3. To estimate the progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated with peposertib and low-dose liposomal doxorubicin.

**Correlative Objectives:**

1. To test the hypothesis that soft tissue sarcomas (STS) with homologous recombination deficiency (HRD) will be more susceptible to deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA)-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin.
2. To test the hypothesis that gammaH2AX and pNBS1 can be used as pharmacodynamic biomarkers of response to DNA-PKi in combination with low-dose liposomal doxorubicin.
3. To test the hypothesis that disease activity correlates with circulating tumor DNA levels in the plasma.

**Eligibility Criteria:**

1. Patients with histologically confirmed sarcoma that is metastatic or unresectable.
2. Patients must have been treated with at least 1 prior line of therapy.
3. Patients must have evaluable disease that is amenable to biopsy.
4. Patients must have an Eastern Cooperative Oncology Group (ECOG) performance status ≤ 2.
5. Patients must have a negative urine or serum pregnancy test within 72 hours prior to receiving the first dose of study medication.

**Exclusion Criteria:**

1. Patients who have not recovered from adverse events due to prior anti-cancer therapy.
2. Patients who are receiving any other investigational agents.
3. Patients who have a history of allergic reactions attributed to compounds of similar chemical or biologic composition to peposertib or other agents used in the study.
4. Patients who cannot discontinue concomitant medications or herbal supplements that are strong inhibitors or strong inducers of cytochrome P450 (CYP) isoenzymes.

This is a non-randomized, prospective observational study investigating the relationship between androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) and cognitive decline in men with prostate cancer. The study aims to evaluate whether baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio is associated with cognitive decline in men upon starting ADT, and whether ADT is associated with a decline in plasma Aβ42/40 ratio. The study will enroll two cohorts: the ADT cohort, consisting of men with hormone-sensitive prostate cancer who are starting ADT, and the Prostate Cancer (PC) cohort, consisting of men in remission from prostate cancer who have never received ADT. Secondary outcome measures include changes in mean plasma Aβ42/40 ratio, mean cognition score, and mean study partner-reported cognition score.

The study aims to provide insights into the relationship between ADT and cognitive decline in men with prostate cancer, with the ultimate goal of identifying potential biomarkers for predicting cognitive decline.

Title: High-dose Cephalexin for Cellulitis (HI-DOCC)

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of high-dose (1000 mg QID) cephalexin with standard-dose (500 mg QID) cephalexin in treating adult patients with non-purulent cellulitis in the emergency department.

Methods: This is a multicenter, parallel-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled trial conducted at 8 Canadian emergency departments. A total of 446 patients (223 per group) will be enrolled. Patients will be randomized to receive either high-dose or standard-dose cephalexin for 7 days. The primary outcome is oral antibiotic treatment failure, defined as a change in antibiotic treatment within 7 days due to worsening infection.

Secondary outcomes include clinical cure, clinical response, unplanned visits to a healthcare provider, unplanned hospitalization, adverse events, antibiotic intolerance, antibiotic allergy, medication adherence, and health-related quality of life.

The study aims to determine whether high-dose cephalexin is superior to standard-dose cephalexin in reducing oral antibiotic treatment failure and improving patient outcomes in adult patients with cellulitis.
