Title: Comparison of Biofilm Accumulation on the Surface of Zirconia Versus Titanium Implants: A Randomized Controlled Pilot Clinical Trial

Objective: To compare the biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia versus titanium implants in patients undergoing single-implant placement.

Design: Randomized controlled pilot clinical trial with 30 subjects (15 in each group) to evaluate the biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia and titanium implants.

Interventions: Patients will receive either a zirconia or titanium implant for single-tooth replacement. The implants will be placed using a standardized surgical procedure, and patients will receive antibiotic treatment, analgesic and anti-inflammatory medication, and physical anti-inflammatory measures.

Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure is the total amount of biofilm (CFU/ml) and the amount of specific bacteria (CFU/ml) on the implants at 6 months and 1 year after final crown placement. Secondary outcomes include implant survival, probing depth, bleeding on probing, plaque index, and amount of keratinized gingiva.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients of both sexes, aged 18-99 years, with a single missing tooth, and ASA I, II, or III classification.

Exclusion Criteria: Pregnant or breastfeeding women, patients with uncontrolled periodontal pathology, systemic pathology contraindicating the surgical procedure, and patients taking certain medications.

The study aims to evaluate the biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia and titanium implants and compare the two materials in terms of biofilm formation. The results of this pilot study will inform the design of larger, more comprehensive investigations.

Title: The Effect of Transtheoretic Model and Motivational Interview Based Intervention Program on Smartphone Addiction and Sleep Quality Levels in Nursing Students

Objective: To investigate the effect of a motivational interviewing program based on the Transtheoretic Model (TTM) on smartphone addiction and sleep quality levels in nursing students who are at risk of smartphone addiction.

Methodology: This is a quasi-experimental study with a pre-test and post-test design, with a control and intervention group. Nursing students who score above the cut-off score on the Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Form (SAS-SF) will be included in the study. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive the motivational interviewing program, or the control group, which will not receive the intervention. The primary outcome measures will be smartphone addiction, sleep quality, and stages of change.

Intervention: The motivational interviewing program will be based on the TTM and will consist of a varying number of motivational interviews, depending on the stage of change of the participants. The program will aim to help participants change their behavior and reduce their smartphone addiction.

Expected outcomes: The study aims to reduce smartphone addiction and improve sleep quality in nursing students who are at risk of smartphone addiction. The study will also investigate the effect of the motivational interviewing program on the stages of change of the participants.

* Exclusion criteria: ARDS caused by COVID-19, absolute contraindications for bronchoscopy, untreated malignant arrhythmia, documented or suspected intracranial hypertension, one-lung ventilation, and severe coagulopathy.

**Objective:** To establish the scientific basis for newborn screening for cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria, two genetic disorders that can be treated effectively if diagnosed early.

**Design:** This is a single-group assignment, open-label study that will screen newborns for two mutations in the CTNS gene (cystinosis) and one mutation in the PH1 and PH3 genes (primary hyperoxaluria) using molecular-based newborn screening.

2. Number of newborns with heterozygous mutations
3. Patients with PH1 and PH3

**Secondary Outcome Measures:**

1. Newborns identified with heterozygous PH1 c.508G>A and PH3, C700+5G>T

**Study Size:** The study will include up to 200,000 samples, with the possibility of expansion.

**Expected Outcomes:** The study aims to demonstrate the transferability of genetic newborn screening for cystinosis to other laboratories and to lay the scientific basis for screening for primary hyperoxaluria. The study will also investigate whether early diagnosis and treatment lead to a more favorable prognosis for both conditions.

* Proportion of patients with detection of unexpected cancer localization during surgery by NIR camera, with respect to the pathology report
* Proportion of patients with negative surgical margins, with respect to the pathology report
* Detection speed of NIR emission
* Toxicity incidence

**Study Overview:**

The study is a pragmatic trial evaluating the effectiveness of a supportive-expressive group therapy (SEGT) intervention for patients with limb loss. The trial aims to assess the impact of SEGT on mental health outcomes, including depression and anxiety, compared to treatment as usual (TAU).

**Design:**

The study is a two-arm pragmatic trial with 130 patients randomly assigned to either the SEGT arm or the TAU arm. Participants will be assessed at baseline, discharge, and 3 months post-discharge using standardized measures, including the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-Item (GAD-7), PTSD Checklist-5 (PCL-5), and Generalized Self-Efficacy Scale (GSE).

**Intervention:**

The SEGT intervention is a 6-module program delivered over a 3-week period, focusing on coping with limb loss, managing sequelae, goal setting, and strategies for community living. The intervention is based on the evidence-based supportive-expressive approach and has been modified to specifically address the needs of limb loss inpatients.

**Primary Outcome Measures:**

The primary outcome measures are changes in PHQ-9 scores (depression) and GAD-7 scores (anxiety) from baseline to discharge and 3 months post-discharge.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:**

The secondary outcome measures include changes in PCL-5 scores (PTSD symptoms) and GSE scores (self-efficacy) from baseline to discharge and 3 months post-discharge.

**Study Population:**

The study population includes English-speaking patients aged 18 years or older with any etiology and level of limb loss, admitted to St. John's Rehab inpatient unit. Exclusion criteria include active suicidal ideation, inability to participate effectively in a group setting, and history of active psychosis or unmanaged major psychiatric disorder.

**Study Duration:**

The study will be conducted over a 2-year period, with data collection occurring over a 12-month period.

Title: Melphalan Chemoreduction for Ocular Melanoma

Objective: To assess the safety and efficacy of intra-arterial melphalan chemotherapy followed by ruthenium brachytherapy for the treatment of choroidal melanoma with a thickness equal to or greater than 8 mm.

Design: This is a phase I, single-arm, open-label clinical trial.

* Ruthenium brachytherapy using a 24-mm notched plaque 4±1 weeks after melphalan chemotherapy

* Treatment-related adverse events
* Globe salvage (number of patients requiring enucleation or evisceration)

The trial aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of this novel treatment approach for choroidal melanoma, a common primary intraocular malignancy in adults.

**Title:** Mean Arterial Pressure (MAP) Trial: A Multicenter, Randomized, Controlled Trial to Compare Three Different Strategies of Mean Arterial Pressure Management During Cardiopulmonary By-pass

**Objective:** To compare three different strategies of mean arterial pressure (MAP) management during cardiopulmonary by-pass (CPB) in cardiac surgery patients, with the primary endpoint being the maximum serum lactate value (Lmax) during CPB.

**Design:** A randomized, controlled, parallel-group trial with three arms: Standard MAP (50-60 mmHg), High MAP (70-80 mmHg), and Patient-tailored MAP (comparable to pre-operative MAP).

**Participants:** Patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery with a low risk of surgery (Euroscore II < 9%) and preserved or mildly reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF ≥ 40%).

**Interventions:** Patients will be randomized to one of the three MAP management strategies during CPB, and vasodilator or vasoconstrictor drugs will be used to maintain the assigned MAP value.

**Primary Endpoint:** Maximum serum lactate value (Lmax) during CPB.

**Secondary Endpoints:** Area under the curve (AUC) of serum lactate values during CPB, number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l during CPB, and evaluation of intraoperative cerebral and pulmonary perfusion.

**Outcome Measures:** The study will evaluate various outcomes, including serum lactate peak, AUC of serum lactate values, number of cases with serum lactate peak > 3 mmol/l, and evaluation of intraoperative cerebral and pulmonary perfusion, as well as postoperative and 30-day LVEF, acute kidney injury, gastrointestinal ischemia, hepatic function, coagulation indexes, neurological dysfunction, in-hospital mortality, and 30-day mortality.

**Sample Size:** The study aims to enroll 999 patients, with 333 patients in each group.

**Duration:** The study will be conducted over a period of 24 months.

**Objective:** The NET RETREAT trial aims to compare the effectiveness of retreating patients with metastatic unresectable midgut neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) with 177Lu-DOTATATE peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) versus everolimus, a targeted therapy.

**Eligibility:** Patients must be at least 18 years old, have histologically confirmed grade 1 or 2 well-differentiated midgut NETs, and have received previous PRRT treatment. They must also have radiological progression after prior PRRT treatment and no ongoing toxicity from prior PRRT.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the BUNDLE clinical trial:

The BUNDLE study is a prospective, mixed-methods study evaluating the effectiveness of an integrated prenatal care model that incorporates community-based doulas into standard prenatal care. The study aims to improve healthcare engagement, trust, and maternal health outcomes among Black/African American pregnant individuals in Southeastern Wisconsin. The study consists of three aims:

1. Develop an integrated prenatal care model by conducting focus groups with pregnant individuals and healthcare providers to elicit feedback on models of doula/medical provider integration.
2. Conduct a two-arm randomized controlled trial (RCT) to compare the effectiveness of the integrated prenatal care model (BUNDLE) to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement, trust, and reducing adverse maternal outcomes among 412 Black/African American pregnant individuals.
3. Disseminate findings to scholarly and community-based forums and actively pursue opportunities for systems- and policy-level change to sustain successful program outcomes.

The study will measure primary and secondary outcomes, including healthcare engagement, trust in providers, reported discrimination, perceived stress, depression, cesarean birth, unplanned healthcare utilization, severe maternal morbidity, breastfeeding initiation, and group-based medical mistrust. The study aims to improve maternal health outcomes and reduce health disparities among Black/African American pregnant individuals in Southeastern Wisconsin.

Title: Comparison of the effects of Connective Tissue Massage and Classical Massage on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.

Objective: To compare the effects of Connective Tissue Massage (CTM) and Classical Massage (CM) on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain.

Design: A 3-arm randomized controlled trial with 30 participants, divided into three groups: CTM, CM, and control.

Interventions:

* CTM: Manipulation of soft and deep tissues using short and long strokes, focusing on the lower thoracic region.
* CM: Manipulation of soft tissues using long sweeping strokes, kneading, and stroking motions, focusing on the sacrolumbar region and lumbothoracic boundary.
* Control: Standardized physiotherapy program including superficial thermal heat, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), and therapeutic ultrasound.

Outcome measures:

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

**Study Overview**

This is a phase III, open-label, randomized, controlled, comparative efficacy and safety study of Dorzotimol eye drops (20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL) versus Cosopt eye drops (20 mg/mL + 5 mg/mL) in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG).

**Study Objectives**

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops compared to Cosopt eye drops in reducing elevated intraocular pressure in patients with POAG.

**Study Design**

The study is a multicenter, prospective, open-label, randomized, comparative, controlled, parallel-arm study with 110 patients (55 in each group) aged 18-75 years with established stage I and II POAG.

**Primary and Secondary Outcomes**

The primary endpoint is the mean IOP change from baseline, while secondary endpoints include IOP reduction rate to the target level of ≤ 18 mm Hg, IOP reduction rate greater than 20%, and IOP reduction rate greater than 30%.

**Results**

The study found that Dorzotimol eye drops were noninferior to Cosopt eye drops in terms of efficacy and safety, with no statistically significant intergroup differences by any efficacy criteria tested. The efficacy differences between the two products did not exceed the noninferiority margin of 1.5 mm Hg. The safety evaluation also showed comparable safety profiles between the two products.

**Conclusion**

The study concludes that Dorzotimol eye drops are noninferior to Cosopt eye drops in reducing elevated intraocular pressure in patients with POAG, with similar safety profiles.

Title: Hysteroscopy vs. Endouterine Aspiration in the Management of Trophoblastic Retention

Objective: To compare the efficacy of hysteroscopy and endouterine aspiration in managing trophoblastic retention after early miscarriage, with a primary endpoint of uterine vacuity rate at 6 weeks after surgery.

Design: Prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, two-armed clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after spontaneous miscarriage.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with trophoblastic retention after early spontaneous miscarriage (<14 weeks of amenorrhea), diagnosis of intrauterine trophoblastic retention by endovaginal pelvic ultrasound, shared decision for surgical management, and current pregnancy desire.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with known uterine malformation, previous surgical treatment for current intrauterine retention, trophoblastic retention after elective termination, late miscarriage, or postpartum, or patients with an intrauterine device (IUD).

Interventions: Patients will be randomized to either hysteroscopy or endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention. Both arms will receive misoprostol antibiotic prophylaxis to dilate the cervix before surgery and anti-adhesion barrier gels will be used, according to routine procedures at each center.

Primary Outcome Measure: Uterine vacuity rate at 6 weeks after surgery, determined by endovaginal pelvic ultrasound.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Complication rates, rate of second-line surgical management, synechia rates, mean time to conception, and pregnancy rates at 6, 12, and 24 months after surgery.

Follow-up: Patients will be followed until a pregnancy is obtained with a term greater than or equal to 24 weeks of amenorrhea or over a maximum period of 26 months after the surgery.

* Immunogenicity (Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADA) and neutralizing antibody (Nad))

**Title:** Assess the Safety and Efficacy of Sovateltide in Patients With Acute Cerebral Ischemic Stroke

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of sovateltide, a highly selective ETB receptor agonist, in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke (ACIS).

**Population:** Adult males and females aged 18-80 years with acute ischemic stroke, confirmed by computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), and a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score of ≥ 8 and < 20.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Include excellent outcome (mRS score of 0-1), improvement in functional outcome (NIHSS, mRS, and Barthel Index [BI] scores), quality of life (EuroQol-EQ-5D and Stroke-Specific Quality of Life [SSQOL] scores), incidence of recurrent cerebral ischemic stroke, mortality, radiographic or symptomatic intracerebral hemorrhage, and adverse events.

Title: Methotrexate for Immune Related Arthritis or Arthralgias (IMPACT 2.1)

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in patients with immune-related arthritis or arthralgias (irAA) who have developed recurrent grade ≥ 2 irAA or remain on glucocorticoids for irAA at 3 months.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with a history of cancer receiving anti-PD1 or anti-PDL1 monoclonal antibody ICI therapy who develop CTCAEv5.0 grade ≥2 arthritis or arthralgia that is felt to be treatment-related (irAA). Patients must be ≥ 18 years old, have adequate hematologic and renal function, and be capable of providing consent.

Intervention: Methotrexate 20 mg PO weekly for 12 weeks, with folic acid 1mg PO daily for as long as methotrexate is given. Prednisone starting at 20 mg PO daily for 8 weeks, tapering dose.

Primary Outcome Measure: Proportion of patients who are able to discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without recurrence of grade 2 or higher irAA.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Total steroid usage, development of immune-related adverse events (irAEs) other than irAA, adverse events, re-initiation of immune checkpoint inhibitor therapy, and progression-free survival.

Study Duration: 12 weeks, with a total study observation period of 3 years.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

**Title:** Comparison of the Effects of General and Regional Anesthesia on Sleep Quality in Patients Planning Total Hip Arthroplasty

**Objective:** To evaluate the effects of general anesthesia (GA) and regional anesthesia (RA) on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty (THA).

**Methodology:** This randomized, parallel-group study will enroll 60 patients undergoing elective THA. Patients will be randomly assigned to either a GA group or an RA group. Sleep quality will be assessed using the Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale (PIRS-20) at three time points: one month before surgery, the day before surgery, and one week after surgery. Secondary outcomes include subjective anxiety level (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory) and pain level (Visual Analog Scale).

**Population:** Patients aged 18-85 years with ASA scores I-III, undergoing elective THA.

**Interventions:** Patients in the GA group will receive general anesthesia with propofol and sevoflurane, while patients in the RA group will receive combined spinal-epidural anesthesia or spinal anesthesia with PENG block.

**Primary Outcome:** Subjective sleep quality (PIRS-20 score).

**Secondary Outcomes:** Subjective anxiety level (STAI score) and pain level (VAS score).

**Duration:** The study will be conducted over a period of three months, with patients evaluated at three time points: one month before surgery, the day before surgery, and one week after surgery.

Title: Study of Oral Atogepant Tablets to Assess Change in Disease Activity in Adult Japanese Participants With Episodic Migraine

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese participants with episodic migraine.

Design: Phase 2/3, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study with an active treatment extension.

Participants: Adults (18-80 years) with a history of migraine (with or without aura) and 4-14 migraine days per month.

Interventions: Participants will receive either atogepant (dose A, B, or C) or placebo for 12 weeks, followed by re-randomization to atogepant (dose A, B, or C) for an additional 12 weeks.

Primary outcome measure: Change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days.

Secondary outcome measures: Change from baseline in mean monthly headache days, acute medication use days, and migraine-specific quality of life questionnaire scores, as well as percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in migraine days.

Keywords: Migraine, Episodic Migraine, Atogepant.

Title: Evaluating Efgartigimod in Patients With Guillain-Barré Syndrome

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of efgartigimod in patients with Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) compared to intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg), the standard-of-care treatment.

Design: This is a phase 2, randomized, double-blind, controlled, single-site trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either efgartigimod or IVIg.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with a diagnosis of GBS, aged 18 years or older, with a GBS Disability Scale (GBS-DS) score of 3, 4, or 5, and onset of GBS-related weakness within 14 days prior to infusion.

Exclusion Criteria: Pregnant or lactating women, patients with a history of malignancy, patients with severe bacterial, viral, or fungal infections, and patients with a GBS-DS score of 2 or less.

Interventions: Participants will receive either 20mg/kg of intravenous efgartigimod on days 1 and 5, with normal saline administered as placebo on days 2-4, or 0.4g/kg of IVIg daily for 5 days.

Primary Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measures are the GBS-DS score at 12 weeks and the number and seriousness of adverse events through study completion.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The secondary outcome measures include the GBS-DS score at 4, 24, and 48 weeks, Neuropathy Impairment Scale (NIS) score at 4, 24, and 48 weeks, Inflammatory Rasch-Built Overall Disability Scale (I-RODS) score at 4, 24, and 48 weeks, Forced Vital Capacity (FVC), Maximal Inspiratory Pressure (MIP), and Maximal Expiratory Pressure (MEP) at 4, 24, and 48 weeks.

Title: A Study to Understand the Effect and Safety of the Study Medicine PF-07817883 in Adults Who Have Symptoms of COVID-19 But Are Not Hospitalized

Objective: To evaluate the virological response and safety of oral PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adult participants with COVID-19.

Design: This is a Phase 2b, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel-group, dose-ranging study.

Eligibility Criteria: Participants aged 18-64 years with confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, symptoms of COVID-19, and no need for hospitalization.

Interventions: Participants will receive either PF-07817883 at low, medium, or high doses or placebo.

Primary Outcome Measure: Change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Incidence of treatment-related adverse events, serious adverse events, clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, adverse events leading to discontinuations, clinically significant abnormal vital signs, and clinically significant abnormal ECGs.

Duration: The study will last for approximately 33 days.

Title: Evaluation of the Therapeutic Effect of Adding Letrozole to the Protocol of Combined Treatment of Cesarean Scar Pregnancy

Objective: To evaluate the therapeutic effect of adding letrozole to the protocol of combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) using methotrexate (MTX) monotherapy.

Design: Prospective cohort study with two arms: MTX monotherapy and MTX + letrozole add-on.

Eligibility Criteria: Women with CSP confirmed on pelvic ultrasound, increasing B-hCG concentrations, and consent of the Bioethics Committee for termination of CSP.

Interventions:

* MTX monotherapy: Single dose of 100 mg MTX intravenously and 50 mg MTX in intra-amniotic injection (day 0), along with 30 mg potassium chloride in case of positive fetal heartbeat (FH), and subsequent hysteroscopic evacuation of products of conception (POC).
* MTX + letrozole add-on: MTX monotherapy + letrozole 5 mg orally (from day 0) for 10 days.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Blood loss during the procedure expressed as a decrease in hemoglobin concentration
* Blood loss volume during the procedure expressed in volume units
* Conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Effect of treatment on bone marrow function (red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets)
* Effect of treatment on liver function (serum total bilirubin, alanine transaminase, aspartate transaminase, and gamma-glutamyltransferase)
* Effect of treatment on kidney function (urea and creatinine)

The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of adding letrozole to the protocol of combined treatment of CSP using MTX monotherapy.

Title: Blood Salvage From Liver Donors: a Feasibility Pilot Study (BLEED Study)

Objective: To evaluate the feasibility and safety of salvaging red blood cells from liver donors during organ procurement and transfusing them to liver transplant recipients during surgery.

Design: This is a single-group, open-label pilot study conducted at Fondazione Policlinico A. Gemelli IRCCS. Eligible patients are adult liver transplant recipients who receive a liver transplant from deceased donors with identical ABO blood groups.

Intervention: A 3-step procedure is performed to recover, process, and transfuse donor blood to recipients during surgery.

Primary Outcome Measure: The number and percentage of liver transplant recipients successfully transplanted with internal donors who receive donor RBC concentrates for intraoperative transfusion support.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Blood product need in enrolled patients, rate of graft failure in the prospective sample, and comparison to a control-matched series of liver transplant patients.

The study aims to assess the feasibility and safety of using salvaged donor blood for transfusion during liver transplant surgery, with the potential to reduce the need for allogenic blood products.

Title: Assessing the Optimal Amount of Tissue Sampling in Contrast-Enhanced Stereotactic Biopsy (CESB)

Objective: To determine the minimum number of CESB-guided tissue samples needed to establish a final histopathological biopsy diagnosis for "recombined-only lesions" (ROLs) in women with breast cancer.

Design: Prospective, single-center, observational cohort study.

Population: Non-pregnant women aged 18 years or older with a ROL recently observed during a regular Contrast-Enhanced Mammography (CEM) examination.

Intervention: CESB, consisting of an intravenous injection of iodinated contrast agent followed by stereotactic localization and vacuum-assisted biopsy (VAB) of the ROL.

Primary Outcome Measure: The minimum amount of tissue samples needed for CESB to establish a reliable diagnosis.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Complication rate, diagnostic results, patient comfort, and pain associated with the procedure.

The study aims to answer the question of how many tissue samples are required to reach a final diagnosis using CESB, and to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the procedure.

Title: Comparison of Quadriceps Strengthening and Kinesiotaping on Gait in Knee Osteoarthritis

Objective: To compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening and quadriceps facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in patients with knee osteoarthritis.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with 2 arms: concentric muscle training (group A) and quadriceps facilitatory kinesiotaping (group B).

Participants: Adults aged 50-60 years with knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren and Lawrence OA grade 2 or 3) and knee pain due to tibiofemoral knee osteoarthritis.

Interventions:

* Group A: Concentric muscle training with exercises such as leg press, knee flexion, knee extension, and Quad drills performed 2 times a week for 6 weeks.
* Group B: Quadriceps facilitatory kinesiotaping applied on the anterior thigh region with 20% tension of the tape.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcome: Temporo-spatial gait parameters (gait velocity, cadence, step length, step width, and single support time) measured at 6 weeks.
* Secondary outcomes: Numeric Pain Rating Score (NPRS), Functional Status (WOMAC Questionnaire), and Strength (measured using a handheld dynamometer) at 6 weeks.

This study aims to investigate the effects of two different interventions on gait parameters in patients with knee osteoarthritis, with the primary outcome being temporo-spatial gait parameters.

Title: Hysteroscopic Septoplasty by Different Modalities: A Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective: To compare the effectiveness and safety of hysteroscopic septoplasty using scissors versus resectoscope in women with a septate uterus and a history of recurrent pregnancy loss or subfertility.

Design: Prospective, randomized, controlled trial with 20 patients in each group.

Interventions:

* Need for second intervention

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Live birth rate

**Title:** Boosting Psychotherapy Effects by Means of Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a multimodal intervention combining Transcranial Direct Current Stimulation (tDCS) with metacognitive therapy (MCT) for treating unipolar depression.

Objective: To investigate the effectiveness and safety of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) use in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD) who underwent percutaneous coronary angioplasty (PCI) and are at moderate risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.

Title: Dry Needling vs Lasertherapy in Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome (GTPS): Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective: To compare the effectiveness of dry needling and lasertherapy in reducing pain and improving function in patients with Greater Trochanteric Pain Syndrome (GTPS).

Study Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial with a longitudinal design.

Participants: 35-60 years old females with lateral hip pain (VAS 3) for at least 3 months, referring pain to palpation of the insertion of the tendon of the middle and maximum gluteus in the major trochanter.

Interventions: 6 weeks of treatment, 2 times a week, with either dry needling or lasertherapy.

Primary Outcome Measure: Change in pain intensity using the Visual Analog Pain Scale (VAS).

Secondary Outcome Measures: Change in hip function using the VISA-G questionnaire, change in lower limb function using the Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) and 30'' Sit to Stand Test.

Exclusion Criteria: Surgery on lower limbs or spine in the last 12 months, symptoms of osteoarthritis or intra-articular disease of the hip, infiltration of the hip with corticosteroids in the last 6 months, received physical therapy for this condition in the past three months, and participants who need to use anti-inflammatory drugs.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of dry needling and lasertherapy in reducing pain and improving function in patients with GTPS, and to compare the two interventions.

The RAPID AFib Pilot Trial is a prospective, randomized pilot study evaluating the acceptability and impact of a web-based patient decision aid on shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with recent onset atrial fibrillation (AF). The decision aid, called Risk Assessment and Personal preferences to Improve Decisions for Atrial Fibrillation (RAPID AFib), estimates an individual's risk for stroke and bleeding, allows patients to interactively compare oral anticoagulant therapies, and summarizes the risk information and selected therapy for discussion with their physician. Title: Evaluation of Efficiency of High Flow Nasal Cannula Versus Noninvasive Ventilation in Patients With Acute Hypercapnic Respiratory Failure

Objective: To compare the efficiency of High Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) versus Noninvasive Ventilation (NIV) in patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure.

Study Design: Randomized controlled trial in which 50 patients were assigned to each group: Group A (HFNC) and Group B (NIV).

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure, defined by pH >7.25 and <7.35 and PCO2 >45mmHg, admitted to ICU and received HFNC or NIV.

Exclusion Criteria: Patients <18 years old, altered consciousness, hemodynamic instability, need for immediate endotracheal intubation, contraindication to NIV, post-cardiac arrest patients.

Interventions:

* Group A (HFNC): High-flow oxygen therapy using Airvo 2 device or Precision flow Hi - VNI ™ (Vapotherm ) or built-in HFNC mode in e Volution ventilator, with initial flow rate 40 liter/minute and temperature set to 37°C.
* Group B (NIV): Noninvasive ventilation using Puritan Bennett™ 840 Ventilator and oro-nasal mask, with pressure-support level adjusted to obtain tidal volume of 6-8 ml/kg and FiO2 adjusted to maintain SpO2 of 88-92%.

Primary Outcome Measure: Failure of treatment modality, defined as failure to improve pH within 1 hour.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Mortality, ICU stay, and other related outcomes.

Keywords: HFNC, NIV, type 2 RF.

**Title:** ImpleMEntation of a Digital-first Care deLiverY Model for Heart Failure in Uganda

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a digital-first care delivery model for heart failure patients in Uganda, focusing on improving self-care, clinical outcomes, and cost-effectiveness.

**Design:** A mixed-methods, randomized controlled trial with a Learn-As-You-Go design, involving 18 months of implementation and 18 months of follow-up.

**Population:** Adults with heart failure (NYHA Class II-III) in Uganda, aged 18 years or older, with access to a mobile phone and basic reading skills.

**Interventions:** Two arms:

1. Core HF intervention: Enhanced clinical care bundle, including a care protocol, self-care training, and medication stock management.
2. Core HF + Medly Uganda digital health intervention: Patient-facing mobile health application to improve self-care, with clinician-facing internet dashboard for monitoring and guidance.

**Outcomes:** Primary outcomes include:

* Change in Self-Care of Heart Failure Index (SCHFI)
* Clinical effectiveness (composite of mortality and HF hospitalization)

Secondary outcomes include:

* Participant fidelity to self-care
* Facility fidelity to implementation strategy
* Clinical measures (blood pressure, weight, resting pulse, etc.)
* Quality of life measures (KCCQ, EQ-5D, PHQ-9)

**Duration:** 3 years, with 18 months of implementation and 18 months of follow-up.

**Title:** Comparative Pharmacokinetic (PK) Study of Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Modified-Release Tablets in Healthy Adults Under Fasting Condition

**Objective:** To evaluate the bioequivalence of Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Modified-Release Tablets (400mg/50mg) manufactured by Overseas Pharmaceuticals, Ltd. with Motrin IB (Ibuprofen Tablets USP 200mg) and Benadryl (Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Tablet 25mg) manufactured by Johnson & Johnson Consumer Inc., McNeil Consumer Healthcare Division in healthy adults under fasting condition.

**Design:** Open-label, randomized, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover study in healthy adults aged 18 years or older.

**Interventions:** Participants received either Ibuprofen and Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Modified-Release Tablets (400mg/50mg) or Motrin IB (Ibuprofen Tablets USP 200mg) and Benadryl (Diphenhydramine Hydrochloride Tablet 25mg) under fasting condition.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Area under the curve from time zero to the time of the last quantifiable plasma concentration of the period (AUC0-last), Area under the curve from time zero to infinity (AUC0-inf), and Peak concentration at each treatment period (Cmax,tp).

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Peak concentration of the first dosing (Cmax), Time to reach peak concentration of the first dosing (Tmax), Terminal half-life (T1/2), and Mean residence time (MRT).

**Inclusion Criteria:** Healthy adults aged 18 years or older, with no significant medical history, and able to communicate well with the investigator.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Allergic constitution, history of clinically significant food, drug allergy, or other allergic diseases; or allergic to any component of ibuprofen or diphenhydramine; or history of asthma or other allergic reactions after taking aspirin or other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

**Title:** iSTAR: Phase 1b Trial of Idasanutlin and Selinexor Therapy for Children with Progressive/Relapsed Atypical Teratoid Rhabdoid Tumors, Extra-CNS Malignant Rhabdoid Tumors, or Synchronous/Metachronous Rhabdoid Tumors

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the combination therapy of idasanutlin and selinexor in children with progressive or relapsed atypical teratoid rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT), malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT), or synchronous/metachronous AT/RT and MRT.

**Design:** Open-label, non-randomized, phase 1b trial with a dose-finding/safety phase and an expansion phase.

**Population:** Children with progressive or relapsed AT/RT, MRT, or synchronous/metachronous AT/RT and MRT, aged 6 months to 25 years.

**Interventions:** Patients will receive idasanutlin and selinexor in combination, with idasanutlin dosed once daily on Days 1-5 of a 28-day cycle and selinexor dosed on Day 4 of each of the first 3 weeks of a 28-day cycle.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of combination treatment, idasanutlin plasma apparent systemic clearance (CL/F), and idasanutlin area under the plasma concentration time curve (AUC).

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Objective response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival.

**Duration:** Approximately 2 years from start of treatment.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with progressive or relapsed AT/RT, MRT, or synchronous/metachronous AT/RT and MRT, with measurable disease, adequate performance status, and adequate organ function.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with significant nausea and vomiting, chronic diarrhea, malabsorption, or other medical conditions that may impact the safety and efficacy of the study treatment.

**Title:** Multimodal Prehabilitation in Localized Pancreatic Cancer Patients Undergoing Surgery: a Randomized Controlled Trial

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program (including physical exercise, nutritional therapy, and anxiety-reducing techniques) in improving functional capacity, nutritional status, and patient-reported health-related quality of life in patients with localized pancreatic cancer undergoing surgery.

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with 226 patients (113 in each arm) who will be randomly assigned to either the multimodal prehabilitation group or the usual care group.

**Intervention:** The multimodal prehabilitation group will receive a 4-week preoperative intervention including exercise training, nutritional therapy, and anxiety-reducing techniques, aimed at preventing or attenuating surgery-driven functional decline.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Comprehensive Complication Index (CCI), functional capacity, and pro-inflammatory cytokines.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Time to patient functional recovery, length of stay, bioimpedance analysis-derived body composition, computed tomography-derived body composition, generic health-related quality of life, and disease-specific health-related quality of life.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with localized pancreatic cancer, aged 18 years or older, who are candidates for curative resection and have signed informed consent.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with metastatic or unresectable disease, comorbidities contraindicating prehabilitation, pregnancy, illiteracy, or ASA score 4-5.

The "Active Surveillance of Influenza Virus Zoonotic Transmission Events: a Pilot Study in Belgium" aims to monitor zoonotic transmission of influenza viruses from animals to humans in Belgium. The study involves four sentinel networks: avian influenza outbreak farms, poultry farm workers, wild bird/life rehabilitation center workers, and pig industry veterinarians. Participants will be asked to perform self-sampling with nasopharyngeal swabs every 2 days (for outbreak participants) or every 2 weeks (for sentinel network participants) for a maximum of 2 weeks or the duration of the study. Blood samples will also be collected to detect seroconversion against non-seasonal influenza viruses. The primary outcome measures include the number of participants positive for non-seasonal influenza viruses, while secondary outcome measures include seroconversion rates. The study aims to detect and characterize non-influenza viruses and assess the transmission of influenza viruses from animals to humans in Belgium.

The study aims to assess the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and required capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program in Bangladesh. The study will enroll high-risk groups, including children aged 6-8 years, pregnant women, elderly individuals, and adults with chronic diseases, from nine tertiary-level hospitals across Bangladesh. The study will collect data on the health beliefs, barriers, and intentions of participants to receive the influenza vaccine, as well as the costs associated with influenza illness and vaccination. The study will also estimate the required capacity of the hospital-based influenza vaccination program.

The study will have two arms: an intervention arm where participants will receive the influenza vaccine, and a control arm where participants will not receive the vaccine. The primary outcome measures will include influenza vaccine acceptability and incremental cost-effectiveness ratios (ICERs). Secondary outcome measures will include perceived susceptibility and severity, perceived barriers and benefits, required capacity related to vaccine doses, self-injection equipment, and storage capacity.

The study will use a quasi-experimental design, with data collection taking place over a period of one year. The study will also conduct a cost-effectiveness analysis using the CETSIV tool and a probabilistic sensitivity analysis to estimate the uncertainty of the results. The study will provide valuable insights into the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and required capacity of a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program in Bangladesh, which can inform policy decisions and improve public health outcomes.

**Study Title:** A Phase 4 Multicenter, Randomized, Double-Blind Study of Risankizumab for the Treatment of Adult Subjects With Moderate to Severe Genital Psoriasis or Moderate to Severe Scalp Psoriasis.

**Objective:** To assess the safety and efficacy of subcutaneously injected risankizumab in adults with moderate to severe genital or scalp psoriasis.

**Study Design:** Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with a treatment period of 52 weeks and an 8-week follow-up period.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Adults with a clinical diagnosis of chronic plaque psoriasis with or without psoriatic arthritis for at least 6 months, with moderate to severe genital or scalp psoriasis, and inadequate control of psoriasis and/or intolerance to topical treatment, phototherapy, and/or systemic therapy.

**Interventions:** Participants will receive either risankizumab or placebo for risankizumab for 16 weeks, followed by risankizumab for an additional 36 weeks.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The percentage of participants with achievement of static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) of 0 or 1, and the percentage of participants with achievement of Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Additional measures include the percentage of participants with achievement of various clinical and patient-reported outcome measures, such as the Psoriasis Scalp Severity Index (PSSI), Dermatology Life Quality Index (DLQI), and Genital Psoriasis Itch Numerical Rating Scale (NRS).

**Keywords:** Genital Psoriasis, Scalp Psoriasis, Plaque Psoriasis, Psoriasis, ABBV066, Skyrizi, Risankizumab.

Title: A Study to Assess the Adverse Events and Change in Disease Activity of Oral Atogepant Tablets in Pediatric Participants (6-17 Years of Age) With Episodic Migraine

Title: Left Bundle Branch Area Pacing in Heart Failure Patients With Ejection Fraction Below Normal

Objective: To investigate the safety and efficacy of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) in heart failure patients with an ejection fraction below 50%.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the OPTI-DOSE clinical trial:

The OPTI-DOSE study is a randomized pilot trial aimed at investigating the optimal dosing of oral anticancer drugs in older adults (≥65 years) with various types of cancer. The study hypothesis is that a lower starting dose of anticancer tablets can lead to better treatment tolerability in older patients while maintaining treatment benefits.

The trial will enroll 30 patients who will be randomized into two groups: a control group receiving the standard-of-care dose as recommended by the drug label, and an intervention group receiving a lower starting dose with dose escalation every 2 weeks if tolerated. The primary endpoint is the feasibility of investigating whether a lower starting dose with step-up approach leads to a better overall treatment utility compared to standard dosing.

Secondary endpoints include overall treatment utility, progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, safety, hospital care use, and pharmacokinetic parameters. The study will also collect blood samples for pharmacogenomic analysis.

The trial will provide valuable insights into the optimal dosing of oral anticancer drugs in older adults, which can inform the design of larger randomized phase 2 trials.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Overview**

This is a two-stage study to evaluate the efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of levilimab, a monoclonal antibody against interleukin-6 receptor, in healthy subjects and subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis.

**Study Design**

The study consists of two stages: Stage 1 is an open-label, single-center, non-randomized cohort study in healthy subjects, and Stage 2 is a randomized, double-blind, controlled clinical study in subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis.

**Inclusion Criteria**

In Stage 1, subjects must be healthy males aged 18-45 years with no history of rheumatoid arthritis. In Stage 2, subjects must be males or females aged ≥ 18 years with active rheumatoid arthritis that meets the ACR 2010 criteria.

**Primary Outcome Measures**

The primary outcome measures are:

* Safety primary endpoint (Stage 1): to determine the safety profile of levilimab following single subcutaneous or intravenous administration at ascending doses in healthy subjects.
* Low disease activity (Stage 2): proportion of subjects with low activity of rheumatoid arthritis (DAS28-ESR <3.2) at Week 24 of the study in each treatment group.

**Secondary Outcome Measures**

The secondary outcome measures include:

* RA remission (Stage 2): proportion of subjects who achieved RA remission according to DAS28-CRP (<2.6), DAS28-ESR (<2.6), CDAI (≤2.8), SDAI (≤3.3), and ACR/EULAR 2011.
* PK endpoints (Stage 1): various pharmacokinetic parameters, including AUC0-1680, AUC0-∞, Cmax, Cmin, Tmax, Tmin, Vd, T½, Kel, and CL.
* ACR response (Stage 2): proportion of subjects who achieved ACR20, ACR50, and ACR70.
* Low disease activity (Stage 2): proportion of subjects with low rheumatoid arthritis activity according to DAS28-CRP (<3.2), DAS28-ESR (<3.2), CDAI (≤10), SDAI (≤11).
* Changes in RA indexes (Stage 2): change in DAS28-CRP, DAS28-ESR, CDAI, and SDAI from baseline.
* Moderate/good response according to the EULAR criteria (Stage 2): proportion of subjects with moderate and good response according to the EULAR criteria at Week 24 and 52 compared with baseline values.
* Change in the serum C-reactive protein concentration (Stage 2): change in the serum C-reactive protein concentration from baseline.
* Change in ESR (Stage 2): change in ESR from baseline.
* Change in the quality of life measured with SF-36 (Stage 2): change in the quality of life according to the SF-36 questionnaire from baseline.
* Change in the quality of life measured with the EQ-5D-3L (Stage 2): change in the quality of life according to the EQ-5D-3L questionnaire from baseline.
* Change in the Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy - Fatigue (FACIT-F) score (Stage 2): change in the fatigue assessments according to the FACIT-F questionnaire from baseline.
* Change in functional activity (Stage 2): change in the functional activity according to the HAQ-DI questionnaire from baseline.
* X-Ray assessment (Stage 2): radiographic characterization of the affected joints at Week 24: change in mean modified total Sharp/van der Heijde score (mTSS).

**Keywords**

Rheumatoid Arthritis, Levilimab, Ilsira, anti-IL-6R, IL-6 receptor inhibitors.

In Phase 2, participants received placebo supplements, followed by white kidney bean supplements 72 hours later.

Exclusion criteria included a history of diabetes, metabolic syndrome, digestive diseases, endocrine disorders, mental diseases, and other medical conditions that may affect gastrointestinal function or glucose tolerance.

The study aimed to assess the efficacy of white kidney bean supplements on OGTT in healthy adults and provide insights into its potential benefits and risks.

Title: ACT for Healthy Living: a Brief Acceptance and Commitment Therapy Intervention for Women With Obesity

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a brief acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) workshop in promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors and reducing obesity in women with a body mass index (BMI) of 30.0 kg/m2 or higher.

Design: This is a randomized, open-label trial with a parallel assignment design. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group receiving the ACT workshop or a waitlist control group.

Intervention: The ACT workshop is a 4-hour behavioral intervention that teaches acceptance and commitment therapy skills to approach healthy living.

Outcomes: The primary outcome measures include changes in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, valued living, and weight self-stigma at 1 week and 1 month post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in body image, emotional eating, physical activity, diet quality, and body weight.

Eligibility: Women aged 40-70 years with a BMI of 30.0 kg/m2 or higher, who are able to read and understand written and spoken English, and have a primary residence within 50 miles of the University of Alabama at Birmingham campus.

Exclusion criteria include presence of eating disorder symptoms, major mood disorder, recent weight change, recent use of prescription medication for weight loss, and current participation in another weight management program.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the ACT workshop in promoting healthy lifestyle behaviors and reducing obesity in women with obesity.

Title: Clinical Research of Drug Holiday Based on MRD Detection in GIST Patients at High Risk of Recurrence

Objective: To evaluate the value of MRD detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence of high-risk GIST, investigate the effect of drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection on disease recurrence and patient survival, and explore whether it can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations.

Study Design: One-arm prospective observational clinical trial in patients with high-risk GIST who have achieved disease control after 3 years of imatinib adjuvant therapy.

Inclusion Criteria: Patients with high-risk GIST who have undergone surgery, received 3 years of imatinib adjuvant therapy, and have achieved disease control with no gross lesions detected by imaging examination.

Primary Outcome Measures: Progress-free Survival, Drug re-use rate, and Drug retreatment response rate.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Overall Survival, genetic mutation profiling of ctDNA-MRD, and MRD versus imaging examination.

The study aims to investigate the feasibility and efficacy of a drug holiday treatment mode based on MRD detection in high-risk GIST patients and to explore its potential to delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations.

Title: Supporting Physical Literacy at School and Home (SPLASH) Study

Objective: To increase physical activity (PA) among elementary schoolchildren through a multilevel, comprehensive physical literacy (PL)-focused program, and to examine the program's effects on PL and PA among subgroups.

Design: 2-arm, group randomized controlled trial with 400 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools receiving either the Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program or delayed-intervention control.

Intervention: The RNYRR program is a school-based physical education curriculum with a family engagement component, aiming to build competence, confidence, and motivation for physical activity.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcome measures: Baseline and end-point physical activity levels, measured using Actigraph accelerometers.
* Secondary outcome measures: Baseline and end-point fundamental movement skills, assessed using the Physical Literacy Assessment for Youth tool.

Subgroup analyses will examine whether program effects on PL and PA differ by sex or weight status, and whether changes in PL subdomains mediate changes in daily PA volume or moderate-to-vigorous PA.

Title: A Phase III, Randomised, Double-blind, Parallel-group, 76-week, Efficacy and Safety Study of BI 456906 Administered Subcutaneously Compared With Placebo in Patients With Obesity Disease in Japanese

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of BI 456906, a subcutaneously administered investigational medicinal product, in reducing body weight and improving related comorbidities in Japanese patients with obesity disease.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, 76-week study with three arms: BI 456906 3.6 mg, BI 456906 6.0 mg, and placebo.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients aged 18 years or older with a body mass index (BMI) ≥35 kg/m² or ≥27 kg/m² with at least one obesity-related comorbidity, and a history of at least one self-reported unsuccessful dietary effort to lose body weight.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Percentage change in body weight from baseline to Week 76
* Achievement of body weight reduction ≥5%, ≥10%, ≥15%, and ≥20% from baseline to Week 76

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Absolute changes in body weight, BMI, waist circumference, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and various biomarkers, including glycosylated haemoglobin A1c, fasting plasma glucose, insulin, and lipids.

This study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of BI 456906 in reducing body weight and improving related comorbidities in Japanese patients with obesity disease.

**Title:** The Effect of Pituitrin on Postoperative Outcomes in Patients With Pulmonary Hypertension Undergoing Cardiac Surgery: a Randomized Controlled Study

**Objective:** To investigate the impact of pituitrin on the prognosis of patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery, with a focus on reducing postoperative mortality and serious complications.

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment design, comparing pituitrin with normal saline in patients undergoing cardiac surgery with pulmonary hypertension.

**Eligibility:** Patients aged 18-80 years with pulmonary hypertension (mean pulmonary artery pressure ≥ 25mmHg or pulmonary artery systolic pressure ≥ 40mmHg) undergoing elective cardiopulmonary bypass heart surgery.

**Interventions:** Patients received either pituitrin (1ml/6U, diluted with normal saline to 0.5u/ml, and injected by intravenous pump at the rate of 0.04u/(kg·h)) or normal saline at the same dose and speed.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** A composite endpoint of mortality or severe postoperative complications within 30 days after cardiac surgery.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Various outcomes, including postoperative infection, septic shock, duration of mechanical ventilation, postoperative pulmonary complications, and others, within 30 days after cardiac surgery.

**Study Plan:** The study will enroll 120 patients and follow them up for 30 days after cardiac surgery. The primary outcome will be assessed at 30 days, and secondary outcomes will be assessed at various time points during the 30-day follow-up period.

Title: Single Site Feasibility and Safety Study of Home Initiation of Noninvasive Positive Pressure Ventilation in Children With Medical Complexity

Objective: To evaluate the feasibility and safety of initiating noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) at home in children with medical complexity (CMC) using remote telemonitoring, compared to the standard of care, which is in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) laboratory-based initiation.

Methodology: This 12-week, open-label, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial will recruit 20 children aged 5-17 years with CMC who are newly prescribed NiPPV. Participants will be randomized to either the home initiation arm or the standard of care arm. The home initiation arm will involve titrating NiPPV settings during an awake trial, followed by remote telemonitoring and home overnight oximetries at 1, 4, and 12 weeks. The standard of care arm will involve in-hospital PSG initiation and titration.

Primary outcomes: The study will assess the recruitment and retention rate, proportion of eligible patients randomized, and proportion of patients that crossover based on safety criteria.

Secondary outcomes: The study will also assess adherence to NiPPV, quality of life, and caregiver-reported sense of mastery, as well as the difference in expiratory and inspiratory positive airway pressure between home and PSG titration.

This study aims to determine the feasibility and safety of initiating NiPPV at home in children with CMC, and to identify potential benefits and barriers to this approach.

Objective: To evaluate the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of adjunctive, midline prefrontal, lower intensity, shorter session, EEG-enhanced, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS) for chronic trauma and stressor-related disorders (TSRD) in veterans.

Title: Atorvastatin for Preventing Disease Metastasis in Patients With Resected High-Risk Stage IIA Melanoma

Objective: To compare the recurrence-free survival (RFS), distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS), and overall survival (OS) of patients with high-risk stage IIA melanoma treated with atorvastatin versus placebo.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group, placebo-controlled trial.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with histologically confirmed stage IIA cutaneous melanoma, aged 18 years or older, with a DecisionDx Melanoma test result of class 2B, and no prior treatment for melanoma beyond complete surgical resection.

Interventions: Patients are randomized to receive either atorvastatin (Arm II) or placebo (Arm I) orally once daily for up to 5 years, with CT and/or MRI scans performed throughout the study.

Primary Outcome Measure: Recurrence-free survival (RFS) at 5 years.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) and overall survival (OS) at 5 years.

The study aims to assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma and evaluate the safety and efficacy of atorvastatin in preventing disease metastasis in patients with resected high-risk stage IIA melanoma.

Title: Gain and Loss Framed Text Messaging to Reduce Drinking Among Older Adults

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of scalable, tailored text-messaging programs using gain and loss framing to reduce hazardous drinking among older adults (ages 50-85).

Design: Randomized controlled trial with three conditions: Loss-framed messaging, Gain-framed messaging, and Combined (Loss and Gain) messaging. Participants will receive daily text messages for 8 weeks, with assessments at baseline, weeks 4, 8, and 16.

Inclusion criteria: Participants must be fluent in English, aged 50-85, have hazardous drinking habits, and be willing to reduce drinking to non-hazardous levels.

Primary outcome measures: Weekly sum of standard drinks and heavy drinking days.

Secondary outcome measures: Adherence to daily and weekly drinking assessments via text messages, and willingness to continue the program.

This study aims to develop an effective, low-cost, and scalable intervention to reduce hazardous drinking among older adults using text-messaging technology.

Title: Long-term Effect of TMS in Primary Progressive Aphasia

Objective: To investigate the long-term effect of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in patients with primary progressive aphasia (PPA).

Design: Randomized, parallel-group, triple-masked trial with two arms: Active TMS + language therapy and Sham TMS + language therapy.

**Title:** Methylprednisolone in Patients With Cognitive Deficits in Post-COVID-19 Syndrome (PCS)

**Objective:** To investigate the impact of methylprednisolone on cognitive deficits in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS) with suspected autoimmune involvement.

**Design:** Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled trial with two arms: Methylprednisolone and placebo.

**Population:** Adults (18 years or older) with a history of confirmed COVID-19 infection, ongoing symptoms of PCS for at least 3 months, and self-reported cognitive deficits.

**Intervention:** Participants will receive either methylprednisolone (1mg/kg body weight orally once daily for 6 weeks, with dosage reduction after week 4) or placebo (matching tablets) for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open-label methylprednisolone treatment.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Improvement in memory satisfaction as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ) at 8 weeks after first IMP intake.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Long-term improvement in memory satisfaction, improvement in memory ability and strategy, improvement in neurocognitive functions, quality of life, physical and mental fatigue, and mood.

**Duration:** 52 weeks, with follow-up assessments at weeks 8, 20, and 52.

**Importance:** This study aims to benefit individuals with PCS by exploring the effects of methylprednisolone on cognitive impairment and fatigue, and may provide insights into the pathophysiological processes of PCS, leading to the development of more effective therapies and improved patient outcomes.

Title: A Phase II/III Study to Evaluate the Immunogenicity and Safety and Efficacy of SWIM816 Vaccines for SARS-CoV-2

Objective: To evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of SWIM816 vaccines in previously vaccinated subjects against COVID-19.

Design: A randomized, double-blinded, parallel controlled trial with two phases: Phase II (n=200) and Phase III (n=600).

Interventions:

* Phase II: SWIM816 (25 μg) or SW-BIC-213 (25 μg)
* Phase III: SWIM816 (25 μg) or Pfizer Bivalent vaccine (30 μg)

Endpoints:

* Immunogenicity: GMTs of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron and related strain neutralizing antibody levels, geometric mean ratio (GMR) of SARS-CoV-2 Omicron-neutralizing antibody levels, and seroresponse rate
* Safety: Occurrence of local and systemic adverse events, unsolicited adverse events, and frequency, severity, and relatedness of adverse events
* Efficacy: Occurrence of confirmed symptomatic cases, severity of confirmed cases, and number of IFN-γ positive and IL-4 positive T cell subsets

Inclusion criteria:

* Male or female aged ≥18 years old
* Previously vaccinated with 2/3 doses of COVID-19 vaccine
* Interval between last dose and study vaccination: 6-24 months
* Healthy participants or participants with pre-existing medical conditions in stable condition

Exclusion criteria:

* Presence of fever within 3 days before study vaccination
* History of infection or disease related to severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), Middle East respiratory syndrome (MERS), or other disease corresponding use of immunosuppressants
* History of allergic reactions to any vaccine or drug
* Medical or family history of seizure, epilepsy, encephalopathy, and psychosis
* Immunocompromised patients
* Presence of severe or uncontrollable cardiovascular diseases, or severe or uncontrollable disorders related to endocrine system, blood and lymphatic system, liver and kidney, respiratory system, metabolic and skeletal systems, or malignancies

The study aims to evaluate the immunogenicity, safety, and efficacy of SWIM816 vaccines in previously vaccinated subjects against COVID-19, comparing it to Pfizer Bivalent vaccine in Phase III.

**Title:** A Phase I Safety and Feasibility Study of Cellular Immunotherapy for Extensive Stage Small Cell Neuroendocrine Prostate Cancer Using Autologous T Cells Lentivirally Transduced to Express L1CAM-Specific Chimeric Antigen Receptors.

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and feasibility of autologous T cells lentivirally transduced to express L1CAM-specific chimeric antigen receptors (CARs) in patients with locally advanced and unresectable or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer.

**Design:** This is a single-arm, open-label, dose-escalation study. Patients will undergo leukapheresis to obtain peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMCs) for T cell product manufacturing, followed by lymphodepleting chemotherapy and infusion of autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells. Patients will be followed up for 12 months after the last infusion.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients must be ≥ 18 years old, have a confirmed diagnosis of small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer, and have received a platinum-based chemotherapy regimen. Exclusion criteria include active autoimmune diseases, active hepatitis B or C, and certain cardiac conditions.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The incidence of adverse events and dose-limiting toxicity rates will be evaluated. Secondary outcome measures include objective response, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.

**Study Plan:** The study will enroll patients in a single arm, and patients will receive autologous L1CAM-specific CAR+EGFRt+ T cells infusion on day 0. Patients may receive additional lymphodepletion chemotherapy and T cell infusion as needed. Patients will undergo various assessments, including echocardiography, computed tomography, bone scan, and blood sample collection.

The study includes 12-18 year old male and female participants who are English-speaking and able to understand and respond to questionnaires. Exclusion criteria include pregnancy, breastfeeding, substance abuse, chronic medical conditions, and a history of head injury or neurological disorder.

The study is designed as a single-group, open-label trial, where participants will receive a 5mg melatonin gummy 30 minutes before bedtime for two consecutive nights. The primary outcome measure is the change in sleep spindle density during non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep between baseline and melatonin nights, as measured by a portable EEG device. Secondary outcome measures include changes in sleep quality between baseline and melatonin nights.

The study aims to explore the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with ASD, which may provide insights into the potential therapeutic benefits of melatonin for this population.

The DETERMINE Trial Treatment Arm 04 is a phase II, open-label, non-randomized study evaluating the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab in combination with pertuzumab in adult, teenage/young adult, and pediatric patients with rare cancers that have HER2 amplification or activating mutations. The study aims to translate positive clinical findings to the NHS (Cancer Drugs Fund) to provide new treatment options for rare adult, pediatric, and teenage/young adult cancers.

The study will enroll up to 30 evaluable patients and will assess the primary outcome measures of objective response (OR) and durable clinical benefit (DCB). Secondary outcome measures include duration of response, best percentage change in sum of target lesion diameters, time to treatment discontinuation, progression-free survival time, time to progression, growth modulation index, overall survival time, and occurrence of suspected unexpected serious adverse events.

Eligible patients must have a confirmed diagnosis of a malignancy with HER2 amplification or activating mutations, be at least 12 years old, and have adequate organ function. Patients with a history of breast cancer, brain metastases, or certain cardiac conditions are excluded from the study.

The study will be conducted in multiple centers in the UK and will follow patients for up to 2 years after treatment completion. The study is expected to provide valuable insights into the efficacy and safety of trastuzumab in combination with pertuzumab in patients with rare cancers.

Title: Etiological Study of Persistent Velopharyngeal Insufficiency in Children With Operated Velopalatine Cleft by Analysis of Velopharyngeal Motor Skills in Static and Dynamic MRI

The study will analyze velopharyngeal motor skills in children aged 7-12 years with isolated cleft lip and palate who have undergone surgery at the Amiens University Hospital. The study will use real-time MRI to assess velopharyngeal function, specifically the ratio between the diameter of the pharynx at rest and during phonation, closure distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall, and distance between the velar knee and the posterior pharyngeal wall. The pilot study aims to evaluate the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration membrane in critically ill patients with vasoplegic shock. The study involves measuring the clearance of vasoactive metabolites using blood purification with the oXiris membrane and analyzing the concentrations of angiotensins, regulatory enzymes, and endothelial permeability markers. Title: Lateral Versus Central Urinary Bladder Dissection During Total Laparoscopic Hysterectomy in Cases With Previous Cesarean Section: A Randomized Controlled Study

Objective: To compare the efficacy and safety of lateral versus central urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in patients with previous cesarean section.

Methodology: This randomized controlled trial enrolled patients undergoing total laparoscopic hysterectomy for benign conditions with a previous cesarean section scar. Patients were randomly assigned to either the central or lateral urinary bladder dissection group. The primary outcome measure was the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection. Secondary outcome measures included operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications.

Interventions:

* Central urinary bladder dissection: A metal catheter was inserted in the bladder, and the bladder was dissected with monopolar scissors while the catheter was in place.
* Lateral urinary bladder dissection: The broad ligament was dissected down to the uterine bundle, and the space was dissected above the vessels to reach the lateral margins of the cervix.

Conclusion: This study aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of lateral versus central urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in patients with previous cesarean section. The primary outcome measure was the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection, and secondary outcome measures included operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications.

Title: Improving Alcohol and Substance Use Care Access, Outcome, Equity During the Reproductive Years

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) program in improving alcohol and substance use care access, outcomes, and equity among reproductive-aged women. The program will be implemented in family planning clinics, which are trusted care sources for women and a safety net for socially disadvantaged groups.

The study will involve a Type 1 Hybrid Effectiveness-Implementation Trial, where 400 women will be randomly assigned to either the SBIRT group or the usual care group. The SBIRT group will receive a brief motivational interviewing-based intervention, while the usual care group will receive standard care. The primary outcomes will be changes in alcohol and substance use behaviors, depression, anxiety, and quality of life.

The study will also assess the fidelity of the SBIRT program, provider knowledge and skills, and patient satisfaction. The results will inform the development of an evidence-based, innovative, and stakeholder-driven FP SBIRT model that can be scaled up nationally to promote women's health equity.

The study's population will consist of reproductive-aged women (18-45 years) who are at risk of alcohol and substance use disorders and are seeking care at family planning clinics. The study will be conducted over a 12-month period, with data collection at baseline, 30 days, and 3 months.

**Title:** TeTrimTeas: Gut Microbiome and Blood Lipid Markers After Habitual Herbal Tea Consumption

**Objective:** To investigate the effects of habitual consumption of three herbal tea blends (green tea, senna herbal mix, and rhubarb root herbal mix) on gut microbiome, blood lipid markers, and dietary habits in healthy adults.

**Design:** Randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study with three intervention arms: green tea, senna herbal mix, and rhubarb root herbal mix.

**Participants:** Healthy adults aged 18 and above who are willing to consume the herbal teas as part of their daily routine for 21 days.

**Interventions:** Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three intervention arms and will receive a specific herbal tea blend to consume daily for 21 days.

**Outcomes:** Primary outcomes include changes in total plasma cholesterol, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C), high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), and triglycerides. Secondary outcomes include changes in plasma non-HDL-C, diet quality scores, and body mass index (BMI).

**Methods:** Participants will undergo a 2-day diet monitoring period before the study, followed by a 21-day experimental period during which they will consume the assigned herbal tea blend daily. Blood samples and stool samples will be collected at baseline and after the experimental period to assess changes in lipid profiles and gut microbiome. Diet quality scores will be assessed using the Prime Diet Quality Score (PDQS).

**Expected outcomes:** The study aims to investigate the effects of habitual consumption of herbal tea blends on lipid profiles, gut microbiome, and dietary habits in healthy adults. The results may provide insights into the potential health benefits of these herbal tea blends and inform future studies on their use as a therapeutic approach for cardiovascular health.

Title: Effect Of Strengthening Hip Rotators And Ankle Muscles On Knee Osteoarthritis

Objective: To investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, strength of muscles, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with two groups: Experimental group receiving strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles, and Control group receiving quadriceps strengthening and hamstring and calf stretching exercises.

Population: Adult males and females aged 40-55 years with chronic knee osteoarthritis, referred from orthopedic surgeons.

Interventions: Experimental group: Strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles, in addition to quadriceps strengthening and hamstring and calf stretching exercises. Control group: Quadriceps strengthening and hamstring and calf stretching exercises only.

Outcome measures: Primary outcomes include pain level (assessed by visual analogue scale), functional level (assessed by Knee injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score), and knee proprioception (assessed by joint position sense). Secondary outcomes include hip and ankle strength (assessed by handheld dynamometer).

Duration: 4 weeks, with 12 sessions of exercises, 3 times a week.

This natural experiment study aims to investigate the effects of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. Patients who are receiving care from the Division of Oncology at the primary Siteman Cancer Center site and reside within the catchment area of a Siteman Cancer Center satellite site are eligible to participate. The study compares two groups: one where care is transitioned to a satellite site and another where care remains at the primary site.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of eligible participants who successfully transfer to a provider at a satellite location. Secondary outcome measures include types of candidacy for transfer, treatment burden, participant satisfaction with provider interactions, financial toxicity, and participant rationales for opting to transfer or maintain care at their usual site.

The study will collect data on these outcomes at baseline and approximately 6 months later. The study aims to explore the effects of providing cancer care closer to home on patient outcomes and experiences, with a focus on reducing travel burden and improving patient satisfaction.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of virtual reality (VR) goggles to nitrous oxide (N2O) as a method of distraction for pediatric patients undergoing dental procedures. The study aims to determine if VR goggles can reduce pain and anxiety in children undergoing dental treatment, potentially providing an alternative to N2O. 

The study will recruit pediatric patients aged 4-12 years who require two restorative dental procedures and have a Frankl 2-3 behavior score, indicating they require behavior guidance during the procedure. Patients will be randomized into one of two groups: a control group that will receive standard care with N2O, and a treatment group that will receive VR goggles. Both groups will undergo two dental appointments, with the second appointment using the alternative treatment. 

The primary outcome measures include the rate of effectiveness of VR goggles in reducing pain, as measured by the Faces, Legs, Arms, Crying Consolability (FLACC) scale and the WongBaker FACES Pain Scale. Secondary outcome measures include the rate of effectiveness of VR distraction compared to N2O, as measured by the Houpt Behavioral Scale. The study will assess behavioral scores, pain levels, and patient satisfaction during and after the procedure.
