The study aims to develop a new method to identify patients with a high risk of recurrent colorectal lesions and personalize their surveillance based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype. The study will recruit 200 patients with a colorectal polyp larger than 10mm removed by colonoscopy and evaluate the mutation profile of their index and synchronous lesions. During a five-year surveillance period, patients will undergo regular colonoscopies, and the study will assess the correlation between clinical and histopathological parameters and mutational phenotype. The study will also compare the mutation profile of lesions from the index period with those from the metachronous lesions and analyze the similarity of mutation profiles of lesions found in the same or close areas of the colorectum. The primary outcome measure is the development and clinical utility of a new method to identify patients with a high risk of recurrent colorectal lesions and personalize their surveillance.

* Untargeted microRNA expression profiles in saliva samples
* Salivary extracellular vesicle analysis
* Metagenomic analysis of salivary samples

**Title:** Implementation of Exercise Strategies in Parkinson's Disease: Clinical Outcomes

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of different exercise strategies in people with Parkinson's disease, including standard care, written exercise guidance, and consultative physical therapy, on physical activity and exercise participation over 12 months.

**Design:** A non-randomized, sequential assignment study with three treatment groups: standard care, written exercise guidance, and consultative physical therapy.

**Methods:** Participants with Parkinson's disease will be recruited from two clinics in the Chicagoland area and will wear a research-grade physical activity monitor and a commercially available activity tracker. They will also complete online surveys and wear a research-grade physical activity monitor for 7 consecutive days at baseline, 3, 6, 9, and 12 months.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Minutes per day of moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) measured every 3 months throughout the 12-month study period.

**Secondary Outcome Measure:** Steps per day measured every 3 months throughout the 12-month study period.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Participants must have a neurologist-confirmed diagnosis of Parkinson's disease, be aged 18-89 years old, ambulatory, and have written and verbal basic English proficiency. Exclusion criteria include diagnosis of dementia or mild cognitive impairment, use of a rollator or rolling walker for mobility, and comorbidities significantly limiting ability to participate in exercise.

The study will monitor cerebral oxygenation and autoregulation in multiple brain regions using a full-head coverage tr-fNIRS device. The primary outcome measures include the impact of intraoperative hemodynamic parameters on regional differences in cerebral oxygenation and regional differences in cerebral autoregulation. The Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT) is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study evaluating the efficacy and safety of enavogliflozin, a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, in patients with heart failure (HF) and functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF).

The study aims to assess the effects of enavogliflozin on clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in patients with HF and functional TR, compared to placebo. The primary outcome measure is a composite of cardiovascular death, hospitalization for HF, or worsening of TR.

The study will enroll approximately 1,500 patients aged 20-80 years with functional TR and HF with preserved LVEF. The trial will assess the safety and efficacy of enavogliflozin in this patient population and provide insights into its potential benefits in reducing cardiovascular events and improving clinical outcomes.

The "Promoting Recovery Outcomes Through Precise Early Locomotor Interventions in Persons With Spinal Cord Injury" trial investigates the optimal timing of locomotor training after incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI). The study aims to determine whether early, sub-acute, or chronic body weight supported treadmill training (BWSTT) improves recovery outcomes compared to standard of care.

The trial includes 160 participants with acute and traumatic SCI between C5 and T12 levels, aged 16-74. The study aims to identify the critical time window for rehabilitation after incomplete SCI and determine the most effective timing for locomotor training to promote optimal recovery outcomes.

**Title:** A Phase 1, Open-Label Study Evaluating the Pharmacokinetics, Safety, and Tolerability of ARV-471 in Chinese Participants with ER+/HER2- Advanced Breast Cancer

**Objective:** To evaluate the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of ARV-471, a study medicine, in Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer.

**Design:** This is a single-arm, open-label study with a single group of participants receiving ARV-471 as a single agent.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Participants must have a histological or cytological diagnosis of breast cancer with evidence of ER+/HER2- locally advanced or metastatic disease, have received at least one line of standard of care endocrine therapy, and have up to two prior regimens of chemotherapy for advanced or metastatic disease.

**Intervention:** Participants will receive ARV-471 orally once daily with food for 28-day cycles.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** The study will assess the pharmacokinetics of ARV-471, including maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the concentration-time curve (AUC), and terminal half-life.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also evaluate the safety and tolerability of ARV-471, including adverse events, laboratory abnormalities, vital sign changes, and electrocardiogram (ECG) values.

**Duration:** The study will enroll participants for up to 100 weeks, with assessments every 4 weeks during the first 24 weeks and every 12 weeks thereafter.

**Location:** The study will be conducted in China.

**Population:** The study will enroll Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer.

**Study Overview**: The study is a phase II trial evaluating the combination of olaparib and alpelisib in patients with metastatic HER2-negative breast cancer. The study aims to determine the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy compared to olaparib alone.

**Objectives**: The primary objectives are to determine the progression-free survival (PFS) and objective response rate (ORR) of the combination therapy in patients with PARP-inhibitor naive metastatic HER2-negative breast cancer. The secondary objectives include assessing the ORR, overall survival (OS), clinical benefit rate (CBR), and tolerability of the combination therapy.

**Design**: The study is a randomized, open-label trial with three cohorts: Cohort 1 (PARP-inhibitor naive patients), Cohort 2 (PARP-inhibitor naive patients randomized to receive either combination therapy or olaparib alone), and Cohort 3 (PARP-inhibitor resistant patients).

**Interventions**: Patients in Cohort 1 will receive combination therapy with olaparib and alpelisib. Patients in Cohort 2 will be randomized to receive either combination therapy or olaparib alone. Patients in Cohort 3 will receive combination therapy with olaparib and alpelisib.

**Outcome Measures**: The primary outcome measures are PFS and ORR in Cohort 2. Secondary outcome measures include ORR, PFS, OS, CBR, and incidence of adverse events in all cohorts.

**Inclusion Criteria**: Patients must have metastatic HER2-negative breast cancer, be at least 18 years old, and have an ECOG performance status of 0-2. Patients must also have a minimum of one measurable lesion and have not received prior PARP-inhibitor therapy.

**Exclusion Criteria**: Patients with a history of brain metastases, active hepatitis, or HIV with detectable viral load are excluded. Patients with a history of chronic concomitant treatment with strong inhibitors of CYP3A4 or moderate CYP3A inducers are also excluded.

**Objective:** To investigate the effectiveness of schema therapy (ST) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) in patients with chronic treatment-resistant depression (CTRD) on depression outcomes at 12 months after baseline.

**Design:** Multi-center, two-arm, parallel group, assessor-blinded, randomized controlled superiority study.

**Participants:** Patients with chronic or treatment-resistant depression, aged 18-65, who have been referred to treatment in a psychiatric clinic.

**Interventions:** Schema therapy (ST) and treatment as usual (TAU).

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Change from baseline in depression symptoms on the Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression at 12 months after baseline.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Change from baseline in depression symptoms, functional impairment, psychological well-being, personal recovery, anger processing, repetitive negative thinking, anxiety symptoms, health-related quality of life, and schema modes.

**Duration:** 24 months.

**Sample Size:** 129 participants, randomized 1:1 in each intervention arm.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients with chronic or treatment-resistant depression, aged 18-65, who have been referred to treatment in a psychiatric clinic.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with acute suicidal risk, bipolar or psychotic disorder, alcohol or substance abuse, mental disability, or non-Danish speakers.

**Study Sites:** Four psychiatric out-patient clinics in Denmark.

**Therapist Training:** Schema therapists will be trained in schema therapy and will receive ongoing supervision and evaluation of their competency.

**Data Collection:** Data will be collected via interview and self-report at baseline, 6, 12, and 24 months after baseline.

**Data Analysis:** The primary analysis will be based on the intention-to-treat principle, with conservative imputation of missing outcomes. Secondary analyses will include sensitivity analyses and exploratory analyses.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the FRACT-AI clinical trial:

The FRACT-AI study evaluates the impact of artificial intelligence (AI)-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in detecting fractures on plain X-rays. The study aims to assess the performance of an AI algorithm, Gleamer Boneview, and compare it to the reference standard. The study also investigates the impact of AI assistance on the performance of readers, including emergency medicine doctors, trauma and orthopaedic surgeons, emergency nurse practitioners, physiotherapists, general radiologists, and radiographers.

The study consists of two phases, with 18 readers reviewing 500 X-rays in each phase. In Phase 1, readers review X-rays without AI assistance, and in Phase 2, they review X-rays with AI assistance. The primary outcome measures include the performance of the AI algorithm in terms of sensitivity, specificity, and area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC), as well as the performance of readers with and without AI assistance. The study also assesses reader speed with and without AI assistance.

The study aims to provide insights into the effectiveness of AI-assisted detection of fractures on X-rays and its potential impact on clinical practice.

Title: Uptake of the Childhood Live Attenuated Influenza Vaccine (LAIV) and Influenza-related Healthcare Resource Use in England During the 2012 to 2022 Flu Seasons

Objective: To evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines in children aged 2-17 years in England between 2012 and 2020, and to describe influenza-related healthcare resource use (HCRU) outcomes in vaccinated and unvaccinated children.

Methods: A retrospective, observational study using the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) and Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) databases. The study included children aged 2-17 years with at least 6 months of history in CPRD before their first influenza vaccination.

Primary objective: To evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines, including LAIV, QIV, and unspecified influenza vaccinations.

Secondary objectives:

* To describe HCRU associated with laboratory-confirmed influenza and/or influenza-like illness (ILI) in England between 2012 and 2020
* To describe demographics and clinical characteristics of individuals vaccinated with LAIV or not vaccinated against flu
* To estimate a directed acyclic graph (DAG) aligned model for LAIV uptake in England based on demographic and clinical factors

Outcome measures:

* Uptake of influenza vaccination
* GP consultations for ILI
* Laboratory-confirmed influenza
* Admitted patient care (APC) episodes associated with ILI
* Accident and emergency (A&E) attendances associated with ILI
* Outpatient attendances associated with ILI
* Length of stay in APC for influenza and ILI
* Number of antibiotic prescriptions
* Number of antiviral prescriptions

Title: A Digitally Assisted Risk Reduction Platform for Youth at High Risk for Suicide

Objective: To develop and test a comprehensive digital platform, Vira, to enhance the effectiveness of preventative healthcare for youth at high risk for suicide by integrating mobile sensing data, self-report assessments, and just-in-time nudges and notifications into their management.

Design: A pragmatic randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 200 adolescent patients aged 13-18 years old, randomized to either the Vira group (n=100) or the treatment as usual control group (n=100).

Intervention: The Vira platform uses mobile sensing data and self-report assessments to monitor patients' risk-relevant behavioral patterns and psychological states, and provides just-in-time nudges and notifications to support behavior change plans and DBT treatment.

Primary Outcome Measures: The Columbia Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) and the Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI) will be assessed at 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Additional measures include the Screen for Anxiety Related Emotional Disorders (SCARED), Risky Behavior Questionnaire for Adolescents (RBQ-A), Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI), Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ), and Anticipatory & Consummatory Interpersonal Pleasure Scale (ACIPS), all assessed at 3 and 6 months.

This study aims to test whether using the Vira platform in the context of an intensive outpatient setting improves clinical outcomes for youth at high risk for suicide.

**Title:** Open-label, Single-center, Single-arm Futility Trial Evaluating Daily Remote Ischemic Conditioning for Reducing Progression of Disability in Patients With Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS)

**Objective:** To investigate whether daily remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) can prevent disability worsening in patients with Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis (PPMS) as measured by the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW) test.

**Design:** Phase II, open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial with a Simon-2-stage MiniMax design.

**Intervention:** Participants will receive daily RIC treatment for 12 months using an electric auto-control device with a blood pressure cuff that inflates up to 200 mmHg during the ischemic period. The procedure will be self-administered at home.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Worsening of disability, defined as an increase by 20% or more in the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW) at 12 months follow-up compared to baseline.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Nine Hole Peg Test, MRI measure of remyelination, and Single Digit Modalities Test (SDMT).

**Eligibility Criteria:** Men and women aged 18-65 years with Primary Progressive Multiple Sclerosis, Expanded Disability Status Scale score between 4.0 and 6.5, and timed 25-foot walk (average of two trials) of 5.5 seconds or more. Exclusion criteria include patients with known renal insufficiency, significant hepatic impairment, or allergy to gadolinium MRI contrast agent, among others.

The SMaRT Mom trial is a randomized controlled study investigating the effectiveness of a smartphone management and responsive time (SMaRT) intervention on breastfeeding mothers with smartphone addiction. The study aims to reduce maternal reports of infants' negative emotionality and increase maternal self-efficacy as distal outcomes, as well as breastfeeding as a rewarding experience and maternal attention towards the infant during breastfeeding as proximal outcomes.

The SMaRT Mom intervention involves instructing mothers not to use their smartphones during breastfeeding for one week, with remote support sessions and daily reports of distractions while breastfeeding. The control group will not receive this intervention.

The "Non-invasive Electrophysiological Monitoring in High Risk Pregnancies at the Obstetric High Care" study aims to investigate the effectiveness of continuous non-invasive electrophysiological monitoring using the Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS) in high-risk pregnancies. Title: Bone Marrow Versus Adipose Tissue as a Cell Source for Infiltrative Treatment of Knee Osteoarthritis: Randomized Clinical Trial

Objective: To investigate the effectiveness of bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) and minimally manipulated adipose tissue (MM-AT) as cell sources for infiltrative treatment of knee osteoarthritis.

Design: Randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 204 patients with symptomatic unilateral knee osteoarthritis. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either a single intra-articular injection of BMAC or MM-AT.

Interventions: Patients in the BMAC group will receive a single intra-articular injection of bone marrow aspirate concentrate derived from their own iliac crest, while patients in the MM-AT group will receive a single intra-articular injection of minimally manipulated adipose tissue derived from their own abdominal adipose tissue.

Primary Outcome Measure: The Western Ontario and McMaster University Osteoarthritis index (WOMAC) - Pain subscale, assessed at 6 months follow-up.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Various outcome measures will be assessed at baseline, 2 months, 6 months, and 12 months follow-up, including the WOMAC, Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS), Tegner Activity Level Scale, and others.

Duration: 12 months.

Population: Patients with symptomatic unilateral knee osteoarthritis, aged 40-75 years, who have not responded to at least 4 months of conservative treatment. Exclusion criteria include patients with axial deviations > 5°, patients who have suffered trauma or undergone intra-articular infiltration of other substances in the previous 6 months, and patients with concomitant knee injuries causing joint pain or swelling.

Title: Evaluating Efficacy and Safety of CBD TPM Capsules for Use in Insomnia

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of cannabidiol (CBD) TPM capsules in reducing insomnia severity in adults.

Population: Adults aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of insomnia disorder, as defined by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-5).

Interventions: Participants will receive either a placebo, 75mg CBD, or 150mg CBD capsule nightly before bed.

Primary Outcome Measures:

1. Mean change from study baseline of insomnia severity index (ISI) score at 8 weeks
2. Mean change from study baseline in subject sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks

Study Design: Randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group trial with three arms: placebo, 75mg CBD, and 150mg CBD.

The primary outcome measure is the detection of prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infection in cirrhotic patients and the difference between cirrhotic patients and non-cirrhotic patients with no comorbidity. The REtinal Detachment Outcomes Study (REDOS) is a randomized controlled trial investigating the treatment of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD) with or without scleral buckle (SB) and different gas tamponade agents. The study aims to compare the anatomic and functional outcomes of three treatment arms: pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) gas tamponade, PPV with SB and SF6 gas tamponade, and PPV with perfluoropropane (C3F8) gas tamponade.

The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of rhegmatogenous RRD, excluding those with Proliferative Vitreoretinopathy (PVR) grade ≥C2, chronic RRD, or other specific conditions. The primary outcome measure is single surgery anatomic success, defined as freedom from reoperation for recurrent RRD, with follow-up until the final 1-year visit. Secondary outcomes include pinhole visual acuity, best-corrected visual acuity, time to onset of RD recurrence, severity and number of complications, and quality of life questionnaire assessments at various time points.

The study is designed as a factorial, randomized controlled trial with triple masking, and is expected to provide valuable insights into the optimal treatment approach for rhegmatogenous RRD.

This randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group interventional study aims to evaluate the effects of 0.25%, 0.5%, and 1% ropivacaine on the onset and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients undergoing forefoot surgery for anesthesia and postoperative analgesia. The study hypothesizes that 1% ropivacaine will result in a faster onset time and longer sensory block duration compared to 0.25% and 0.5% ropivacaine. The primary outcome is the difference in sensory block duration, while secondary outcomes include onset time, postoperative pain scores, and opioid consumption. A total of 15 mL of each concentration of ropivacaine will be administered to each participant, and the study will measure the outcomes over a period of 48 hours, 72 hours, and one week.

The primary outcome measures will be the change in RLS Severity Rating Scale score and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index score from baseline to the end of 21 days. **Title:** The Efficacy of Home-based Strength and Tai-chi Exercise Snacking for Improving Physical Function in Taiwanese and British Older Adults: a Randomised Control Trial.

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a home-based exercise program, combining strength and Tai-chi exercises, in improving physical function in older adults.

**Intervention:** The intervention group received a 12-week home-based exercise program, consisting of three progressive phases, with exercises performed at home and recorded in a log book. The program aimed to improve physical function, balance, strength, and flexibility.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Participants must be aged 65 or older, able to perform daily physical activity independently, and not regularly engaging in recreational sports or structured exercise. Exclusion criteria include current musculoskeletal injuries, contraindications to exercise, and certain medical conditions.

This randomized controlled trial aims to evaluate the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on the comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients. Title: P-KIDs CARE: An Intervention to Address Health Systems Delays to Care for Injured Children in Tanzania

Objective: To develop and pilot-test an intervention, P-KIDs CARE, aimed at reducing delays in care for injured children in Tanzania.

Methods:

* Formative research (Aim 1) to inform the development of the P-KIDs CARE intervention, including capacity assessments, in-depth interviews, and focus group discussions with healthcare providers and family members of pediatric injury patients.
* Intervention development (Aim 2) through a 2-day workshop with an interdisciplinary study team and feedback from healthcare providers and a community-engaged panel.
* Pilot-testing (Aim 3) of the P-KIDs CARE intervention in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region, enrolling 200 pediatric injury patients and 10 healthcare providers.

Intervention: The P-KIDs CARE intervention includes two components: the World Health Organization (WHO) Basic Emergency Care Course for training on patient assessment and stabilization, and a decision support tool integrating adaptation of two evidence-based tools for mortality risk assessment and timely referral decisions.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcome: Mortality
* Secondary outcomes: Time from injury to definitive care, patient disposition, and patient morbidity (measured by the Glasgow Outcomes Scale-Extended Pediatrics)

This study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity of the P-KIDs CARE intervention and its potential impact on reducing delays in care for injured children in Tanzania.

Title: Combining Pelvic Floor Rehabilitation With Postural Re-education in Women With Stress Urinary Incontinence and Chronic Low Back Pain: a Preliminary Study.

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education in women with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain.

Methodology: This randomized, triple-blind study enrolled women aged 18-75 years with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. Participants were randomly assigned to one of two groups: pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education or pelvic floor rehabilitation with spinal mobilization. Each group received 10 sessions of treatment over 5 weeks.

Outcome Measures: The primary outcome measure was the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF), which evaluates the frequency, severity, and impact on quality of life of urinary incontinence. Secondary outcome measures included the Pain Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and the Modified Oxford Scale (MOS), which assess pain intensity and pelvic floor muscle strength, respectively.

This study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education or spinal mobilization in improving symptoms of stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain in women.

Title: Development of a Pharmacodynamic Model for Propofol in Older Adults

Objective: To develop a pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic (PKPD) model that uses pharmacokinetic parameters from the Eleveld model and new pharmacodynamic parameters derived from frontal electroencephalography (EEG) in patients older than 65 years to predict the hypnotic effect of propofol.

Design: Single-group, open-label study with 30 patients undergoing non-cardiac elective surgery requiring general anesthesia. Patients will receive an intravenous infusion of propofol with prespecified plasma targets, and registration of BIS values, frontal EEG, and clinical signs of consciousness will be performed.

Primary Outcome Measures: Performance Error (PE) and Median Absolute Performance Error (MDAPE) to evaluate the accuracy of the model.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Median Prediction Error (MDPE), Time of Loss of Response (LOR), Time of Burst-suppression (BS), and Time of Return of Response (ROR) to evaluate the performance of the model.

Population: Patients older than 65 years undergoing non-cardiac elective surgery requiring general anesthesia.

Intervention: Intravenous infusion of propofol with prespecified plasma targets.

This study aims to develop a PKPD model that accurately predicts the hypnotic effect of propofol in older adults, allowing for better titration of the drug and avoiding potential deleterious effects.

Title: Very Short-course Versus Standard Course Antibiotic Therapy in Patients With Acute Cholangitis After Adequate Endoscopic Biliary Drainage

Objective: To compare the effectiveness and safety of a very short-course (1 day) of antibiotics versus a standard course (4-7 days) of antibiotics in patients with acute cholangitis after endoscopic biliary drainage.

Design: Multicenter, open-label, non-inferiority randomized controlled trial.

Eligibility: Patients with acute cholangitis due to common bile duct stones, benign or malignant distal biliary obstruction, or distal biliary stent dysfunction, aged 18 years or older, with adequate biliary drainage, and without fever or signs of infection.

Interventions: Patients will be randomly assigned to either a very short-course group (1 day of antibiotics) or a standard course group (4-7 days of antibiotics).

Primary Outcome Measure: Clinical cure rate by day 14 after ERCP without relapse by day 30.

Secondary Outcome Measures: All-cause 90-day mortality, relapse of cholangitis within 90 days, rate of any other subsequent infection requiring antibiotic therapy within 90 days, rate of subsequent infections with MDR bacteria or Clostridioides difficile within 90 days, rate of other adverse drug events within 14 days, length of intensive care and hospital stay for the initial episode of cholangitis, quality of life and health utility, and societal costs and cost-effectiveness/-utility.

Keywords: antibiotics, randomized controlled trial.

This is a prospective, randomized, double-blinded clinical trial conducted at the Anesthesiology Department in Tanta University Hospitals. The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuver (US-LRM) compared to conventional lung recruitment maneuver (C-LRM) in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

The study will enroll 60 patients, divided into two groups: the conventional group (C) and the ultrasound-guided group (US). Patients will receive standard anesthesia and mechanical ventilation, and will undergo lung ultrasound examination at three time points during surgery. The primary outcome measure is the change in lung ultrasound score, while secondary outcomes include the incidence of atelectasis and intra-operative desaturation.

The US-LRM will be performed under direct real-time guidance of ultrasound if atelectasis is present, with a maximum airway pressure of 40 cmH2O. The C-LRM will be performed by manual inflation with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds. The study will assess the effectiveness of both techniques in reducing the incidence of atelectasis and improving lung function in morbidly obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

**Title:** Optimization of Fractionation Schedules of Heel Spur Radiotherapy: A Prospective Randomized Open-label Trial

**Objective:** To determine whether one-day irradiation (a single fraction) is non-inferior to fractionated radiotherapy over a three-month period in terms of pain relief for heel spur patients.

**Design:** Prospective, randomized, open-label trial with six arms: standard fractionated dose (6 Gy in 4 fractions) and five experimental single-dose arms (0.5 Gy, 1 Gy, 1.5 Gy, 2 Gy, and 3 Gy).

**Eligibility:** Patients aged 40 years or older with a diagnosed painful unilateral plantar heel spur for at least six months, suitable for radiotherapy, and without prior history of radiotherapy for heel spur.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Non-inferiority of single fraction radiotherapy of heel spur, evaluated by Calcaneodynia sum score (100 = free of symptoms, 0 = very intense symptoms) at three months after radiotherapy.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Comparison of different single fraction radiotherapy prescriptions, need for reirradiation, quality of life, and VAS score at various time points.

**Duration:** 44 months.

**Location:** Masaryk Memorial Cancer Institute Brno, Czech Republic.

**Title:** Lifestyle Intervention in Overweight/Obese Chronic Low Back Pain (CLBP) Patients: an International Multi-center RCT

**Objective:** To examine the effectiveness of a behavioral weight reduction program combined with Pain Neuroscience Education (PNE) and Cognition-Targeted Exercise Therapy (CTET) in reducing pain and improving quality of life in overweight or obese patients with chronic low back pain (CLBP) compared to PNE and CTET alone.

**Methodology:** This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 252 participants aged 18-65 years, who are overweight or obese and have CLBP. Participants will be randomized to either the experimental group, which will receive the behavioral weight reduction program combined with PNE and CTET, or the control group, which will receive PNE and CTET alone. The interventions will be delivered over 14 weeks, with assessments at baseline, directly post-treatment, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 12 months post-treatment.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Average pain intensity, measured using the Brief Pain Inventory (BPI).

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Pain interference on functioning, pain distribution, pain extent, kinesiophobia, fear avoidance beliefs, body weight, BMI, fat mass, fat-free mass, muscle mass, body water, waist-hip circumference, regional body composition, sedentary behavior, physical activity, sleep quality, dietary intake, health economics, productivity cost, and quality of life.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Adults aged 18-65 years, overweight or obese, with CLBP, who are seeking care for low back pain and leg pain.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with BMI ≥ 40 kg/m², morbid obesity, pregnant or breastfeeding women, patients with specific spinal pathology or severe underlying comorbidities.

Title: Comparison of Outcomes for Single vs Double Pyloromyotomy for Gastroparesis Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: To compare the clinical outcomes and efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy techniques in gastric per-oral endoscopic myotomy (G-POEM) for refractory and severe gastroparesis.

Methodology: This is a randomized controlled prospective multicenter study that will enroll patients with refractory and severe gastroparesis based on the Gastroparesis Cardinal Symptom Index (GCSI) score > 2. Patients will be randomized into two groups: single pyloromyotomy and double pyloromyotomy. The primary outcome measures will be clinical success at 3, 6, and 12 months, GCSI score before and after GPOEM at 3, 6, and 12 months, and technical success rate. Secondary outcome measures will include total procedure time, adverse events, and recurrence of symptoms.

Population: The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older with refractory and severe gastroparesis who have failed medical therapy and have impaired gastric emptying.

Intervention: Patients will undergo gastric per-oral endoscopic myotomy (G-POEM) with either single or double pyloromyotomy techniques.

Duration: The study will follow patients for 12 months after the procedure.

This summary captures the key aspects of the trial, including the objective, methodology, population, intervention, and duration.

**Title:** Cerebral Hemodynamic and Metabolic Responses to Anesthesia and Vasopressors in Adult Surgery: A 2x2 Factorial Design Randomized Controlled Trial With Light-based Neuromonitoring (CHEM-FACT Study)

**Objective:** To investigate the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents (propofol vs. sevoflurane) and vasopressors (phenylephrine vs. ephedrine) on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism in adult patients undergoing surgery under general anesthesia.

**Methodology:** This is a prospective, randomized controlled trial with a 2x2 factorial design. 80 adult patients (ASA I-III) will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: propofol-based anesthetic maintenance with phenylephrine or ephedrine, or sevoflurane-based anesthetic maintenance with phenylephrine or ephedrine. Patients will undergo light-based neuromonitoring (trNIRS/DCS) to measure cerebral blood flow, oxygenation, and metabolism. The primary outcome measures are the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism.

**Outcome Measures:** The primary outcome measure is the difference in cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2) during surgery between the four groups. Secondary outcome measures include the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents and vasopressors on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism during anesthesia induction.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Adult patients over 18 years old, ASA I-IV, undergoing surgery under general anesthesia at London Health Sciences Centre or St. Joseph's Healthcare that is scheduled to last longer than 1 hour.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with neurological conditions, history of substance abuse, contraindications to applying the cerebral oximetry device, or contraindications to receiving specific anesthetic agents or vasopressors.

Title: A Phase 2 Study on Immune Checkpoint Inhibitors and Radioembolisation for Previously Untreated Metastatic Hepatocellular Carcinoma

Exclusion Criteria: Patients with severe active autoimmune disease, prior monoclonal antibody, immunotherapy, or immune checkpoint inhibitors, prior chemotherapy or targeted small molecule therapy, known additional malignancy, active infection, or history of human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection.

**Title:** Neoadjuvant Tremelimumab and Durvalumab With Gem/Cis in Intrahepatic Cholangiocarcinoma

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of neoadjuvant durvalumab and tremelimumab combined with gemcitabine and cisplatin in patients with borderline resectable or resectable intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma.

**Study Design:** Phase II, open-label, single-arm study.

**Population:** Patients with histologically proven intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, untreated with systemic therapy, and with a performance status ECOG 0, 1. Patients must have an estimated life expectancy > 6 months and be willing to undergo surgical resection if the tumor is deemed resectable.

**Interventions:** Patients will receive durvalumab (1500 mg IV every 3 weeks for up to 8 cycles) and tremelimumab (300mg IV on cycle 1) in combination with gemcitabine (1000 mg/m2 IV on days 1 and 8 of each cycle) and cisplatin (25mg/m2 on days 1 and 8 of each cycle). **Primary Outcome Measures:** Rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable and incidence of related treatment emergent adverse events.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Objective response rate, pathological complete response, overall survival, progression-free survival, rate of R0 resection, relapse-free survival, patient-reported outcomes decline, and event-free survival.

**Study Overview**: The study aims to investigate the relationship between peri-implantitis, a condition that affects dental implants, and COX-2 gene polymorphisms, active matrix metalloproteinase 8 (MMP-8) levels, and the characterization of associated microbiota.

**Objectives**: The study has three main objectives:

3. To evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of the ImplantSafe MMP-8 biomarker test in peri-implantitis.

**Methodology**: The study will be conducted as a case-control study, recruiting 100 patients with peri-implantitis and 100 healthy controls. Buccal swabs will be collected to analyze COX-2 gene polymorphisms, and peri-implant crevicular fluid samples will be collected to analyze MMP-8 levels and microbiota. The ImplantSafe MMP-8 biomarker test will be used to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of the test.

**Inclusion and Exclusion Criteria**: Patients with screw-retained implant restorations, loaded for more than 12 months, treated for periodontal disease, and without diabetes or immunosuppressant diseases will be included. Patients who have received antibiotics in the past 3 months, have periodontal maintenance in the previous 3 months, or have diabetes or immunosuppressant diseases will be excluded.

**Study Plan**: The study will be conducted over a period of 3 years, with data collection and analysis taking place throughout the study period. The primary outcome measure will be the gene polymorphisms of MMP-8.

Title: Examining Engagement Predictors of Health and Fitness App Uptake and Subscription in the General Population

Objective: To examine predictors of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates at six months for the WayBetter app, a wellness lifestyle mHealth app. The study aims to identify underlying homogenous subgroups of individuals using Latent Class Analysis (LCA) and examine associations between these subgroups to determine which users are more likely to sign-up, subscribe, and renew subscription to the app.

Methodology: The study will enroll approximately 400 adult users who are new to the app and have entered into a 7-day free trial. Participants will complete a survey to collect information on socio-demographics, past health behaviors, psychological determinants, and app engagement metrics. The primary outcomes are rates of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates at six months. Secondary outcomes include app engagement metrics, such as app opens per week, date of joining first game, game adherence, and non-usage attrition.

The study will use linear regressions and Cox Proportional Hazard regression models to examine engagement correlates and Latent Class Analysis to identify underlying subgroups of users. The study will also conduct a sensitivity analysis to examine the effects of methods of WayBetter account creation on primary outcomes.

Keywords: mHealth, behavioral economics, financial incentives, deposit contracts, engagement, physical inactivity, nutrition, mindfulness.

**Title:** Immediate Effects of Proprioceptive Neuromuscular Facilitation With Lower Leg Kinesiotaping on Ankle Dorsiflexion, Gait and Functional Mobility in Patients With Chronic Stroke

**Objective:** To investigate the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesiotaping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

**Outcome Measures:** The primary outcome measures were time up and go test, Barthel Index, Motor Assessment Scale, and Dynamic Gait Index. These measures were assessed at baseline and after 1 hour.

**Title:** Effect of Early Bedside Cycling Exercises on Selected Physical and Psychological Outcomes in Patients After Heart Valve Surgery

**Objective:** To assess the effect of early bedside cycling exercises on physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery.

**Design:** Randomized controlled trial with 50 patients diagnosed with valve heart disease undergoing valve replacement or intervention. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (bedside cycling) or control group (routine physiotherapy).

**Intervention:** Bedside cycling exercises will be performed daily from being extubated and relatively stable until discharge from the hospital. The exercises will be conducted at a moderate intensity (RPE 11-13) and will last 20 minutes, with a gradual increase in duration and intensity.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcomes include functional capacity (Six Minutes Walk Test), forced vital capacity (spirometry), psychological status (Depression Anxiety Stress Scales), and activities of daily living and functional level (Barthel Index). Secondary outcomes include functional capacity, psychological status, quality of life, length of hospital stay, and incidence of adverse events.

**Duration:** The study will last approximately 2 weeks, with follow-up assessments at 1 month.

**Inclusion Criteria:** Patients aged 20-40 years with valvular heart disease who have undergone valve surgical intervention.

**Exclusion Criteria:** Patients with cognitive impairment, neurological disorders, severe musculoskeletal disorders, underlying pulmonary diseases, comorbidities such as liver or renal disease, or complicated operative course.

Title: Investigating the Effectiveness of Low-Level Laser in Reducing Root Resorption of the Upper Incisors During Intrusion Movement Using Mini-Implants in Adult Patients With Deep Overbite

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing root resorption during the correction of deep bite with the help of mini-implants in adult patients with Class I or II molar and canine relationship malocclusion.

Methodology: A randomized controlled clinical trial will be conducted to compare the effects of LLLT with traditional orthodontic treatment in 30 patients (18-30 years old) with deep overbite. Patients will be randomly assigned to either the control group (traditional orthodontic treatment) or the experimental group (LLLT). The primary outcome measures will be the change in root volume and length of the upper incisors, measured using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) images before and after the end of the incisor intrusion procedure.

Intervention: Patients in the experimental group will receive LLLT using a Ga-Al-As diode laser with a wavelength of 808 nm, while patients in the control group will receive traditional orthodontic treatment.

Inclusion criteria: Overbite > 4 mm, Class I or II molar and canine relationship malocclusion, maxillary anterior crowding < 2 mm, maxillary incisors positioned below the functional occlusal plane, incisor display of 2-3 mm or more at rest, and normal or horizontal facial growth pattern. Exclusion criteria include maxillary incisors with a history of trauma or endodontic treatment, increased inclination of the maxillary incisors towards the labial, and poor oral hygiene.

The study aims to explore the psychological impact of Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN) on women who have completed chemotherapy treatment. The objectives are to gain insight into the emotional impact of GTN post-treatment, ascertain if health professionals are providing adequate psychological support, identify sources of support that patients accessed post-completion of treatment, and identify potential areas of improvement in follow-up support for future patients.

The study will involve a cross-sectional retrospective study of 20 women who completed single agent or multi-agent chemotherapy between 6 weeks and 24 months post-treatment. The interviews will be digitally recorded and transcribed verbatim, and thematic analysis will be used to generate in-depth descriptions of the patients' experiences.

The study aims to increase knowledge and insight into patients' experiences of their psychological experiences post-chemotherapy, patients' perspectives of the support received after their treatment, and potential areas of improvement in care. The study will also identify common themes of psychological experiences post-chemotherapy, common opinions of post-treatment support, and themes of suggested improvement in patient care.

The study is expected to have minimal risks and will not involve any medical or invasive procedures. The data will be stored securely and confidentially, and participants will be able to withdraw from the study at any point. The study will end when all the data is analyzed.

**Title:** The Effectiveness of a Brief Behavioral Teacher Training for Behavioral Difficulties at School: a Randomized Controlled Trial.

**Objective:** To evaluate the effectiveness of a brief, individually-tailored behavioral teacher training program in reducing behavioral difficulties in children at school.

**Design:** A two-armed randomized controlled trial with 60 participants, where teachers are randomly assigned to either receive the brief teacher training or practice as usual (PAU).

**Intervention:** The brief teacher training program consists of three sessions, each lasting 2-3 hours, which focus on stimulus control and contingency management techniques to address behavioral difficulties in the classroom.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** The severity of four daily rated target behaviors in specific classroom situations, measured using a 5-point Likert scale.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** The study will also assess the severity of behavioral difficulties in other classroom situations, teacher-reported behavioral difficulties, child impairment at school, teacher-student relationship quality, teacher's sense of self-efficacy, and teacher-reported frequency of supportive and non-supportive management strategies.

**Population:** The study will recruit 60 teachers of children with behavioral difficulties in grades 1-8, from regular elementary education, special elementary education, or special education schools.

**Duration:** The study will run from November 2023 to February 2028, with data collection taking place at three time points: before randomization, one week after the brief training, and three months after the brief training.

**Locations:** The study will be conducted in the Netherlands, with participating mental health care centers and school collaborations.

**Methodology:** This is a single-blind, randomized, monocentric controlled trial with four arms: HABIT-ILE therapy at home without follow-up, HABIT-ILE therapy at home with follow-up, classic HABIT-ILE therapy without follow-up, and classic HABIT-ILE therapy with follow-up. Title: Sequential Adult Left Lateral Lobe Liver Transplantation (SALT) in Patients With Liver Cirrhosis With Hepatocellular Carcinoma (HCC): a Single-center, Prospective, Single-arm Study

Objective: To evaluate the overall survival rate of patients with liver cirrhosis and HCC treated with sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) using a single-center, prospective, single-arm study design.

Study Population: Patients aged 18-75 with liver cirrhosis and HCC, Child-Pugh A-B, and hepatitis B virus infection.

Intervention: SALT operation plan, which involves hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation followed by residual liver resection after the graft grows to a sufficient functional liver volume.

Primary Outcome Measure: Overall survival at 3 years after the second liver resection.

Secondary Outcome Measure: Disease-free survival at 1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, and 3 years post-transplant.

This study aims to address the shortage of donor livers for liver transplantation in patients with liver cirrhosis and HCC by using a new surgical method, SALT, which allows transplantation of the left liver (segments 2+3) to an adult recipient, while the remaining enlarged right hemi-liver is transplanted to another adult recipient.

Title: Randomized Placebo-Controlled Trial of Methylphenidate for the Treatment of Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder With Associated Neurocognitive Complaints

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of methylphenidate (MPH) in reducing symptoms of post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and associated neurocognitive complaints in Veterans with PTSD, with or without comorbid mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI).

Design: Aggregated N-of-1 randomized placebo-controlled trial with 70 Veterans across two sites, each receiving sequential 4-week periods of MPH and placebo (PBO), separated by a 1-week washout, for a total of 20 weeks.

Inclusion Criteria: Veterans with PTSD, subjective neurocognitive impairment, and a CAPS-5 past month total score ≥ 26. Exclusion Criteria: Presence of severe psychotic symptoms, moderate or severe substance use disorder, severe TBI, dementia, or increased risk of suicide.

Primary Outcome Measures: PTSD Symptom Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5) and Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function short form (NeuroQoL).

Secondary Outcome Measures: Symbol Digit Coding (SDC) task.

The study aims to assess the efficacy of MPH compared to PBO for reducing PTSD and depression symptoms, improving neurocognitive functioning, and characterizing baseline predictors of treatment response. If successful, MPH could provide a new treatment option for Veterans with PTSD and associated neurocognitive complaints.

Title: Absolute Flow for Ischemia With No Obstructive Coronary Arteries

Objective: To prospectively validate the capacity of coronary flow reserve (CFR) as a predictor of angina in patients with Ischemia With No Obstructive Coronary Arteries (INOCA) at 3 months, and to identify predictors of major cardiovascular events at 12 months.

Study Design: A diagnostic study using continuous thermodilution to measure absolute coronary flow and minimal microvascular resistance in patients with INOCA.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients over 18 years old with clinical indication for coronary angiography, clinical diagnosis of typical or atypical angina, and coronary arteries without lesions or with epicardial lesions <50%.

Primary Outcome Measure: Angina status assessed by the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ) at inclusion.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Quality of life at 3 months, accuracy of continuous thermodilution CFR measured by Youden Index, and concordance between measures of coronary microvascular function obtained by continuous and bolus thermodilution.

Keywords: Microvascular dysfunction, Coronary circulation, Myocardial ischemia Diagnosis, Coronary flow.

**Title:** Phase 2a Study of Adding Ruxolitinib With Tacrolimus/Methotrexate Regimen for Graft-versus-Host Disease Prophylaxis in Myeloablative Conditioning Hematopoietic Cell Transplantation in Pediatric and Young Adult Patients

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of adding ruxolitinib to tacrolimus and methotrexate as graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) for acute myeloid leukemia, acute lymphoblastic leukemia, or myelodysplastic syndrome.

**Design:** This is a single-arm, open-label study with a safety lead-in segment and a phase II segment. Patients will receive ruxolitinib, tacrolimus, and methotrexate from day -1 to day +100, followed by HCT on day 0. The primary endpoint is the incidence of adverse events, and the secondary endpoints include GVHD-free and relapse-free survival, cumulative incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, overall and progression-free survival, relapse/progression rate, and infection rate.

**Eligibility:** Patients must be between 2 and 22 years old, have a Karnofsky performance status of 60% or higher, and have a diagnosis of acute leukemia or myelodysplastic syndrome. Exclusion criteria include prior allogeneic transplantation, chemotherapy, or radiation therapy within 14 days of study enrollment, and active infections or uncontrolled illnesses.

**Duration:** The study will follow patients for up to 2 years after HCT.

Title: Patient and Prescriber Perspective on Climate Impact of Inhalers in the Treatment of Asthma

Objective: To assess asthma patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons and prescribers' willingness to prescribe a different inhaler for environmental reasons at the patient's request.

Methodology: The study will involve an educational intervention for asthma patients, providing them with information about the climate impact of inhalers and the option to change from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler. The study will also assess patient awareness of the climate impact of inhalers and their willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons, as well as prescribers' perspectives on the climate impact of inhalers and their approach to inhaler rotation.

Outcome Measures:

* Primary outcome: Proportion of participants who changed their inhaler from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler within 30 days of study visit.
* Secondary outcomes: Rate of failure of the intervention, proportion of patients who filled Bricanyl Rx change, awareness of patients regarding the climate impact of inhalers, patients' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons, and providers' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons.

Keywords: Asthma, Inhalers, Environment, Climate impact.

Title: Hybrid Argon Plasma Coagulation and Endoscopic Sleeve Gastroplasty Validation Study

Objective: To evaluate the durability of endoscopic plications, weight loss outcomes, and improvements in obesity-related co-morbidities for the combined hybrid argon plasma coagulation plus endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) procedure compared to traditional ESG.

Design: Single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial with 1:1 allocation to experimental and control groups.

Interventions:

* Experimental group: Hybrid APC and ESG
* Control group: ESG alone

Primary Outcome Measure: Durability of plications and endoscopic sutures on repeat endoscopy at 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Blood pressure
* HbA1c percentage
* Quality of life (SF-36 and IWQOL-Lite)
* Depression (PHQ-9)
* Eating behavior (TFEQ-r18)
* Binary outcomes: ≥25% change in %EWL and incidence of esophagitis

Eligibility Criteria:

* Age 21-65
* BMI ≥ 30 and ≤40 kg/m²
* Willingness to comply with dietary restrictions and follow-up schedule
* History of failure with non-surgical weight-loss methods

Exclusion Criteria:

* History of foregut or gastrointestinal surgery
* Prior open or laparoscopic bariatric surgery
* Inflammatory diseases of the gastrointestinal tract
* Potential upper gastrointestinal bleeding conditions
* Gastrointestinal stromal tumors
* Gastric mass or gastric polyps > 1 cm in size
* Hiatal hernia > 4cm of axial displacement of the z-line above the diaphragm
* Severe coagulopathy
* Insulin-dependent diabetes
* Chronic abdominal pain
* Motility disorders of the GI tract
* Hepatic insufficiency or cirrhosis
* Use of an intragastric device prior to this study
* Active psychological issues preventing participation in a lifestyle modification program
* Patients unwilling to participate in an established medically supervised diet and behavior modification program

Title: THE EFFECT OF CANCER EDUCATION BASED ON THE HEALTH BELIEF MODEL ON AWARENESS OF WOMEN WITH DISABILITIES AND THEIR PARTICIPATION IN SCREENING

Objective: To determine the effectiveness of cancer education based on the Health Belief Model (HBM) on awareness and participation in cancer screening among women with physical disabilities.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with two intervention groups: Intervention 1 (HBM-based cancer education) and Intervention 2 (standard cancer education).

Participants: Women with physical disabilities between 18-65 years old, married or living with a spouse, and with no history of common cancers in women.

Interventions:

Outcome measures:

* Primary outcome: The Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale, measuring awareness of gynecological cancers.
* Secondary outcomes: Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening, measuring perceived barriers to breast self-examination and mammography.

The study aims to increase awareness and participation in cancer screening among women with physical disabilities by using the Health Belief Model-based education.

Title: The Effect of Progressive Muscle Relaxation and Deep Breathing Exercises Training on Dyspnea, Fatigue and, Quality of Sleep in Patients With COPD: A Randomized Controlled Clinical Trial

Objective: To investigate the effect of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and deep breathing exercises (DBE) on dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

Design: Randomized controlled trial with a parallel assignment design.

Interventions:

* Experimental group 1: PMR exercises, which involve systematic relaxation of main muscle groups, applied twice daily for 8 weeks.
* Experimental group 2: DBE training, which includes deep and comfortable breathing techniques, applied twice daily for 8 weeks.
* Control group: No intervention.

Outcomes:

* Primary outcomes: Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease and Asthma Fatigue Scale, Dyspnea-12 Scale, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index.
* Measurements taken at two weeks.

Eligibility criteria:

* Patients with COPD who are conscious, fully oriented, and have not had an acute exacerbation in the past month.
* Exclusion criteria include hearing problems, inability to practice relaxation exercises regularly, neurological diseases, and comorbidities such as acute myocardial infarction or cancer.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of PMR and DBE in improving dyspnea, fatigue, and quality of sleep in patients with COPD.

The study aims to evaluate the functional diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing de novo coronary artery lesions. The trial will enroll patients with stable or unstable angina pectoris or after acute myocardial infarction, aged 18 years or older, with intermediate coronary lesions (30-80% stenosis). The study will compare the diagnostic accuracy of UFR with fractional flow reserve (FFR) and intravascular ultrasound (IVUS) in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis. The primary outcome measures include the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient and vessel levels, as well as the diagnostic accuracy of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level. The study will also evaluate the area under the receiver-operating characteristic curve (AUC) of UFR for coronary stenosis.

Title: Effect of Balint Group on Burnout and Self-efficacy of Nurse Leaders in China: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effect of Balint group activities on burnout and self-efficacy of nurse leaders in China.

Methodology: This randomized controlled trial enrolled nurse leaders in clinical departments in China. Participants were randomly assigned to either a Balint group or a non-Balint group. The Balint group completed Balint training for three months, which included two lectures and 10 small group discussion sessions. The primary outcome measures were subscales of the Maslach Burnout Inventory-Human Services Survey (MBI-HSS) and the General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES). The secondary outcome measures were also subscales of the MBI-HSS and GSES.

Population: Nurse leaders in clinical departments in China.

Duration: Three months.

Intervention: Balint group activities.

Outcome measures: Burnout (emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and personal accomplishment) and self-efficacy.

The Clinical Study on the Mangrove Sword Bean Food Bar Effect for Older People is a non-randomized, parallel assignment study conducted by the School of Environmental Sciences - University of Indonesia. The study aims to evaluate the effect of mangrove sword bean food bars on the weight of older people affected by a landslide disaster in Cihanjuang Village, Indonesia.

The study recruited 60-80 year old male and female participants who were affected by the disaster, had normal, under-, or over-nutrition status, and were willing to avoid consuming snacks other than the food bars and plain water. Participants were randomly assigned to either a treatment group or a control group.

The primary outcome measure was the change in weight of the participants, which was measured at the first and second weeks of the study. Secondary outcome measures included the change in balanced nutrition knowledge of the participants, which was measured through questionnaires at the baseline and end-line.

The study aimed to assess the effect of the mangrove sword bean food bars on the weight and nutrition knowledge of older people affected by a disaster, and to provide a balanced nutrition education to the participants.

Title: Efficacy and Safety of Chiglitazar Added to Glargine in Patients With Type 2 Diabetes

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Chiglitazar added to metformin and insulin glargine in patients with type 2 diabetes who have poor glycemic control despite current treatment.

**Title:** Prospective Validation of an EHR-based Pancreatic Cancer Risk Model

**Objective:** To prospectively validate and assess the performance of an EHR-based pancreatic cancer risk-prediction model (PRISM) in a real-time clinical setting.

**Design:** A multi-center, prospective cohort study deploying the PRISM model within the TriNetX federated network database. The study will follow individuals for up to 3 years to assess the primary end-point of pancreatic adenocarcinoma (PDAC) development.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Males and females aged 40 years or older from 44 US healthcare organizations (HCOs) with at least 2 clinical encounters within the last year.

**Intervention:** The PRISM model, which uses routinely collected electronic health record (EHR) data to stratify individuals into PDAC risk groups.

**Outcome Measures:** Primary outcomes include the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) and calibration of the PRISM model. Secondary outcomes include sensitivity, specificity, PPV, and SIR for patients identified as high-risk or medium-risk by PRISM, as well as the timing of incident PDAC occurrence and tumor stage at diagnosis.

**Study Timeline:** The study will run for up to 3 years, with data collection and analysis occurring at 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, and 3 years.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group, open-label study with three arms: (1) control group maintaining 35 hours/week of exercise training, (2) lower exercise volume group reducing exercise volume by 15-30%, and (3) extended recovery group maintaining 35 hours/week of exercise training with longer rest intervals.

The study will enroll 18-70 year old individuals with MDD and healthy controls. Secondary outcome measures include determining the optimal length for PDE4B scans, measuring whole-brain VT of PDE4B in a retest setting, and assessing the relationship between clinical rating scales and PDE4B binding.

The study is expected to run for 36 months and will be conducted at the National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH).

The Global Burden Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) study aims to estimate the point-prevalence of high-risk Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection in low socio-economic populations and the incidence of persistent HPV infection in specific sub-populations. The study will be conducted in 8 countries, with a harmonized protocol and country-specific protocols to accommodate differences in study settings and populations. The study will enroll girls and women aged 9-50 years, with a focus on vulnerable sub-populations, and collect urine samples, self-collected vaginal swabs, and blood samples (if feasible). Title: Operant Conditioning of Sensory Brain Responses to Reduce Phantom Limb Pain in People With Limb Amputation

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of operant conditioning with peripheral stimulation in reducing phantom limb pain in individuals with limb amputation.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group, triple-blind study with two arms: intervention group receiving operant conditioning feedback with peripheral stimulation, and control group receiving only peripheral stimulation.

Participants: Individuals with a limb amputation (traumatic or atraumatic) and chronic phantom limb pain, aged 18 years or older, with no other medically unstable conditions.

Intervention: Operant conditioning with peripheral stimulation, involving non-painful stimulation to elicit a brain response, and visual feedback in pseudo real-time. Control group receives only peripheral stimulation without operant conditioning feedback.

Duration: 8-9 weeks of training, followed by 2 follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of operant conditioning in reducing phantom limb pain and improving sensorimotor responses in individuals with limb amputation.

Title: UM CRMC RecuR Score Pilot

Study Overview:
The study aims to reduce 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions by identifying patients at high risk of readmission using the RecuR Score, an artificial intelligence-powered risk score. The study will test the efficacy of a new transitional care model, which includes additional educational materials, focus on readmission risk during interdisciplinary team huddles, and home health services, in reducing readmissions in patients with a high readmission risk.

Objectives:
The primary objectives are to reduce 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions in patients with a high readmission risk (RecuR Score ≥ 3) by 30% and to reduce readmissions in patients with a medium-high readmission risk (RecuR Score 2 or 3) by 30%.

Methods:
The study is a parallel-group, two-arm, prospective, randomized, non-blinded, fallback design controlled superiority study. Patients will be randomized to receive either Standard of Care or Enhanced Care. The Enhanced Care arm will receive additional interventions, including additional educational materials, focus on readmission risk during interdisciplinary team huddles, and home health services.

Outcomes:
The primary outcomes are the number of patients with 30-day post-discharge hospital readmissions and the number of patients with 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmissions in patients with a medium-high readmission risk (RecuR Score 2 or 3).

Population:
The study will enroll patients with a high readmission risk (RecuR Score ≥ 3) or medium-high readmission risk (RecuR Score 2 or 3) who are admitted to the University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center (UM CRMC) and meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

Duration:
The study will enroll patients for a period of approximately 12 months.

This summary captures the key aspects of the trial, including the study objectives, methods, outcomes, and population.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Study Overview**

The "Trans-coronary Cooling and Dilution for Cardioprotection During Revascularisation for ST-elevation Myocardial Infarction" study is a pilot trial investigating the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of trans-coronary cooling and dilution during primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

**Study Population**

The study will enroll 60 patients with STEMI undergoing primary PCI at Harefield Hospital. Patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either trans-coronary cooling and dilution or standard of care.

**Primary Aim**

The primary aim of the study is to investigate the recruitment rate, feasibility, and safety of the trans-coronary cooling and dilution treatment.

**Secondary Aims**

Secondary aims include:

* Exploring invasive haemodynamic assessment of coronary flow and microvascular function
* Examining blood biomarkers before and after treatment for myocardial infarction
* Assessing myocardial salvage after treatment for myocardial infarction using magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)

**Intervention**

Patients randomized to the intervention arm will receive trans-coronary cooling and dilution through the guiding catheter during primary PCI. The treatment will involve an infusion of room temperature 0.9% Normal Saline solution through the guiding catheter, which will commence immediately prior to crossing the coronary occlusion with the guidewire. The infusion will continue until 10 minutes after the lesion is crossed and distal flow is restored.

**Outcome Measures**

The primary outcome measures include recruitment rate, feasibility, and safety. Secondary outcome measures include various haemodynamic and biomarker assessments, as well as MRI and echocardiography evaluations.

**Study Timeline**

The study will be conducted over a period of 1 year, with follow-up assessments at 6 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months.

The playful interactions will be conducted using dramatic improvisation techniques, and will involve verbal and non-verbal elements. The control conditions will involve introductory conversations and movement exercises. The study will assess various outcomes, including cognitive tests (e.g., digit span, phonetic fluency, flanker task), social and emotional measures (e.g., perceived partner responsiveness, closeness, mood), and subjective experiences (e.g., flow, mindfulness, subjective arousal).

The study will also investigate the mediating role of personality traits and cognitive functions in connection to the beneficial effects of playful interactions. The investigators hypothesize that playful interactions will induce greater effects on emotional and social indices, as well as on executive functioning, compared to more familiar social interactions. Title: Physiological Effects of Prone vs. Supine Position on Lung Recruitability in Infants/Children with Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome

Objective: To investigate the effects of prone positioning on lung recruitability in infants and children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).

Design: 2x2 crossover design, non-randomized, open-label study.

Population: Infants and children aged 4 weeks to 18 years with ARDS, PaO2/FiO2 < 200 in the supine position, and no history of chronic respiratory disease or heart failure.

Intervention: Patients will be ventilated in the supine position for 30 minutes, followed by prone positioning for 1 hour. Ventilator settings will remain unchanged throughout the study.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Various respiratory mechanics and gas exchange parameters, including PaO2/FiO2, PaCO2, PaO2, tidal volume distribution, and lung dynamic strain, measured using electrical impedance tomography.

Safety endpoints: Number of endotracheal tube displacements and oxygen desaturations during prone positioning.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of prone positioning on lung recruitability and respiratory mechanics in infants and children with ARDS, with the goal of improving oxygenation and reducing lung injury.

**Title:** Non-myeloablative Haploidentical HCT Study for Patients With Sickle Cell Disease, Including Compromised Organ Function

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and efficacy of a non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) regimen for patients with sickle cell disease (SCD) who have compromised organ function or are at high risk for disease-related morbidity or mortality.

**Design:** This is a phase I/II, open-label, single-arm study with two cohorts. Patients will receive a non-myeloablative conditioning regimen consisting of alemtuzumab, TBI, sirolimus, and infusion of filgrastim-mobilized peripheral blood hematopoietic cells from haploidentical related donors. Cohort 1 will receive a single dose of PT-Cy, while Cohort 2 will receive two doses of PT-Cy.

**Eligibility:** Patients with SCD who have compromised organ function or are at high risk for disease-related morbidity or mortality, and have a haploidentical related donor available.

**Primary Endpoint:** The percentage of SCD patients at 1 year post-transplant who have not experienced graft failure and who are without severe graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

**Secondary Endpoints:** Event-free survival, overall survival, viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflammatory complications, and incidence of hematologic malignancies.

**Organ Damage:** The study will evaluate the impact of the non-myeloablative conditioning regimen on organs including the heart, lung, kidneys, liver, brain, neurocognitive function, and endocrine organs.

**Quality of Life:** The study will also evaluate the impact of the regimen on quality of life.

**Gene Therapy:** The study will explore the use of gene therapy involving cell culture or genetic manipulation to produce normal or therapeutic hemoglobin on excess autologous CD34+ cells collected from recipients.

This randomized controlled trial aims to compare the effectiveness of microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation methods on the euploidy rate of pre-implantation genetic testing (PGT) in couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: the microfluidic chip group or the density gradient centrifugation group. Sperm preparation will be performed using either the Sperm Separation Device or discontinuous density gradient centrifugation method. The primary outcome measure is the euploid rate of blastocysts, while secondary outcomes include live birth rate, positive urine pregnancy test rate, clinical pregnancy rate, ongoing pregnancy rate, miscarriage rate, multiple pregnancy rate, DNA fragmentation, and ectopic pregnancy rate. The study aims to assess the impact of the two sperm preparation methods on IVF outcomes, including pregnancy rates and obstetric complications.

Title: XELOX Combined With Fruquintinib and Sintilimab Regimen Conversion Therapy for Gastric Cancer/Gastroesophageal Junction Adenocarcinoma

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of XELOX combined with Fruquintinib and Sintilimab in patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma who have liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis.

The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of the combination therapy in patients with gastric cancer/gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma who have liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastasis.

Title: Incentives for Physical Activity for Older Adults

Objective: To evaluate the impact of alternative incentives (prosocial and personal) on physical activity (step count) in older adults (ages 55+), and to explore the impact on physical and mental health.

Design: Randomized controlled trial (RCT) with 200 participants, divided into two groups: treatment (n=100) and control (n=100). The treatment group receives incentives (meal donations and monetary rewards) for meeting a daily step goal of 7,500 steps, while the control group does not receive incentives. Participants wear Fitbits to track step count for 8 weeks.

Inclusion criteria: 55 years old or older, owns a smartphone, can walk independently, and does not regularly engage in outdoor physical activity.

Primary outcome measure: Change in step count (averaged across a week) at weeks 1 and 8.

Secondary outcome measures: Change in CES-D (Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale) score at weeks 1 and 8, as a measure of mental health.

The study aims to address the limitations of traditional incentive-based behavior change programs, such as scalability and habit formation, by using alternative incentives that harness prosocial preferences and do not crowd out intrinsic motivation.

Title: Phase II Study Evaluating Pre- or Post-operative HYPOfractionated Radiation Therapy in Aged (≥ 70 Years) or Fragile (≥ 65 Years) Patients With Limb or Trunk Soft Tissue SARComa.

Objective: To evaluate the safety and efficacy of pre- or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in aged or fragile patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma.

Eligibility: Patients with histologically confirmed soft tissue sarcoma of the limbs or trunk, aged ≥ 70 years or fragile patients aged 65-70 years, with a performance status ECOG ≤ 2, and affiliated to a Social Health Insurance in France.

Interventions: Two arms:

* Experimental: Neo-adjuvant Cohort: Patients receive hypofractionated radiation therapy (30 Gy in 5 fractions) prior to surgery, followed by post-operative follow-up.
* Experimental: Adjuvant Cohort: Patients undergo surgery, then receive adjuvant hypofractionated radiation therapy (40 Gy in 15 fractions), followed by post-operative follow-up.

Primary Outcome Measure: The rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Patients' disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and toxicities of radiation therapy.

Study duration: 3 years post-surgery, with long-term follow-up every 6 months.
