Title: The Role of Health Communication Messaging in Evidence-based Pediatric Obstructive Sleep Apnea Detection

Objective: To investigate the impact of a health communication message on parents' awareness and activation about their child's risk for obstructive sleep apnea (OSA), with the goal of identifying more children with OSA symptoms.

Design: Randomized controlled trial (RCT) with two arms: 1) intervention (health communication message) and 2) usual care.

Eligibility: Children aged 2-13.9 years, primary care patients at Eskenazi Health, and parents who completed a pre-visit questionnaire with OSA screening items.

Intervention: Parents in the intervention arm will view a health communication message (infographic) about OSA symptoms and be encouraged to discuss their child's risk with their primary care provider. Parents in the usual care arm will not receive any additional information about OSA or their child's risk.

Primary outcome measures: Rate of completed OSA referral, rate of OSA diagnosis, and rate of OSA treatment.

Secondary outcome measures: Rate of OSA referral, rate of evidence-based evaluation, rate of parent activation, and rate of OSA diagnosis.

The study aims to determine whether involving parents in the OSA detection process through a health communication message can identify more children with OSA symptoms and improve the rate of OSA diagnosis and treatment.

Title: Testing of Online Version of QAPS

Study Overview: This study aims to assess the prewriting skills of children aged 3 to 7 years old using an online version of the QAPS (Qualitative Assessment of Pre-writing Skills) assessment.

Methodology: Children will participate in a series of tasks, including playing a drawing game on a tablet, copying shapes using a pencil and paper, writing letters, and cutting paper with scissors. Caregivers will also complete surveys about their child's development, including demographics, emotionality, attentional behavior, and ego resiliency.

Assessments: The study will measure the following outcomes:

* Online QAPS: Children will draw shapes on a touch-screen tablet to assess their prewriting skills.
* Beery VMI: Children will complete a pencil-paper visual motor assessment to copy shapes of increasing difficulty.
* Functional hand tasks: Children will demonstrate their handwriting and scissors skills.
* Demographics survey: Caregivers will complete a 12-question survey about their child's demographics.
* Emotionality Assessment: Caregivers will rate their child's ability to regulate emotions.
* Strengths & difficulties Questionnaire Inattention/Hyperactivity subscale: Caregivers will rate their child's attentional behavior.
* Ego Resiliency Scale: Caregivers will rate their child's ability to adapt to change.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the online version of QAPS in assessing prewriting skills in children and to identify any potential issues or limitations.

Title: Effects of Blood Flow Restriction Rehabilitation After ORIF of Distal Radius Fractures

Objective: To investigate the effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy on rehabilitation outcomes after open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of distal radius fractures.

Design: Prospective, randomized controlled trial with two groups: control group receiving standard rehabilitation and experimental group receiving rehabilitation with BFR.

Inclusion criteria: Adults aged 18+ with acute fracture of distal radius requiring ORIF surgery.

Exclusion criteria: Exorbitant pain, prior trauma or surgery to the affected limb, obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular, renal, liver or pulmonary disease, active infections, cancer, bleeding or coagulation disorder, rapid weight change, and inability to participate in the intervention.

Intervention: The experimental group will undergo standard postoperative rehabilitation with the addition of BFR therapy using a tourniquet during selected exercises.

Primary outcome measures: Body composition/bone density, forearm girth, grip strength, and pinch grip strength.

Secondary outcome measures: Patient-reported outcome surveys, including DASH, Michigan Hand Outcomes, and Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation.

Duration: The study will follow participants for 12 weeks post-operatively.

Masking: None (open-label).

**Title:** Workplace Intervention to Reduce Sitting Time: a Randomized Clinical Trial

**Objective:** To determine the effect of the Stand up for your Health computer app on sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, cardiometabolic markers, and physical activity in office workers.

**Design:** A 2-arm randomized controlled trial with a 6-month follow-up period. Participants will be recruited from educational establishments and will be measured at baseline, 3rd, and 6th months.

**Intervention:** The experimental group will receive the Stand up for your Health computer app plus educational information, while the control group will only receive educational information.

**Outcomes:** The primary outcome measures include sedentary behavior (occupational sitting time), cardiometabolic biomarkers (fasting blood glucose, insulin, cortisol, triglycerides, total cholesterol, LDL, and HDL), and musculoskeletal symptoms (pain and symptoms). Anthropometric measurements (height, weight, waist circumference, and body mass index) will also be assessed.

**Eligibility:** Office workers over 18 years of age, full-time employees (≥35 hours per week), who spend most of their workday sitting (> 60%), and are able to walk without assistance. Exclusion criteria include pregnant women, desktop workers using a height-adjustable workstation, and office workers who are sufficiently active according to WHO criteria.

Title: Artificial Intelligence for Preventing Heart Disease (AiPHD): Observational, Single Center, Prospective and Retrospective Study

Objective: To develop an AI-based model to identify and categorize patients at high risk of coronary artery disease (CAD) progression and provide personalized management approaches to improve patient outcomes.

Study Design: A single-center, observational study with a retrospective cohort of 2500 patients and a prospective cohort of 500 patients who underwent clinically indicated coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) examinations for CAD evaluation.

Primary Outcome Measures: The study will measure the composite outcome of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction at 36 months from cCTA examination.

Secondary Outcome Measures: The study will also measure the composite outcome of all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization at 36 months from cCTA examination.

The study aims to overcome current limitations in AI-based applications in cardiovascular care by developing a platform that provides external validation of the algorithm, state-of-the-art security measures, interoperability with current clinical software, and an easy-to-use interface.

**Title:** Evaluate the Efficacy and Safety of Different Doses of Edaravone Dexborneol Concentrated Solution for Injection Combined With Conventional Medical Therapy in the Treatment of Patients With Cerebral Hemorrhage

**Objective:** To evaluate the safety and tolerability of different doses of Edaravone Dexborneol concentrate for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in patients with cerebral hemorrhage.

**Design:** Multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled exploratory clinical trial.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Patients with cerebral hemorrhage, aged 18-80 years, with a hematoma volume ≤ 30 ml, and a National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS) score ≥ 6 points and ≤ 20 points.

**Interventions:** Patients were randomized to receive either Synbixin (edaravone dexborneol concentrate for injection) at a dose of 37.5 mg or 62.5 mg, or placebo, in combination with conventional medical therapy.

**Primary Outcome Measures:** Incidence of serious adverse events (SAEs) up to 90 days after the first dose of treatment.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Incidence of deaths, proportion of subjects with adverse events, modified Rankin Score (mRS), Glasgow Outcome Score (GOS), National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS), Barthel index (BI), imaging endpoints, plasma pharmacokinetic endpoints, and plasma biomarker endpoints.

**Duration:** The study was divided into two periods: Period A (dose escalation) and Period B (maintenance treatment). The study treatment was administered for up to 90 days.

Title: Promoting BEST (BEtter, Faster, Longer, STronger) Walking for People With Parkinson's

Objective: To identify technical, attitudinal, and motivational obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease (PD) to adopt technology to improve gait and quantify changes in gait biomechanics, ultimately improving physical function, physical activity, motivation, and quality of life.

Design: An individualized, blocked, stepped-wedge design with a randomized allocation of participants to receive the Heel2Toe sensor, training, and remote supervised use at intervals of 3 weeks.

Eligibility Criteria: Participants must have technology readiness, be able to use a smartphone, and have a recent smartphone that supports the technology. They must also be able to walk outdoors on most days and have a positive attitude towards learning new things.

Intervention: Participants will receive the Heel2Toe sensor, which provides real-time auditory feedback when taking a good step, and will be instructed to use it for 3 months.

Primary Outcome Measures: Angular velocity of ankle at heel strike, push-off, and foot swing, as well as co-efficient of variation of angular velocity of ankle during three phases of gait cycle.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Motivation, apathy, walking behavior, health-related quality of life, self-reported cognitive ability, and cognitive performance test.

Duration: 3 months, with assessments at baseline and 3 months.

The study aims to improve gait and physical function in people with PD by providing real-time feedback and motivation through the use of wearable technology.

Title: Preliminary Effects of a Laughter Yoga Program on Mood, Anxiety, and Loneliness Among Adolescents with Intellectual and Physical Disabilities in a Special School: A Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial

Objective: To evaluate the effects of a 4-week laughter yoga program on mood, anxiety, and loneliness among adolescents with mild to moderate intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with 40 participants aged 10-18 years old, randomly allocated to either the intervention group (laughter yoga program) or the control group (routine care).

Intervention: The laughter yoga program consists of 8 sessions over 4 weeks, with each session lasting 15 minutes. The program includes hand clapping, deep breathing, childlike playfulness, and laughter exercises.

Outcome measures: Mood, anxiety, and loneliness were assessed using standardized scales (Mood Scale, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, and UCLA Loneliness Scale) at pre-intervention and post-intervention.

Methodology: Participants were recruited from a special school in Hong Kong, and data collection was conducted by direct care staff, school nurses, and schoolteachers. Descriptive statistics and multiple regression analysis were used to analyze the data.

Expected outcome: The study aims to demonstrate the feasibility and potential benefits of laughter yoga in promoting mental health and well-being among adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities.

Title: Impact of Pasta Consumption Timing on Multiple Health Outcomes

Objective: To assess the impact of consuming pasta at lunch or dinner on sleep quality, anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, and gut microbiota in normal-weight subjects.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with a crossover design, involving two phases of nutritional intervention. Participants will be randomly assigned to either eat pasta at lunch or dinner for 3 months, and then switch to the other condition for another 3 months.

Exclusion Criteria: Presence of chronic illness, irregular sleeping schedules, use of medications affecting sleep or metabolism, and other conditions that may affect the outcome of the study.

Objective: To determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in patients with multiple myeloma.

Design: Open-label, single-center, phase 2 study enrolling up to 55 patients with multiple myeloma. Patients will be divided into two cohorts: newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) and relapsed and/or refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM).

Eligibility Criteria: Patients ≥ 18 years old with a documented diagnosis of multiple myeloma, measurable disease, and an ECOG performance status of 0 to 2.

Exclusion Criteria: History of allergic reactions to similar compounds, severe claustrophobia, uncontrolled intercurrent illness, and others.

The primary outcome measures will be the agreement of blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output between the two devices, assessed using Scatterplot and Bland-Altman analysis.

The study aims to develop and evaluate an online psychotherapy program and AI-assisted interventions for post-secondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington (KFL&A) region. Title: A Study to Assess the Efficacy of Omnivirol-Salicylic Acid Combination Therapy for Cutaneous Warts With Emphasis on Persistent Warts

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of a combination therapy of Omnivirol (AV2) and salicylic acid (SA) in treating cutaneous warts, with a focus on persistent warts.

Design: Randomized, parallel-group, quadruple-blinded study with two arms: Experimental (AV2-SA) and Active Comparator (SA).

Interventions: Participants in the Experimental arm receive AV2-SA combination therapy (one drop daily and one puff weekly), while those in the Active Comparator arm receive standard SA treatment (one drop daily and one puff weekly).

Primary Outcome Measures: Cure rate and recurrence rate of index warts at 12 weeks and 6 months after enrollment, respectively.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Safety, time to clearance of index wart, change in size of index wart, number of verrucae remaining, and genotype-specific distribution of wart-associated HPV types in a Belgian population.

Eligibility Criteria: Participants must be 12 years or older, have one or more cutaneous warts, and agree to refrain from using prescription or supplemental antiviral medications without permission. Exclusion criteria include immunocompromised individuals, those with severe diseases, and those with a history of allergic or adverse reactions to the investigational product.

The study aims to assess the efficacy of letrozole compared to methotrexate in treating ectopic pregnancy. A total of 75 women with ectopic pregnancy were randomly allocated to one of three groups: a single dose of methotrexate, letrozole twice daily for 10 days, or letrozole three times daily for 5 days. The primary outcome measures are the levels of beta-human chorionic gonadotropin (βhCG) on day 14 and anti-mullerian hormone (AMH) 3 months after treatment. Secondary outcomes include measurement of blood cells, liver enzymes, urea, and serum creatinine levels on days 1 and 7. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of letrozole in treating ectopic pregnancy and its potential advantages over methotrexate.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT) in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The study will enroll patients with papillary thyroid cancer and collect tumor and healthy tissue samples for analysis. The primary outcome measures include:

* H2O2 generation in papillary thyroid cancer and corresponding normal tissues
* TERT mitochondrial localization in papillary thyroid tumors
* Effect of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation in thyroid cancer cell lines
* Mitochondrial oxidative stress generation, proliferation, apoptosis, and migration in cells lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors

Secondary outcome measures include genetic characterization of tumor tissues and expression profile of tumor tissues. The study will investigate the relationship between oxidative stress, mitochondrial TERT, and therapeutic resistance in papillary thyroid cancer, with the goal of identifying potential therapeutic targets for the disease.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Title:** Cooling in Mild Encephalopathy Versus Targeted Normothermia (COMET) Trial

**Objective:** To compare the effects of whole-body hypothermia (33.5°C) with targeted normothermia (36.5°C) in newborns with mild hypoxic-ischaemic encephalopathy (HIE) on cognitive and neurological outcomes at 2 years of age.

**Design:** A phase III, prospective, multi-centre, open-label, randomized controlled trial with an internal pilot and masked outcome assessments.

**Eligibility:** Newborns born at or after 36 weeks of gestation with birth weight ≥ 1800g, requiring resuscitation at birth, and with mild HIE defined as two or more abnormal findings on a structured neurological examination.

**Interventions:** Whole-body hypothermia (33.5°C) for 72 hours or targeted normothermia (36.5°C) for 80 hours, both with supportive neonatal intensive care.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Mean Cognitive Composite Scale score from the Bayley IV examination at 22-26 months.

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care, hospital stay, mechanical ventilation, inotropic support, bloodstream or cerebrospinal fluid positive infection, thrombocytopenia or coagulopathy requiring transfusion, opioid use, and brain injury scores on conventional magnetic resonance imaging.

**Follow-up:** Babies will be assessed at 2 years of age using the Bayley Scales of Infant and Toddler Development IV, Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) for cerebral palsy, vision, and hearing assessment.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial document:

**Title:** A First-In-Human Trial of pTTL in Advanced Colorectal Cancer

**Objective:** To investigate the safety and tolerability of pTTL, an immunotherapy consisting of autologous T cells activated and expanded in vitro using tumour-specific personalised neoantigens, in patients with advanced colorectal cancer (CRC).

**Design:** Open-label, non-randomised, single-group assignment trial with a maximum of 36 patients.

**Eligibility Criteria:** Adults with stage IV CRC, good performance status, and adequate organ function. Patients must have received all possible standard of care therapies or have toxicity from previous therapy that limits further standard of care therapy.

**Intervention:** pTTL, an autologous cell product for adoptive cancer immunotherapy, will be administered as a single dose after pre-conditioning chemotherapy with Fludarabine and Cyclophosphamide.

**Primary Outcome Measure:** Safety of pTTL administration, as determined by assessment of incidence and severity of adverse events (AEs).

**Secondary Outcome Measures:** Objective response, time to treatment response, duration of treatment response, time to tumour progression, kinetics of tumour progression/growth, overall survival, progression-free survival, and disease-specific survival.

**Duration:** The trial will consist of three parts: Part I (patient identification and tissue collection), Part II (pTTL production and treatment), and Part III (long-term follow-up). The trial is expected to be completed within 5 years after pTTL administration.

Title: Benefit of Early Intrauterine Transfer of Blank Culture Medium Prior to Transfer of a Thawed Embryo From 1st in Vitro Fertilization

Objective: To investigate the effect of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization (IVF) attempt on clinical outcomes.

Design: Randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial with two arms: experimental (with blank culture transfer) and sham comparator (without blank culture transfer).

Inclusion criteria: Women who have had a first fresh or frozen IVF attempt with pregnancy failure, have at least two eligible embryos for transfer or freezing, and have given informed consent.

Primary outcome measures: Clinically progressive pregnancy rate between groups, measured at 12 weeks of amenorrhea.

Secondary outcome measures: Occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, live birth, and cost-result ratio.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first IVF attempt.

This multicenter, observational cohort study aims to construct a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life of patients with primary solid malignant cancers receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study includes patients with solid tumors who have received immunotherapy for the first time, and collects baseline information before treatment and follow-up information after treatment. The primary outcome measures are disease-free progression survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS), while secondary outcomes include quality of life scores. Title: The Effect of Acupressure Applied in the Late Postpartum Period After Cesarean Section on Back Pain

Objective: To examine the effect of acupressure on back pain in postpartum women who had a cesarean section.

Design: Randomized controlled experimental study with two groups: Acupressure group and Control group.

Population: Postpartum women aged 18-49 years who had a cesarean section and reported back pain.

Intervention: Acupressure application to specific points on the body for 12 minutes, once, in the first week postpartum.

Outcome Measures: Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for assessing back pain, measured at baseline and 4 weeks postpartum.

Primary Outcome: Reduction in back pain severity in the Acupressure group compared to the Control group.

Secondary Outcomes: Changes in back pain severity over time in both groups.

Methodology: Participants will be randomly assigned to either the Acupressure group or the Control group. Data will be collected using the VAS and analyzed using statistical software.

Keywords: Back Pain, Late postpartum, Cesarean Section.

Title: Effects of Paroxetine on Cardiovascular Function in Septic Patients

Objective: To investigate the effect of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in patients with septic shock.

Design: Randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel assignment trial with a quadruple-masked design.

Eligibility criteria: Patients aged 18 years or older with septic shock for less than 48 hours, using a minimum dose of noradrenaline, and able to provide informed consent.

Intervention: Patients were randomized to receive either paroxetine (40mg/day for 5 consecutive days or until shock resolution) or placebo.

Primary outcome measure: Time to vasopressor discontinuation for at least 48 consecutive hours.

Secondary outcome measures: Cumulative vasopressor dose in the first 48 hours, variation in cardiovascular sequential organ failure assessment score, cumulative vasopressor dose for 120 hours, total sequential organ failure assessment score variation, length of stay in the ICU, and mortality during ICU stay.

The study was terminated early due to the lack of apparent benefit from the fluoxetine arm, and the results are expected to provide insights into the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in septic patients.

Title: Paramedical Tele-education on Moderate Depressive Episodes

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a tele-education program on moderate depressive episodes in primary care, compared to standard care.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with two arms: experimental group receiving a 5-session tele-education program on depression, and control group receiving standard care.

Intervention: The tele-education program is a personalized, 5-session program delivered via remote sessions, focusing on educational diagnosis, personalized hygienic and dietary measures, symptom identification, destigmatization, mobilization of family and friends, and treatment information.

Primary Outcome Measure: Medication adherence at 6 months post-inclusion.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Effectiveness of the tele-education program on changes in feelings of self-efficacy and barriers to treatment at 3 months post-inclusion.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients with a moderate depressive episode, prescribed an antidepressant within the last 2 months, with internet access, and able to complete self-questionnaires.

Ages Eligible: 18 years and older.

Sexes Eligible: All.

Accepts Healthy Volunteers: No.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the tele-education program in improving medication adherence and reducing barriers to treatment in patients with moderate depressive episodes in primary care.

**Study Title:** Transdermal Microneedle Lignocaine Delivery Versus EMLA Patch for Topical Analgesia Before Venepuncture Procedure To Adults in Clinical Setting

**Objective:** To compare the efficacy of a lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch with the standard EMLA patch in reducing pain during venepuncture procedures in adults undergoing eye surgery.

**Design:** Prospective, phase I/II, randomized, triple-blind, two-parallel group, active-controlled trial.

**Population:** Adults aged 18 years and above undergoing venous cannulation for blood investigations before eye surgery.

**Interventions:** Participants will receive either a lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch or a standard EMLA patch applied on the dorsal aspect of the hand for 30 minutes before venepuncture.

**Key Findings:** The study aims to assess the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the lignocaine-impregnated microneedle patch compared to the standard EMLA patch in reducing pain during venepuncture procedures.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of psychopharmacological treatment, Cognitive Behavioral Couple Therapy (CBCT), and their combination in reducing symptoms of distress and improving quality of life among couples during the perinatal period. The study is a randomized clinical trial that will enroll 200 high-risk couples experiencing perinatal distress. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of five groups: psychopharmacological intervention, CBCT intervention, combined intervention, placebo control, or no intervention.

The primary outcome measures include changes in the scores of the Parental Perinatal Distress Scale (PPDS), Multidimensional Scale for Perceived Social Support (MSPSS), Dyadic Coping Inventory (DCI), Flourishing Scale (FS), and World Health Organization's Quality of Life Brief (WOLQOL-BREF). The study will also assess the number of participants with treatment-related adverse events and changes in blood concentration levels for escitalopram, sertraline, and alprazolam.

The study will take place from August 15, 2023, to September 30, 2023, and will involve 10 sessions over a period of 6 months. The study aims to explore the effectiveness of different interventions in reducing symptoms of distress and improving quality of life among couples during the perinatal period.

Here is a clear, concise, and accurate summary of the clinical trial:

Title: A Phase 1/Phase 2 Open-label Study to Evaluate the Safety, Tolerability, and Efficacy of a Single Intravenous Administration of SAR444836 in Adult Participants With Phenylketonuria

Objective: To evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a single intravenous administration of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral vector-mediated gene transfer of human phenylalanine hydroxylase, in adult participants with phenylketonuria (PKU).

Eligibility: Adult males and females aged 18-65 years with a diagnosis of PKU due to PAH deficiency, with a historical plasma Phe value ≥ 600 μmol/L, and willing to maintain their current diet for the duration of the trial.

Intervention: Participants will receive a single dose of SAR444836 on Day 1 via intravenous infusion.

Primary Outcome Measures:

* Incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events (TEAEs)
* Proportion of participants with sustained plasma level of Phe <360 μmol/L for ≥4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96

Secondary Outcome Measures:

* Change from baseline in plasma level of Phe, dietary protein intake, and plasma Phe: Tyr ratio at Week 24 and Week 96
* Proportion of participants with sustained plasma level of Phe <600 μmol/L and <120 μmol/L for ≥4 weeks without dietary Phe restriction at Week 24 and Week 96
* Number of participants with abnormal laboratory chemistry values
* Assessment of the duration of viral vector shedding of SAR444836 in urine, saliva, and semen at 4-week intervals following administration.

This study aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of SAR444836 in adult participants with PKU, with a focus on the incidence of TEAEs and the proportion of participants with sustained plasma levels of Phe without dietary restriction.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the clinical applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL) as a substitute for fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The study includes 18-80 year old patients with MCI or SCD who provide signed informed consent. Exclusion criteria include contraindications to brain MRI, FDG-PET, or lumbar puncture, and known neurological or psychiatric comorbidities.

The study uses a single-arm design, where patients undergo a diagnostic test using pCASL sequence on a 3 Tesla MRI. The primary outcome measures include the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism at baseline, and the correlation between brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism according to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) profile.

Secondary outcome measures include differences among brain hypoperfusion patterns according to amyloid and tau status, correlations between brain hypoperfusion and neuropsychological tests, predictive properties of brain hypoperfusion and brain hypometabolism for conversion to dementia, and correlations between brain hypoperfusion and CSF and blood biomarkers.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical applicability of pCASL as a substitute for FDG-PET in MCI and SCD patients, and to investigate the potential of pCASL to predict conversion to dementia.

Title: RCT to Evaluate STERN FIX Device as a Sternal Stabilization System in Patients After Sternotomy

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness and safety of the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients undergoing median sternotomy surgery.

Study Design: Randomized controlled trial (RCT) with parallel assignment, double-blinded, and active comparator.

Eligibility Criteria: Patients undergoing median sternotomy surgery with at least one of the following risk criteria: obesity, diabetes, COPD, non-serious osteoporosis, creatinine > 200 µmol/L, or scheduled bilateral internal mammary artery grafting.

Interventions: Two arms:

1. Active Comparator: Combination of at least one STERN FIX device and surgical wires for a total of 5 fixation points.
2. Active Comparator: Standard of care median sternotomy closure method with surgical wires.

Primary Outcome Measure: Sternal stability, evaluated using the sternal instability scale (SIS) with grades 0 to 3, at 1 month after surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures: Safety, device deficiencies, reinterventions, sternal wound infections, dehiscence, sternal closure time, easiness of use, surgeon satisfaction, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb functional index, quality of life, sternal halves union/malunion, sternal halves alignment, sternum integrity, and closure system integrity.

Study Duration: 6 months after surgery.

Keywords: sternal closure, cardiac surgery, sternotomy.

Title: The Effect of an Active Break Intervention on Nonspecific Low Back Pain and Musculoskeletal Discomfort During Prolonged Sitting Among Young People

Objective: To evaluate the effect of an active break on reducing low back pain and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting in young people with non-specific low back pain.

Methodology: This is a randomized controlled trial with 50 participants aged 18-25 years with non-specific low back pain. Participants were randomly assigned to either an experimental group receiving an active break with lumbar and hip extension exercises or a control group receiving self-care recommendations.

Primary outcomes:

* Average pain intensity (Visual Analogue Scale)
* Disability (Oswestry Disability Index)
* Perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting (Borg CR-10 scale)
* Global Perceived Effect (7-point Likert scale)

Secondary outcomes:

* Post-Intervention Questionnaire (5-item self-completed questionnaire)

The study aims to develop an exercise protocol and intervention to reduce low back pain and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting, and to build evidence-based practice for students, teachers, health professionals, and family doctors.

Title: Performance and Safety of Vaginal Administration of Tocopherol Acetate (Vitamin E) in Pre-Peri and Postmenopausal Women

Objective: To evaluate the performance and safety of vaginal administration of tocopherol acetate (vitamin E) in pre-peri and postmenopausal women.

Study Design: A 14-day, single-arm, open-label study in pre-peri and postmenopausal women.

Inclusion Criteria: Women aged 50-70 years, with premenopause, perimenopause, or postmenopause status, able to comply with the study requirements and provide informed consent.

Intervention: Vaginal administration of tocopherol acetate (Filme Gyno-V Vaginal Ovules) for 14 days.

Duration: The study will run from January 1, 2020, to December 31, 2022, with data collection from June 30, 2023, to July 31, 2023.

Title: Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) in Palliative Care: a Randomised, Double-blind, Active-placebo Controlled Phase II Study

Objective: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of Lysergic Acid Diethylamide (LSD) in palliative care patients with end-stage fatal disease, focusing on symptoms such as pain, anxiety, depression, demoralization, and spiritual well-being.

Design: Randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II study with two arms: experimental (LSD 100 μg or 200 μg) and active comparator (LSD 25 μg).

Population: Patients with end-stage fatal disease, aged 25 years or older, with a life expectancy of 12 weeks to 2 years, and sufficient understanding of the study procedures.

Outcome measures:

* Primary outcome measures: changes in state anxiety, pain levels, and spiritual well-being
* Secondary outcome measures: changes in opioid use, demoralization, quality of life, anxiety, and caregiver burden
* Additional outcomes: acute LSD effects, long-lasting therapeutic effects, burden of suffering, and subjective changes after intervention

Duration: The study will last up to 9 weeks after the second intervention.

Adverse events will be monitored throughout the study, and vital signs will be recorded before and after drug administration. The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of LSD in palliative care patients and explore its potential therapeutic effects.

Title: Teaching by Texting to Promote Health Behaviours in Pregnancy (SmartMom)

Objective: To evaluate the effectiveness of a text messaging program (SmartMom) in promoting healthy behaviors and improving pregnancy outcomes among pregnant women.

Design: Randomized controlled trial with two arms: SmartMom messaging (intervention) and control messaging.

Eligibility: Pregnant women at 15 weeks gestation or earlier, able to read and understand English at grade 8 level, and living in Canada (excluding British Columbia).

Intervention: Participants in the SmartMom arm receive three text messages per week with evidence-based information to promote healthy behaviors during pregnancy, while control arm participants receive one text message per week with general information about pregnancy.

Primary outcomes: Change in weight during pregnancy, attendance at prenatal care visits, and rate of pregnancy weight gain.

Secondary outcomes: Changes in health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, and use of tobacco, vaping, alcohol, or cannabis. Additionally, the study assesses rates of planned vaginal birth after cesarean, exclusive breastfeeding at hospital discharge, and adverse pregnancy outcomes such as gestational diabetes, stillbirth, preterm birth, and small for gestational age status.

The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the SmartMom program in improving pregnancy outcomes and reducing the risk of adverse events, while also evaluating its cost-effectiveness.
